Epiglottitis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Epiglottitis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Epiglottitis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Epiglottitis is inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. In most cases, it's caused by infection. The epiglottis is a flap of tissue that sits beneath the tongue at the back of the throat.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epiglottitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-05-02T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-05-02T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epiglottitis/", "name": "Epiglottitis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-24T11:29:31+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epiglottitis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Epiglottitis"}], "keywords": ["Epiglottitis"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epiglottitis is inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis. It's often caused by an infection, but can also sometimes happen as a result of a throat injury.

The epiglottis is a flap of tissue that sits beneath the tongue at the back of the throat.

Its main function is to close over the windpipe (trachea) while you're eating to prevent food entering your airway.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of epiglottitis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The symptoms of epiglottitis usually develop quickly and get rapidly worse, although they can develop over a few days in older children and adults.

Symptoms include:

  • a severe sore throat
  • difficulty and pain when swallowing
  • difficulty breathing, which may improve when leaning forwards
  • breathing that sounds abnormal and high-pitched (stridor)
  • a high temperature (fever) of 38C or above
  • irritability and restlessness
  • muffled or hoarse voice
  • drooling

The main symptoms of epiglottitis in young children are breathing difficulties, stridor and a hoarse voice.

In adults and older children, swallowing difficulties and drooling are the main symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When to seek medical advice", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epiglottitis is regarded as a medical emergency, as\u00a0a swollen epiglottis can restrict the oxygen supply to your lungs.

Call 999 for an ambulance if you think you or your child has epiglottitis.

While waiting for an ambulance, you should not attempt to examine\u00a0your child's throat, place anything inside their mouth, or lay them on their back. This may make their symptoms worse.

It's important to keep them calm and to try not to cause panic or distress.

Epiglottitis can be fatal if the throat becomes completely blocked. But most people\u00a0make a full recovery with appropriate treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating epiglottitis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epiglottitis is treated in hospital. The first thing the medical team will do is secure the person's airways to make sure\u00a0they can breathe properly.

Securing the airways

An\u00a0oxygen mask will be given to deliver highly concentrated oxygen to the person's lungs.

If this does not work, a tube will be placed in the person's mouth and pushed past their epiglottis into the windpipe. The tube will be connected to an oxygen supply.

In severe cases where there's an urgent need to secure the airways, a small cut may be made in the neck at the front of the windpipe so a tube can be inserted. The tube is then connected to an oxygen supply.

This procedure is called a tracheostomy and it allows oxygen to enter the lungs while bypassing the epiglottis.

An emergency tracheostomy can be carried out using local anaesthetic or general anaesthetic.

Once the airways have been secured and the person is able to breathe unrestricted, a more comfortable and convenient way of assisting breathing may be found.

This is usually achieved by threading a tube through the nose and into the windpipe.

Fluids will be supplied through a drip into a vein until the person is able to swallow.

Once this has been achieved and the situation is thought to be safe, some tests may be carried out, such as:

  • a fibreoptic laryngoscopy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a flexible tube with a camera attached to one end (laryngoscope) is used to examine the throat
  • a throat swab\u00a0\u2013\u00a0to test for any bacteria or viruses
  • blood tests\u00a0\u2013\u00a0to check the number of white blood cells (a\u00a0high number indicates there may an infection) and\u00a0identify any traces of bacteria or viruses in the blood
  • an\u00a0X-ray or a\u00a0CT scan\u00a0\u2013\u00a0sometimes used\u00a0to check the level of swelling

Any underlying infection will be treated with a\u00a0course of antibiotics.

With prompt treatment, most people recover from epiglottitis after about a week and are well enough to leave hospital after 5 to 7 days.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Why it happens", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epiglottitis is usually caused by an infection with\u00a0Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria.

As well as epiglottitis, Hib can cause a number of serious infections, such as pneumonia\u00a0and meningitis.

It spreads in the same way as the cold or flu virus. The bacteria are\u00a0in\u00a0the tiny droplets of saliva and mucus propelled into the air when an\u00a0infected person coughs or sneezes.

You\u00a0catch the infection by breathing in these droplets or, if the droplets have landed on a surface or object, by touching this\u00a0surface and then touching your face or mouth.

Less common causes of epiglottitis include:

  • other bacterial infections \u2013\u00a0such as streptococcus pneumoniae (a common cause of pneumonia)
  • fungal infections \u2013 people with a weakened immune system are most at risk from these types of infection
  • viral infections \u2013\u00a0such as the varicella zoster virus (the virus responsible for chickenpox) and the herpes simplex virus (the virus responsible for cold sores)
  • trauma to the throat\u00a0\u2013\u00a0such as a blow to the throat, or burning the throat by drinking very hot liquids
  • smoking \u2013\u00a0particularly\u00a0illegal drugs, such as cannabis or crack cocaine
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Hib vaccination", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The most effective way to prevent your child getting epiglottitis is to make sure\u00a0their vaccinations are up-to-date.

Children are particularly vulnerable to a Hib infection because they have an underdeveloped immune system.

Babies should be vaccinated against Hib as part of the 6-in-1 DTaP/IPV/Hib vaccine, which also protects against diphtheria, hepatitis B, tetanus,\u00a0whooping cough and polio.

They should receive 3 doses of the vaccine:\u00a0at 8 weeks, 12 weeks and 16 weeks of age. This is followed by an additional\u00a0Hib/Men C "booster" vaccine at 1 year of age.

Contact your GP if you're not sure whether your child's vaccinations are up-to-date.

Read more about the childhood vaccination schedule.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Who's affected", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Because of the success of the Hib vaccination programme, epiglottitis is rare in the UK, and\u00a0most cases now occur in adults.

Deaths from epiglottitis are\u00a0also rare, occurring in\u00a0less than 1 in 100 cases.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Erythema multiforme:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Erythema multiforme", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Erythema multiforme", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about erythema multiforme, a skin reaction that usually causes a rash for a few weeks.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythema-multiforme/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-09-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-09-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythema-multiforme/", "name": "Erythema multiforme", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-09-25T11:28:53+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythema-multiforme/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Erythema multiforme"}], "keywords": ["Itching", "Cold sores", "Skin specialists", "Herpes simplex eye infections", "Allergies", "Infections", "Rashes and skin problems", "Skin", "allergy support"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Erythema multiforme is a skin reaction that can be triggered by an infection or some medicines. It's usually mild and goes away in a few weeks.

There's also a rare, severe form that can affect the mouth, genitals and eyes and can be life-threatening. This is known as erythema multiforme major.

Erythema multiforme mainly affects adults under 40, although it can happen at any age.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of erythema multiforme", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of erythema multiforme

Most people with erythema multiforme will just have a rash, but other symptoms can sometimes occur.

Rash

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The rash starts suddenly and develops over a few days. It tends to start on the hands or feet, before spreading to the limbs, upper body and face.

The rash:

  • starts as small red spots, which may become raised patches a few centimetres in size
  • often has patches that look like a target or "bulls-eye", with a dark red centre that may have a blister or crust, surrounded by a pale pink ring and a darker outermost ring
  • may be slightly itchy or uncomfortable
  • usually fades over 2 to 4 weeks

In more severe cases, the patches may join together to form large, red areas that may be raw and painful.

Other symptoms

Additional symptoms of erythema multiforme can include:

  • a high temperature
  • a headache
  • feeling generally unwell
  • raw sores inside your mouth, making it hard to eat and drink
  • swollen lips covered in crusts
  • sores on the genitals, making it painful to pee
  • sore, red eyes
  • sensitivity to light and blurred vision
  • aching joints 

These symptoms are more common in erythema multiforme major or a similar condition called Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to get medical advice

See a GP as soon as possible if you think you or your child may have erythema multiforme.

A GP may be able to diagnose it just by looking at the rash, but they can refer you to a skin specialist (dermatologist) if they're not sure.

If erythema multiforme major or Stevens-Johnson syndrome is suspected, you'll be referred to hospital immediately because these conditions can be serious.

If you're unable to see a GP, call NHS 111 or go to 111.nhs.uk

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of erythema multiforme", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of erythema multiforme

The cause of erythema multiforme is often unclear, but some cases are the result of a reaction to an infection or medicine.

The condition cannot be passed from person to person.

Infections

Most cases are caused by a viral infection – often the herpes simplex (cold sore) virus. This virus usually lies inactive in the body, but it can become reactivated from time to time.

Some people will get a cold sore a few days before the rash starts.

Erythema multiforme can also be triggered by mycoplasma bacteria, a type of bacteria that sometimes cause chest infections.

Medicines

Some medicines can occasionally cause the more severe form of erythema multiforme. Possible medicine triggers include:

  • antibiotics, such as sulfonamides, tetracyclines, amoxicillin and ampicillin
  • non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen
  • anticonvulsants (used to treat epilepsy), such as phenytoin and barbiturates
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments for erythema multiforme", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments for erythema multiforme

Treatment aims to tackle the underlying cause of the condition, relieve your symptoms and stop your skin becoming infected.

Your doctor may recommend:

  • stopping any medicine that may be triggering your symptoms – do not try this without speaking to your doctor first
  • antihistamines and moisturising cream (emollients) to reduce itching
  • steroid cream to reduce redness and swelling (inflammation)
  • painkillers for any pain
  • antiviral tablets, if the cause is a viral infection
  • anaesthetic mouthwash to ease the discomfort of any mouth sores

More severe cases may be treated in hospital with:

  • stronger painkillers
  • wound dressings to stop your sores becoming infected
  • a softened or liquid diet if your mouth is badly affected – some people may need fluids given through a drip into a vein
  • steroid tablets to control the inflammation
  • antibiotics if you have or develop a bacterial infection
  • eye drops or ointment if your eyes are affected
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of erythema multiforme", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of erythema multiforme

Most people with erythema multiforme make a full recovery within a few weeks. There are usually no further problems and the skin heals without scarring.

There is a risk the condition could come back at some point, especially if it was caused by the herpes simplex virus.

You may be given antiviral medicine to prevent attacks if you experience them frequently.

In severe cases, possible complications can include:

  • sepsis
  • a skin infection (cellulitis)
  • permanent skin damage and scarring
  • permanent eye damage
  • inflammation of internal organs, such as the lungs or liver
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

You may also have flu-like symptoms, such as:

  • try ibuprofen

A GP should be able to tell if you have erythema nodosum by looking at the bumps and patches.

If the GP thinks a medicine you've been taking might be causing erythema nodosum, you may be advised to stop taking it. Do not stop taking your medicines without asking a GP first.

The GP might arrange some tests if erythema nodosum:

  • could be a sign of something more serious
  • has not cleared within 8 weeks
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of erythema nodosum", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Erythema nodosum can be caused by lots of things, but often the cause is not known.

Common causes include:

  • Crohn's disease
  • ulcerative colitis
  • a reaction to some medicines
  • sarcoidosis
  • tuberculosis
  • pneumonia
  • a throat infection
  • a fungal infection

Erythromelalgia:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Erythromelalgia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Erythromelalgia", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about erythromelalgia, which is a rare condition that causes episodes of burning pain and redness in the hands and feet, and sometimes the arms, legs, ears and face.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-09T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-09T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/", "name": "Erythromelalgia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-19T15:10:47+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#overview", "description": "Erythromelalgia is a rare condition that causes burning pain and redness in certain parts of the body.", "text": "

Erythromelalgia mainly affects the feet. Symptoms include heat, pain and redness.

Cooling or raising the area may help relieve erythromelalgia. There are also creams, gels, sprays, tablets and medicines given into a vein.

It's often not clear what causes erythromelalgia. Sometimes it's caused by another medical condition or a faulty gene inherited from a parent.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#symptoms", "description": "Erythromelalgia mainly affects the feet. Symptoms include heat, pain and redness.", "text": "

The 3 main symptoms of erythromelalgia are heat, pain and redness in the skin.

The feet are most commonly affected, but\u00a0the hands, arms, legs, ears and face can be too.

The pain can range from mild, with only a slight tingling feeling like pins and needles, to a severe burning pain, which can be bad enough to make walking, standing, socialising, exercising and sleeping difficult.

It can have a significant impact on work or school life.

People with erythromelalgia typically have episodes or \"flare-ups\" of pain lasting from a few minutes to several days.

The flare-ups usually start as an itching sensation, which worsens to pain, and tender mottled, red skin that feels warm or hot to the touch.

Other symptoms may include:

  • swelling of the affected\u00a0body part
  • sweating in the affected area\u00a0more or less than you\u00a0usually would
  • purple discolouration when there's no flare-up
", "title": "Symptoms of erythromelalgia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#treatments-summary", "description": "Cooling or raising the area may help relieve erythromelalgia. There are also creams, gels, sprays, tablets and medicines given into a vein.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#self-care", "description": "Cooling or raising the area may help relieve erythromelalgia. There are also creams, gels, sprays, tablets and medicines given into a vein.", "text": "

Cooling or\u00a0raising the affected part of your body may help relieve the symptoms of erythromelalgia.

You can cool your skin using a fan, cool water, a cool surface or cool gel packs.

But avoid using ice or anything that's too cold, and do not soak your hands or feet for a long time in cold water.

This can lead to hypothermia or skin damage.

And there's also a risk the change in temperature may trigger a flare-up when the affected area\u00a0warms up again.

", "title": "Things you can do to ease erythromelalgia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#treatments-other", "description": "Cooling or raising the area may help relieve erythromelalgia. There are also creams, gels, sprays, tablets and medicines given into a vein.", "text": "

Medicines for the skin

Some medicines that are applied directly to the skin (topical medicines) have been found to help relieve the symptoms of erythromelalgia.

These may be in the form of creams, gels, sprays or patches. You may be prescribed a capsaicin cream or patch to make the heat receptors in your skin less sensitive.

A local anaesthetic called lidocaine may also be prescribed in the form of a cream, gel or spray.

A GP will be able to give you more information about these medicines and if they're right for you.

You can also speak to a pharmacist about lidocaine creams.

Medicines taken by mouth

A number of different medicines taken by mouth (orally) may help relieve the symptoms of erythromelalgia.

You may need to try several different medicines, under the supervision of a doctor, before you find the one or the combination that works best for you.

Your treatment options will also depend on the type of erythromelalgia you have.

Many treatments require referral to a specialist centre so benefits and potential side effects can be closely monitored.

The types of medicine a doctor may prescribe include:

  • dietary supplements \u2013 such as magnesium, which can help open up your blood vessels
  • aspirin \u2013 only used for adults, not for children
  • anti-epilepsy medicines \u2013 such as gabapentin or carbamazepine
  • blood pressure medicines \u2013 medicine to either open up your blood vessels and increase blood flow, or beta blockers to help reduce blood flow, depending on the cause of your erythromelalgia
  • low doses of antidepressants \u2013 such as duloxetine, venlafaxine, amitriptyline or nortriptyline
  • prescription-only painkillers

Medicines given through a drip

If oral medicine does not manage to control your symptoms, you may be given medicine directly into the bloodstream through a drip (intravenous infusion).

Lidocaine, a local anaesthetic that can help nerve-related pain, can be given this way. But how long it works for varies between people.

Your doctor will explain this procedure to you and how you should prepare for it.

", "title": "Treatments for erythromelalgia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erythromelalgia/#causes", "description": "It's often not clear what causes erythromelalgia. Sometimes it's caused by another medical condition or a faulty gene inherited from a parent.", "text": "

The cause of erythromelalgia is usually unknown.

But it's sometimes caused by another underlying medical condition or a faulty gene inherited from a parent.

Other medical conditions

Erythromelalgia sometimes results from an underlying condition, such as:

  • a blood disorder \u2013 like polycythaemia
  • nerve damage \u2013 for example, caused by peripheral neuropathy
  • multiple sclerosis (MS)
  • an autoimmune problem \u2013 such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues

It may also be caused by certain medicines. Your doctor will be able to give you more information on this.

Genetic cause

Some people with erythromelalgia have a faulty gene that causes the condition.

Erythromelalgia can run in families when the faulty gene is passed down (inherited) from a parent to their child.

The faulty gene causes changes in the way pain signals are delivered to the brain, increasing or strengthening them.

Symptoms of erythromelalgia can begin at any age. Some people may have had it from early childhood, while some are only affected as adults.

  • multiple sclerosis (MS)
  • an autoimmune problem \u2013 such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues

It may also be caused by certain medicines. Your doctor will be able to give you more information on this.

Genetic cause

Some people with erythromelalgia have a faulty gene that causes the condition.

Erythromelalgia can run in families when the faulty gene is passed down (inherited) from a parent to their child.

The faulty gene causes changes in the way pain signals are delivered to the brain, increasing or strengthening them.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "More information and support", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Specialist centres in the UK

  • For children: Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children Pain Control Service
  • For adults: National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery Pain Management Centre

Organisations that provide support

  • The Erythromelalgia Association
  • Foundation for Peripheral Neuropathy
  • Pain Concern
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you or your child has erythromelalgia, your clinical team will pass the\u00a0information\u00a0on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat erythromelalgia. You can opt out of the register at any time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Euthanasia and assisted suicide:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Euthanasia and assisted suicide", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Euthanasia and assisted suicide", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about euthanasia (deliberately ending a person's life to relieve suffering) and assisted suicide (deliberately assisting a person to kill themselves). Both are illegal in England.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/euthanasia-and-assisted-suicide/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-28T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-07-28T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/euthanasia-and-assisted-suicide/", "name": "Euthanasia and assisted suicide", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-07-31T16:24:08+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/euthanasia-and-assisted-suicide/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Euthanasia and assisted suicide"}], "keywords": ["Assisted suicide and euthanasia", "Suicide"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Euthanasia is the act of deliberately ending a person's life to relieve suffering.

For example, it could be considered euthanasia if a doctor deliberately gave a patient with a terminal illness a drug they do not otherwise need, such as an overdose of sedatives or muscle relaxant, with the sole aim of ending their life.

Assisted suicide is the act of deliberately assisting another person to kill themselves. If a relative of a person with a terminal illness obtained strong sedatives, knowing the person intended to use them to kill themselves, the relative may be considered to be assisting suicide.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "The law", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The law

Both euthanasia and assisted suicide are illegal under English law.

Assisted suicide

Assisted suicide is illegal under the terms of the Suicide Act (1961) and is punishable by up to 14 years' imprisonment. Trying to kill yourself is not a criminal act.

Euthanasia

Depending on the circumstances, euthanasia is regarded as either manslaughter or murder. The maximum penalty is life imprisonment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of euthanasia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of euthanasia

Euthanasia can be classified as:

  • voluntary euthanasia \u2013 where a person makes a conscious decision to die and asks for help to do\u00a0so
  • non-voluntary euthanasia \u2013 where a person is unable to give their\u00a0consent\u00a0(for example, because they're in a\u00a0coma)\u00a0and another person takes the decision on their behalf, perhaps because the ill person previously expressed a wish for their life to be ended in such circumstances
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "End of life care", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

End of life care

When you're approaching the last stage of your life, you have a right to high quality, personalised\u00a0end of life care\u00a0that helps you live as well as possible until you die.

Find out more about:

  • where you can receive your care, including in a hospice
  • coping with a terminal diagnosis
  • ways to start talking about the fact you're dying
  • managing pain and other symptoms
  • coping financially and benefits entitlement
  • making a legally binding advance decision to refuse treatment
  • creating a lasting power of attorney\u00a0so someone you trust can make decisions for you if you cannot make them in the future
  • why it can help to plan ahead for your future care

Find palliative care services near you.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Ewing sarcoma:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Ewing sarcoma", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Ewing sarcoma", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about Ewing sarcoma, a rare type of bone cancer. Read about the symptoms and how it's diagnosed and treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/ewing-sarcoma/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-06T00:00:00+00:00", "2020-07-06T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/ewing-sarcoma/", "name": "Ewing sarcoma", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-07-17T15:25:08+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/ewing-sarcoma/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Ewing sarcoma"}], "keywords": ["Cancer and tumours", "Bone cancer"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Ewing sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects bones or the tissue around bones.

It mainly affects children and young people, but is also seen in adults. It's more common in males than females.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and cancer:

  • Macmillan: Coronavirus guidance for people with cancer
  • Cancer Research UK: Coronavirus and cancer
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of Ewing sarcoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of Ewing sarcoma

Symptoms include:

  • bone pain\u00a0\u2013 this may get worse over time and may be\u00a0worse at night
  • a tender lump or swelling
  • a high temperature that does not go away
  • feeling tired all the time
  • unintentional weight loss

Affected bones may also be weaker and more likely to break. Some people are diagnosed after they have a fracture.

The legs (often around the knee), pelvis, arms, ribs and spine are the main areas affected by Ewing sarcoma.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tests\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tests\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma

Ewing sarcoma can be difficult to diagnose because it's quite rare and the symptoms can be similar to lots of other conditions.

Several tests may be needed to diagnose the cancer and see where it is in the body.

These tests may include:

  • an\u00a0X-ray
  • blood tests
  • an\u00a0MRI scan, a\u00a0CT\u00a0scan\u00a0or a\u00a0PET\u00a0scan
  • a bone scan\u00a0\u2013\u00a0after having an injection of a slightly radioactive substance that makes the bones show up clearly
  • a bone\u00a0biopsy, where a\u00a0small sample of bone is removed so it can be checked for signs of cancer and certain genetic changes associated with Ewing sarcoma
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma

Treatment for Ewing sarcoma often involves a combination of:

  • radiotherapy\u00a0\u2013 where radiation is used to kill cancer cells
  • chemotherapy\u00a0\u2013 where medicine is used to kill cancer cells
  • surgery\u00a0to remove the cancer

As Ewing sarcoma is rare and the treatment complicated, you should be treated by a specialist team. They'll recommend a treatment plan based on where the cancer is and its size.

Talk to your care team about why they've suggested the treatment plan, and ask them to go over the benefits and any risks involved. You may also want to discuss what care you might need afterwards.

Radiotherapy

Radiotherapy is often used to treat Ewing sarcoma before and after surgery, or it may be used instead of surgery if the cancer cannot be removed safely.

Chemotherapy

Most people with Ewing sarcoma have chemotherapy to shrink the cancer and then surgery to remove as much of it as possible. This is often followed by further chemotherapy to kill any leftover cancer cells.

Surgery

If Ewing sarcoma affects your bones, you'll need surgery at a specialist bone cancer centre.

There are 3 main types of surgery for Ewing sarcoma. Surgery can be used to remove:

  • the affected bone or tissue \u2013 this is called a resection
  • the bit of bone containing cancer and replacing it with a piece of metal or bone taken from another part of the body \u2013 this is called limb-sparing surgery
  • all or part of an arm or leg \u2013 this is called an amputation

If you have an arm or leg amputated, you may need a prosthetic limb and support to help you regain the use of the affected limb.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook\u00a0for Ewing sarcoma

Ewing sarcoma can spread to other parts of the body quite quickly. The earlier it's diagnosed, the better the chance of treatment being successful.

It can sometimes be cured, but this might not be possible if the cancer has spread.

The cancer can also come back after treatment, so you'll be offered regular check-ups to look for any signs of this. Some people need treatment for many years.

Around 6 out of 10 people with Ewing sarcoma live at least 5 years after being diagnosed. But this can vary and some people live much longer.

Speak to your care team about the chances of your treatment being successful.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "More\u00a0information and support", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

More\u00a0information and support

Being told you or your child has\u00a0cancer can be\u00a0very\u00a0upsetting and overwhelming.

As well\u00a0as the support from\u00a0your care team, you may find it\u00a0useful to get information and advice\u00a0from charities and support groups.

The main organisations for Ewing sarcoma are:

  • Sarcoma UK\u00a0\u2013 which has information on Ewing sarcoma\u00a0as well as general support for people with sarcoma
  • Bone Cancer Research Trust\u00a0\u2013 which has information on Ewing sarcoma\u00a0and support for people with bone cancer

Other good sources of information and support for cancer include:

  • Macmillan Cancer Support
  • Cancer Research UK
  • CLIC Sargent
  • Children's Cancer and Leukaemia Group

There may be a clinical trial suitable for your or your child \u2013 ask your doctor for further information. You can also find out about clinical trials for Ewing sarcoma at the\u00a0Euro Ewing Consortium and Cancer Research UK clinical trials.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomni:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)", "alternateName": ["Hypersomnia"]}, "description": "Read about excessive daytime sleepiness (idiopathic hypersomnia), an unexplained condition that causes you to feel very sleepy during the day, even if you had a good night's sleep.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/excessive-daytime-sleepiness-hypersomnia/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-08-04T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-08-04T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/excessive-daytime-sleepiness-hypersomnia/", "name": "Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-18T13:38:44+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/excessive-daytime-sleepiness-hypersomnia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)"}], "keywords": ["Sleeping problems", "Narcolepsy", "Sleep disorders", "Drowsiness", "Obstructive sleep apnoea", "Lifestyle changes", "Sleep health"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia) is a condition where people fall asleep repeatedly during the day; sometimes in the middle of eating a meal or during a conversation.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if it's hypersomnia

Excessive daytime sleepiness is different from feeling tired all the time.

If you have hypersomnia, you may:

  • regularly nap during the day and not feel refreshed
  • fall asleep during the day, often while eating or talking
  • still sleep for long hours at night
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you often fall asleep during the day
  • sleepiness is affecting your life
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

The GP will want to find out why you're sleeping excessively. They might:

  • ask you about possible causes of your sleepiness, such mental or physical health problems, or any medicines you may be taking
  • suggest you keep a diary of when you sleep
  • refer you to a doctor who specialises in sleep disorders

Treatment for excessive sleepiness will depend on what's causing it. It may include medicine to help keep you awake.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of hypersomnia

Conditions that may be related to excessive sleepiness include:

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Additional symptoms Possible cause
Falling into a deep sleep anywhere, without warning narcolepsy
Loud snorting, breathing and snoring at night sleep apnoea
An unusual feeling in your legs, particularly at night restless legs syndrome
Low mood, little interest in things and feeling irritable depression
Mood swings that range from extreme highs (mania) to extreme lows bipolar disorder
"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some medicines, drinking too much alcohol and taking drugs can also cause excessive daytime sleepiness.

Sometimes there is no cause. This is called idiopathic hypersomnia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things you can try to help your sleeping habits", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can try to help your sleeping habits

Changing your sleep habits may not cure hypersomnia, but it might help you feel better.

Try to:

  • go to bed at the same time every night
  • avoid drinking alcohol and caffeine
  • create a peaceful sleeping environment
  • if possible, avoid medicines that can cause drowsiness
  • avoid working late into the night

It might also help to talk to your family and friends about your excessive daytime sleepiness so they're aware of it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Eye cancer:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Eye cancer", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Eye cancer", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about eye cancer, including the symptoms, causes, treatments, and outlook.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-cancer/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-15T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-01-15T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-cancer/", "name": "Eye cancer", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-22T14:12:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-cancer/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Eye cancer"}], "keywords": ["Eye cancer", "Eye", "Cancer and tumours"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Around 750 cases of eye cancer (ocular cancer) are diagnosed in the UK each year.

There are a number of different types of cancer that affect the eyes, including:

  • eye melanoma
  • squamous cell carcinoma
  • lymphoma
  • retinoblastoma \u2013 a childhood cancer

Cancer can also sometimes develop in the tissues surrounding your eyeball or spread to the eye from other\u00a0parts of the body, such as the lungs or breasts.

This topic focuses on melanoma of the eye, one of the most common types of eye cancer.\u00a0

The Cancer Research UK website has\u00a0more information about the other types of eye cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and cancer:

  • Macmillan: Coronavirus guidance for people with cancer
  • Cancer Research UK: Coronavirus and cancer
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of eye cancer", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of eye cancer

Eye cancer does not always cause obvious symptoms and may only be picked up during a routine eye test.

Symptoms of eye cancer can include:

  • shadows, flashes of light, or wiggly lines in your vision
  • blurred vision
  • a dark patch in your\u00a0eye that's getting bigger
  • partial or total loss of vision
  • bulging of 1 eye
  • a lump on your eyelid or in\u00a0your eye that's increasing in size
  • pain in or around your eye, although this is rare

These symptoms can also be caused by more minor eye conditions, so they're not necessarily a sign of cancer.

But it's important to get the symptoms\u00a0checked by a doctor as soon as possible.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Melanoma\u00a0of the eye", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Melanoma\u00a0of the eye

Melanoma is cancer that develops from pigment-producing cells called melanocytes.

Most\u00a0melanomas develop in the skin, but it's also possible for them to occur in other parts of the body, including the eye.

Eye melanoma most commonly affects the eyeball. Doctors sometimes call it\u00a0uveal or choroidal melanoma, depending on exactly which part of your eye is affected.

It\u00a0can also affect the conjunctiva (the thin\u00a0layer that covers the front of the eye) or the eyelid.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What\u00a0causes eye melanoma?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What\u00a0causes eye melanoma?

Eye melanoma occurs when\u00a0the pigment-producing cells in the eyes divide and multiply too rapidly. This produces a lump of tissue known as a tumour.

It's not clear exactly why this occurs, but the following factors may increase the risk of it happening:

  • lighter eye colour \u2013 if you have blue, grey or green eyes, you have a higher risk of developing eye melanoma compared\u00a0with people who have brown eyes
  • white or pale skin \u2013 eye melanoma mostly affects white people and is more common in\u00a0those with fair skin
  • unusual moles \u2013 if you have\u00a0irregularly shaped or unusually coloured moles, you're more at risk of developing skin cancer and eye melanoma
  • use of sunbeds\u00a0\u2013\u00a0there's some evidence to suggest that exposing yourself to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunbeds, for example, can increase your risk of eye melanoma
  • overexposure to sunlight \u2013 this increases your risk of skin cancer, and may also be a risk factor for eye melanoma

The risk of developing eye melanoma also increases with age, with most cases being diagnosed in people in their 50s.

Read about the risk factors for other types of eye cancer\u00a0on the Cancer Research UK website.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Diagnosing\u00a0melanoma of the eye", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing\u00a0melanoma of the eye

If your GP or optician (optometrist) suspects\u00a0you have a serious problem with your eyes, they'll refer you to a specialist eye doctor called an ophthalmologist\u00a0for an assessment.

If they suspect you have melanoma of the eye, they'll refer you to a specialist centre for eye cancer.

There are 4 centres in the UK, located in London, Sheffield, Liverpool and Glasgow.

It's likely you'll have a number of different tests at the centre, including:

  • an eye examination \u2013\u00a0to look at the structures of your eyes in more detail and check for abnormalities
  • an ultrasound scan of your eye\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a small probe placed over your closed eye uses high-frequency sound waves to create an image of the inside of your eye; this allows\u00a0your doctor to\u00a0find\u00a0out more about the position of the tumour and its size
  • a\u00a0fluorescein angiogram\u00a0\u2013 where photographs of the suspected cancer are taken using a special camera after dye has been injected into your bloodstream to highlight the tumour

Occasionally,\u00a0a thin needle\u00a0may be\u00a0used to remove a small sample\u00a0of cells from\u00a0the\u00a0tumour (biopsy).\u00a0

The genetic information in these cells is analysed to\u00a0give an indication of the chances of the cancer spreading or coming back.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for\u00a0eye melanoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for\u00a0eye melanoma

Treatment for melanoma of the eye depends on the size and location of the tumour.

Your care team will explain each treatment option in detail, including the benefits and any potential complications.

Treatment will aim to conserve the affected eye whenever possible.

The main treatments for eye melanoma are:

  • brachytherapy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0tiny plates lined with radioactive material called plaques are inserted near\u00a0the tumour and left in place for up to a week to kill the cancerous cells
  • external\u00a0radiotherapy\u00a0\u2013 a machine is used to carefully aim beams of radiation at the tumour to kill the cancerous cells
  • surgery to remove the tumour or part of the eye \u2013 this may be possible if\u00a0the tumour is small and you still have some vision in your eye
  • removal of the eye (enucleation)\u00a0\u2013 this may be necessary if the tumour is large or you have lost your vision;\u00a0the eye will eventually be replaced with an artificial eye that matches\u00a0your other eye

Chemotherapy is rarely used for eye melanoma, but may be suitable for other types of eye cancer.

The\u00a0Cancer Research UK website has more information about the treatment options for eye cancer and the types of eye cancer surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for eye melanoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook\u00a0for eye melanoma

The outlook for melanoma of the eye depends on how\u00a0big the cancer is at the time it's diagnosed and exactly which parts of the eye are affected.

Overall:

  • about 8 out of every 10 people (80%) diagnosed with a small eye melanoma will live for at least 5 years after diagnosis
  • about 7 out of every 10 people (70%) diagnosed with a medium-sized eye melanoma will live for at least 5 years after diagnosis
  • about\u00a05\u00a0out of\u00a0every 10 people (50%) diagnosed with a large eye melanoma will live for at least 5 years after diagnosis

The\u00a0Cancer Research UK website has more information about the stages of\u00a0eye cancer\u00a0and\u00a0statistics and outlook for eye cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Eye injuries:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Eye injuries", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Eye injuries", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what to do if you have an eye injury, including when to get medical help.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-injuries/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-06-28T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-06-28T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-injuries/", "name": "Eye injuries", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-07-01T11:51:53+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eye-injuries/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Eye injuries"}], "keywords": ["DVLA", "Eye", "Uveitis", "Eye injuries", "Eye conditions"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Minor eye injuries, such as shampoo or dust in your eye, often get better on their own within a day. Get medical help if you have a chemical in your eye or something pierces it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Go to A&E or call 999 if:", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Go to A&E or call 999 if:

  • a strong chemical, such as oven cleaner or bleach, is in your eye – keep rinsing your eye with water while waiting for medical help
  • a sharp object has pierced your eye
  • something has hit your eye at high speed – for example, while using power tools or mowing the lawn
  • there are any changes to your sight after an eye injury
  • you have a headache, high temperature or sensitivity to light
  • you're feeling sick or being sick after an eye injury
  • you cannot move your eye or keep it open
  • blood or pus is coming from your eye

Find your nearest A&E

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How to treat an eye injury at home", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to treat an eye injury at home

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash your eye with clean water if there's something in it
  • follow the advice on the packaging if any cosmetics or household products get in your eyes
  • take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to help ease any pain or discomfort
"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not try to remove any object that's pierced your eye
  • do not touch or rub your eye until it's better
  • do not wear make-up around your eye until it's better
  • do not wear contact lenses until your eye is better
"}, {"position": 3, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to wash your eye

You should:

  • use clean water (not hot) – this can be from a tap, shower or bottled water if you’re not at home
  • hold your eye open
  • run lots of water over your eyeball for at least 20 minutes

Make sure the flow of water is not too strong.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "See a GP, optician or call 111 if:", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP, optician or call 111 if:

  • your eye is not getting better after 24 hours
  • you're worried about your injury
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

There is separate information about:

  • what to do if you have a black eye
  • what to do if you have a red eye
"}]}]}
Eyelid problems:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Eyelid problems", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Eyelid problems", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what to do if you have a lump on your eyelid, or an eyelid that's swollen, sticky, itchy, drooping or twitching.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eyelid-problems/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-02T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-02T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eyelid-problems/", "name": "Eyelid problems", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-05T18:25:26+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/eyelid-problems/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Eyelid problems"}], "keywords": ["Ectropion", "Blepharitis", "Cysts", "Dry eyes", "Eye symptoms", "Eye"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Most eyelid problems are harmless", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Many eyelid problems are not serious.

It's fairly common to have any of these problems:

  • a lump that goes away by itself after 3 or 4 weeks
  • mildly itchy, flaky or sticky eyelids that clear up by themselves
  • swelling from a nearby insect bite, injury or operation that goes away after a week or so
  • twitching or blinking from time to time – often when you're tired
  • eyelids that droop (or get more "hooded") as you get older
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Types of eyelid problems", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Your symptoms might give you an idea of the cause. Do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

Painful lump, filled with pus like a pimple stye
Hard lump, not painful chalazion (meibomian cyst)

Mole, freckle or patch changes shape, colour or size skin cancer

  • what you can do to treat it yourself

See a GP if:

  • you're worried about an eyelid problem
  • it's getting worse or lasting a long time
  • your eyelid is painful or you're in a lot of discomfort
  • you have yellow lumps or patches around your eyes
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Ask for an urgent GP appointment or call 111 if:

  • your swollen eyelid is red, hot, painful, tender or blistered
  • your eyelid droops suddenly
  • the pain is in your eye (not your eyelid)
  • the white of your eye is very red, in part or all over
  • you're sensitive to light (photophobia)
  • your eyesight changes – for example, you see wavy lines or flashing
  • you have a very high temperature, or feel hot and shivery, or you feel generally unwell
  • you think it's an allergic reaction

111 will tell you what to do. They can arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if you need one.

Go to NHS 111 or call 111.
