[{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

An ectopic pregnancy is when a fertilised egg implants itself outside of the womb, usually in one of the fallopian tubes.

The fallopian tubes are the tubes connecting the ovaries to the womb. If an egg gets stuck in them, it won't develop into a baby and your health may be at risk if the pregnancy continues.

Unfortunately, it's not possible to save the pregnancy. It usually has to be removed using medicine or an operation.

In the UK, around 1 in every 90 pregnancies is ectopic. This is around 11,000 pregnancies a year.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy

An ectopic pregnancy doesn't always cause symptoms and may only be detected during a routine pregnancy scan.

If you do have symptoms, they tend to develop between the 4th and 12th week of pregnancy.

Symptoms can include a combination of:

  • a missed period and other signs of pregnancy 
  • tummy pain low down on 1 side
  • vaginal bleeding or a brown watery discharge
  • pain in the tip of your shoulder
  • discomfort when peeing or pooing

But these symptoms aren't necessarily a sign of a serious problem. They can sometimes be caused by other problems, such as a stomach bug.

Read more about the symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to get medical advice

Contact your GP or call NHS 111 if you have a combination of any of the above symptoms and you might be pregnant – even if you haven't had a positive pregnancy test.

An ectopic pregnancy can be serious, so it's important to get advice right away.

Your GP will ask about your symptoms and you'll usually need to do a pregnancy test to determine if you could have an ectopic pregnancy.

You may be referred to a specialist early pregnancy clinic for further assessment, where an ultrasound scan and blood tests may be carried out to confirm the diagnosis.

Read more about ectopic pregnancy tests.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to get emergency help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to get emergency help

Call 999 for an ambulance or go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department immediately if you experience a combination of:

  • a sharp, sudden and intense pain in your tummy
  • feeling very dizzy or fainting
  • feeling sick
  • looking very pale

These symptoms could mean that your fallopian tube has split open (ruptured). This is very serious and surgery to repair the fallopian tube needs to be carried out as soon as possible.

A rupture can be life threatening, but fortunately they're uncommon and treatable, if dealt with quickly. Deaths from ruptures are extremely rare in the UK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How an ectopic pregnancy is treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How an ectopic pregnancy is treated

There are 3 main treatments for an ectopic pregnancy:

  • expectant management – you're carefully monitored and 1 of the treatments below is used if the fertilised egg doesn't dissolve by itself
  • medication – an injection of a powerful medicine called methotrexate is used to stop the pregnancy growing
  • surgery – keyhole surgery (laparoscopy) is performed under general anaesthetic to remove the fertilised egg, usually along with the affected fallopian tube

You'll be told about the benefits and risks of each option. In many cases, a particular treatment will be recommended based on your symptoms and the results of the tests you have.

Some treatments may reduce your chances of being able to conceive naturally in the future, although most women will still be able to get pregnant. Talk to your doctor about this.

Read more about treating an ectopic pregnancy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Help and support after an ectopic pregnancy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Help and support after an ectopic pregnancy

Losing a pregnancy can be devastating, and many women feel the same sense of grief as if they had lost a family member or partner.

It's not uncommon for these feelings to last several months, although they usually improve with time. Make sure you give yourself and your partner time to grieve.

If you or your partner are struggling to come to terms with your loss, you may benefit from professional support or counselling. Speak to your GP about this.

Support groups for people who have been affected by loss of a pregnancy can also help.

These include:

  • The Ectopic Pregnancy Trust
  • The Ectopic Pregnancy Foundation
  • The Miscarriage Association
  • Cruse Bereavement Care

Read more about dealing with loss and find bereavement support services in your area.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Trying for another baby", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Trying for another baby

You may want to try for another baby when you and your partner feel physically and emotionally ready.

You'll probably be advised to wait until you've had at least 2 periods after treatment before trying again to allow yourself to recover.

If you were treated with methotrexate, it's usually recommended that you wait at least 3 months because the medicine could harm your baby if you become pregnant during this time.

Most women who have had an ectopic pregnancy will be able to get pregnant again, even if they've had a fallopian tube removed.

Overall, 65% of women achieve a successful pregnancy within 18 months of an ectopic pregnancy. Occasionally, it may be necessary to use fertility treatment such as IVF.

The chances of having another ectopic pregnancy are higher if you've had one before, but the risk is still small (around 10%).

If you do become pregnant again, it's a good idea to let your GP know as soon as possible so early scans can be carried out to check everything is OK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What can cause an ectopic pregnancy?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What can cause an ectopic pregnancy?

In many cases, it's not clear why a woman has an ectopic pregnancy. Sometimes it happens when there's a problem with the fallopian tubes, such as them being narrow or blocked.

The following are all associated with an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy:

  • pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) – inflammation of the female reproductive system, usually caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI)
  • previous ectopic pregnancy – the risk of having another ectopic pregnancy is around 10%
  • previous surgery on your fallopian tubes – such as an unsuccessful female sterilisation procedure
  • fertility treatment, such as IVF – taking medication to stimulate ovulation (the release of an egg) can increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy
  • becoming pregnant while using an intrauterine device (IUD) or intrauterine system (IUS) for contraception – it's rare to get pregnant while using these, but if you do you're more likely to have an ectopic pregnancy
  • smoking
  • increasing age – the risk is highest for pregnant women aged 35 to 40

You can't always prevent an ectopic pregnancy, but you can reduce your risk by using a condom when not trying for a baby to protect yourself against STIs, and by stopping smoking if you smoke.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Encephalitis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Encephalitis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Encephalitis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about encephalitis, a rare but serious condition that causes inflammation of the brain.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-12-03T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-12-03T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/", "name": "Encephalitis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-11T12:18:04+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/#overview", "description": "Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain, usually caused by an infection. It's a rare but serious condition.", "text": "

Encephalitis may start off with flu-like symptoms. More serious symptoms include confusion, seizures, difficulty speaking and feeling weak.

Encephalitis needs urgent treatment in hospital. Depending on the cause, treatment may include antiviral medicines, steroids or antibiotics.

Some of the infections that cause encephalitis can be prevented with vaccines, such as the MMR and Japanese encephalitis vaccines.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/#symptoms", "description": "Encephalitis may start off with flu-like symptoms. More serious symptoms include confusion, seizures, difficulty speaking and feeling weak.", "text": "

Encephalitis sometimes starts off with\u00a0flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature and headache.

More serious symptoms come on over hours, days or weeks, including:

  • confusion or disorientation
  • seizures or fits
  • changes in personality and behaviour
  • difficulty speaking
  • weakness or loss of movement in some parts of the body
  • loss of consciousness

Dial 999 for an ambulance immediately if you or someone else has these more serious symptoms.

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of encephalitis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/#treatments-summary", "description": "Encephalitis needs urgent treatment in hospital. Depending on the cause, treatment may include antiviral medicines, steroids or antibiotics.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/#treatments-other", "description": "Encephalitis needs urgent treatment in hospital. Depending on the cause, treatment may include antiviral medicines, steroids or antibiotics.", "text": "

Encephalitis needs to be treated\u00a0in\u00a0a hospital. The earlier treatment is started, the more successful it's likely to be.

Treatment depends on\u00a0the underlying\u00a0cause, but may include:

  • antiviral medicines
  • steroid injections
  • treatments\u00a0to help\u00a0control the immune system
  • antibiotics\u00a0or\u00a0antifungal medicines
  • painkillers to reduce discomfort or a high temperature
  • medicine to control seizures or fits
  • support with breathing, such as oxygen through a face mask or a breathing machine (ventilator)

How long someone with encephalitis needs to stay in hospital can range from a few days to several weeks or even months.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for encephalitis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/#prevention", "description": "Some of the infections that cause encephalitis can be prevented with vaccines, such as the MMR and Japanese encephalitis vaccines.", "text": "

It's not always possible to prevent encephalitis, but\u00a0some of the infections that cause it can be prevented with vaccinations.

These include the:

  • measles, mumps and rubella (MMR)\u00a0vaccine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a routine vaccination offered to all children in England
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine\u00a0\u2013 recommended for travellers to at-risk areas, such as parts of Asia
  • tick-borne encephalitis vaccine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0recommended for travellers to certain parts of\u00a0Europe (but not the UK) and Asia
  • rabies vaccination\u00a0\u2013\u00a0recommended for travellers to at-risk areas\u00a0where access to medical care is likely to be limited

Speak to a GP surgery if you're not sure whether your vaccinations are up to date, or you're planning to travel abroad and do not know if you need any vaccinations.

", "title": "Preventing\u00a0encephalitis"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Encephalitis", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/encephalitis/complications/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Encephalitis", "Vaccinations", "Immune system", "Brain"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Encephalitis is an uncommon\u00a0but serious condition in which the brain becomes inflamed (swollen).

It can be life threatening and requires urgent treatment in hospital.

Anyone\u00a0can be affected, but the very young and very old are most at risk.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of encephalitis", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of encephalitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Encephalitis sometimes starts off with\u00a0flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature and headache.

More serious symptoms come on over hours, days or weeks, including:

  • confusion or disorientation
  • seizures or fits
  • changes in personality and behaviour
  • difficulty speaking
  • weakness or loss of movement in some parts of the body
  • loss of consciousness

Dial 999 for an ambulance immediately if you or someone else has these more serious symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of encephalitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of encephalitis

It's not always clear what causes encephalitis, but it can be caused by:

  • viral infections\u00a0\u2013 several common viruses can spread to the brain and cause encephalitis in rare cases, including the herpes simplex virus (which causes cold sores\u00a0and genital herpes) and the chickenpox virus
  • a problem with the immune system, the body's defence against infection \u2013\u00a0sometimes something goes wrong with\u00a0the immune system and it mistakenly attacks the brain, causing it to become inflamed
  • bacterial or fungal infections\u00a0\u2013 these are much rarer causes of encephalitis than viral infections

Some types of encephalitis are spread by mosquitoes (such as Japanese encephalitis), ticks (such as tick-borne encephalitis) and mammals (such as rabies).

You cannot catch encephalitis from someone else.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for encephalitis", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for encephalitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Encephalitis needs to be treated\u00a0in\u00a0a hospital. The earlier treatment is started, the more successful it's likely to be.

Treatment depends on\u00a0the underlying\u00a0cause, but may include:

  • antiviral medicines
  • steroid injections
  • treatments\u00a0to help\u00a0control the immune system
  • antibiotics\u00a0or\u00a0antifungal medicines
  • painkillers to reduce discomfort or a high temperature
  • medicine to control seizures or fits
  • support with breathing, such as oxygen through a face mask or a breathing machine (ventilator)

How long someone with encephalitis needs to stay in hospital can range from a few days to several weeks or even months.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering\u00a0from encephalitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering\u00a0from encephalitis

Some people eventually\u00a0make a full recovery from encephalitis, although this can be a long and frustrating process.

Many people never make a full recovery and are left with long-term problems caused by damage to their brain.

Common complications include:

  • memory loss
  • frequent\u00a0seizures or fits
  • personality and behavioural changes
  • problems with attention, concentration, planning and problem solving
  • persistent tiredness

These problems can have a significant impact on the life of the affected person, as well as their family and friends.

But help and support is available.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing\u00a0encephalitis", "text": "Preventing\u00a0encephalitis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's not always possible to prevent encephalitis, but\u00a0some of the infections that cause it can be prevented with vaccinations.

These include the:

  • measles, mumps and rubella (MMR)\u00a0vaccine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a routine vaccination offered to all children in England
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine\u00a0\u2013 recommended for travellers to at-risk areas, such as parts of Asia
  • tick-borne encephalitis vaccine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0recommended for travellers to certain parts of\u00a0Europe (but not the UK) and Asia
  • rabies vaccination\u00a0\u2013\u00a0recommended for travellers to at-risk areas\u00a0where access to medical care is likely to be limited

Speak to a GP surgery if you're not sure whether your vaccinations are up to date, or you're planning to travel abroad and do not know if you need any vaccinations.

Endocarditis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Endocarditis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Endocarditis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Endocarditis is a rare and potentially fatal type of heart infection. It's specifically an infection of the inner lining of the heart (the endocardium).", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-02-27T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-02-27T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/", "name": "Endocarditis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-03-13T10:24:17+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Endocarditis", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endocarditis/prevention/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Prevention"}], "keywords": ["Endocarditis", "Heart and vascular diseases", "Congenital heart diseases", "Heart"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Endocarditis is a rare and potentially fatal infection of the inner lining of the heart (the endocardium). It's most commonly caused by bacteria entering the blood and travelling to the heart.

Although the heart is usually well protected against infection, it may be easier for bacteria to bypass the immune system in people who have:

  • an artificial (prosthetic) heart valve – valve replacement surgery is increasingly being used when people experience narrowing of one of their heart valves
  • congenital heart disease – where a person is born with heart defects
  • hypertrophic cardiomyopathy – where the heart muscle cells have enlarged and the walls of the heart chambers thicken
  • damaged heart valves – because of infection or heart disease

People who inject drugs are also more likely to develop endocarditis.

Find out more about the causes of endocarditis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of endocarditis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of endocarditis

The initial symptoms of endocarditis are similar to flu and include:

  • a high temperature
  • chills
  • headache
  • joint and muscle pain

Without treatment, the infection damages the heart valves and disrupts the normal flow of blood through the heart.

This triggers a range of life-threatening complications, such as:

  • heart failure – where the heart is unable to pump enough blood around the body to properly meet the body's demands
  • stroke – where the supply of blood to the brain becomes disrupted

Find out more about the symptoms of endocarditis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treating endocarditis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating endocarditis

Endocarditis is treated with a course of antibiotics given via a drip. You'll need to be admitted to hospital for this.

Some people also need surgery to repair or replace a damaged heart valve or drain away any abscesses that develop.

Endocarditis is a serious illness, especially if complications develop. Early diagnosis and treatment is vital to improve the outlook for the condition.

Find out more about the treatment of endocarditis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

Endocarditis is a rare condition in England, even in those with a higher risk.

It's more common in older people, with half of all cases developing in people aged over 50.

But cases of endocarditis have been recorded in children, particularly those born with congenital heart disease.

Twice as many men are affected as women.

Although it may sound strange, rates of endocarditis are increasing because of advances in medical care.

This is because there's an increasing number of people being treated with valve replacement surgery or surgery to repair congenital heart disease.

Endometriosis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Endometriosis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Endometriosis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Endometriosis is a common condition where small pieces of the womb lining (the endometrium) are found outside the womb.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-18T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-01-18T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/", "name": "Endometriosis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-11T12:18:56+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/#overview", "description": "Endometriosis is a long-term condition where tissue similar to the lining of the womb grows in other places, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes.", "text": "

Symptoms of endometriosis include pain in your lower tummy or back (pelvic pain), severe period pain and pain during or after sex.

Treatments for endometriosis include painkillers, hormone medicines and surgery to remove the endometriosis tissue.

It's not clear what causes endometriosis. It may be linked to things like your genes or a problem with your immune system.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of endometriosis include pain in your lower tummy or back (pelvic pain), severe period pain and pain during or after sex.", "text": "

The symptoms of endometriosis can vary. Some women are badly affected, while others\u00a0might not\u00a0have any noticeable symptoms.

The main symptoms of endometriosis are:

  • pain in your lower tummy or back (pelvic pain) \u2013 usually worse during your period
  • period pain that stops you doing your normal activities
  • pain during or after sex
  • pain when peeing or pooing during your period
  • feeling sick, constipation, diarrhoea, or blood in your pee during your period
  • difficulty getting pregnant

You may also have heavy periods. You might use lots of pads or tampons, or you may bleed through your clothes.

For some women, endometriosis can have a big impact on their life and may sometimes lead to feelings of depression.

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of endometriosis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatments for endometriosis include painkillers, hormone medicines and surgery to remove the endometriosis tissue.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatments for endometriosis include painkillers, hormone medicines and surgery to remove the endometriosis tissue.", "text": "

There's currently no cure for endometriosis, but there are\u00a0treatments that can help ease the symptoms.

Treatments include:

  • painkillers\u00a0\u2013 such as\u00a0ibuprofen and paracetamol
  • hormone medicines and contraceptives\u00a0\u2013\u00a0including the combined pill, the contraceptive patch, an\u00a0intrauterine system (IUS), and medicines called gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogues
  • surgery to\u00a0cut\u00a0away\u00a0patches of endometriosis tissue
  • an operation to remove part or all of the organs affected by endometriosis\u00a0\u2013 such as surgery to remove the womb (hysterectomy)

Your doctor will discuss the options with you. Sometimes they may suggest not starting treatment immediately\u00a0to see if\u00a0your symptoms improve on their own.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for endometriosis"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/endometriosis/#causes", "description": "It's not clear what causes endometriosis. It may be linked to things like your genes or a problem with your immune system.", "text": "

The\u00a0cause of endometriosis is not\u00a0known.

Several theories have been suggested, including:

  • genetics\u00a0\u2013 the condition tends to run in families, and affects people of certain ethnic groups more than others
  • retrograde menstruation\u00a0\u2013 when some of\u00a0the womb lining flows up through the fallopian tubes and embeds itself on the organs of the pelvis, rather than leaving the body as a period
  • a problem with the immune system, the body's natural defence against illness and infection
  • endometrium cells spreading through the body in the bloodstream or lymphatic system, a series of tubes and glands that form part of the immune system

But none of these theories fully explain why endometriosis happens.

It's likely the condition is caused by a combination\u00a0of different\u00a0factors.

Endometriosis is a condition where tissue similar to the lining of the womb starts to grow in other places, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

Endometriosis can affect women of any age.

It's a long-term condition that can have a significant impact on your life, but there are treatments that can help.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of endometriosis", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of endometriosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The symptoms of endometriosis can vary. Some women are badly affected, while others\u00a0might not\u00a0have any noticeable symptoms.

The main symptoms of endometriosis are:

  • pain in your lower tummy or back (pelvic pain) \u2013 usually worse during your period
  • period pain that stops you doing your normal activities
  • pain during or after sex
  • pain when peeing or pooing during your period
  • feeling sick, constipation, diarrhoea, or blood in your pee during your period
  • difficulty getting pregnant

You may also have heavy periods. You might use lots of pads or tampons, or you may bleed through your clothes.

For some women, endometriosis can have a big impact on their life and may sometimes lead to feelings of depression.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to see a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to see a GP

See a GP if you have symptoms of endometriosis, especially if they're having a big impact on your life.

It may help to write down your symptoms before seeing a doctor.

Endometriosis UK has a\u00a0pain and symptoms diary (PDF, 238kb) you can use.

It can be difficult to diagnose endometriosis because the symptoms can vary considerably, and many other conditions can cause similar symptoms.

A GP will ask about your symptoms, and may ask to examine your tummy and vagina.

They may recommend treatments if they think you have endometriosis.

If these do not help, they might refer you to a specialist called a gynaecologist for some further tests, such as an ultrasound scan or laparoscopy.

A laparoscopy is where a surgeon passes a thin tube through a small cut in your tummy so they can see any patches of endometriosis tissue.

This is the only way to be certain you have endometriosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for endometriosis", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for endometriosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's currently no cure for endometriosis, but there are\u00a0treatments that can help ease the symptoms.

Treatments include:

  • painkillers\u00a0\u2013 such as\u00a0ibuprofen and paracetamol
  • hormone medicines and contraceptives\u00a0\u2013\u00a0including the combined pill, the contraceptive patch, an\u00a0intrauterine system (IUS), and medicines called gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogues
  • surgery to\u00a0cut\u00a0away\u00a0patches of endometriosis tissue
  • an operation to remove part or all of the organs affected by endometriosis\u00a0\u2013 such as surgery to remove the womb (hysterectomy)

Your doctor will discuss the options with you. Sometimes they may suggest not starting treatment immediately\u00a0to see if\u00a0your symptoms improve on their own.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Further problems caused by endometriosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Further problems caused by endometriosis

One of the main\u00a0complications of endometriosis is difficulty getting pregnant or not being able to get pregnant at all\u00a0(infertility).

Surgery to remove endometriosis tissue can help\u00a0improve your chances of getting pregnant, although there's no guarantee that you'll be able to get pregnant after treatment.

Surgery for endometriosis can also sometimes cause further problems, such as infections, bleeding\u00a0or damage to affected organs.

If surgery is recommended for you, talk to your surgeon about the possible risks.

Find out more about the complications of endometriosis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Coping\u00a0with endometriosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living\u00a0with endometriosis

Endometriosis can be a difficult condition to deal with, both physically and emotionally.

As well as support from your doctor, you may find it helpful to contact a support group, such as\u00a0Endometriosis UK, for information and advice.

In addition to\u00a0detailed\u00a0information about endometriosis, Endometriosis UK has a directory of local support groups, a helpline\u00a0on 0808 808 2227, and an\u00a0online community for women affected by the condition.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes\u00a0of endometriosis", "text": "Causes\u00a0of endometriosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The\u00a0cause of endometriosis is not\u00a0known.

Several theories have been suggested, including:

  • genetics\u00a0\u2013 the condition tends to run in families, and affects people of certain ethnic groups more than others
  • retrograde menstruation\u00a0\u2013 when some of\u00a0the womb lining flows up through the fallopian tubes and embeds itself on the organs of the pelvis, rather than leaving the body as a period
  • a problem with the immune system, the body's natural defence against illness and infection
  • endometrium cells spreading through the body in the bloodstream or lymphatic system, a series of tubes and glands that form part of the immune system

But none of these theories fully explain why endometriosis happens.

It's likely the condition is caused by a combination\u00a0of different\u00a0factors.

"text": "

Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) is the name for a group of rare inherited skin disorders that cause the skin to become very fragile. Any trauma or friction to the skin can cause painful blisters.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of epidermolysis bullosa", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of epidermolysis bullosa

The main symptoms of all types of EB include:

  • skin that blisters easily
  • blisters inside the mouth
  • blisters on the hands and soles of the feet
  • scarred skin, sometimes with small white spots called milia
  • thickened skin and nails
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "Picture of epidermolysis bullosa", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/C0088387.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "Science Photo Library", "license": "SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY\r\n\r\nhttps://www.sciencephoto.com/media/151100/view", "datePublished": "2017-09-15T09:06:02+00:00", "keywords": []}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of epidermolysis bullosa", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of epidermolysis bullosa

The 3 main types of EB are:

  • epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) \u2013 the most common type, which tends to be milder with a low risk of serious complications
  • dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB) \u2013 which can range from mild to severe
  • junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) \u2013 the rarest and most severe type

The type reflects where on the body the blistering takes place and which layer of skin is affected.

There are also many variants of these 3 main types of EB, each with slightly different symptoms.

Read more about symptoms of different types of epidermolysis bullosa.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Diagnosing EB", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing EB

EB is usually diagnosed in babies and children by your neonatal team, as the symptoms are often obvious from birth. But some milder types of EB may not be diagnosed until adulthood.

If it's suspected your child has the condition, they'll be referred to a skin specialist (dermatologist).

The specialist will carry out tests to determine the type of EB and help come up with a treatment plan. They may take a small sample of skin (biopsy) to send for testing.

Prenatal testing

In some cases it's possible to test an unborn baby for EB at about 11 weeks into pregnancy.

This may be offered if you or your partner are known to be a carrier of the faulty gene associated with EB and there's a risk of having a child with a severe type of EB.

If the test confirms your child will have EB, you'll be offered counselling and advice to help you make an informed decision about how you wish to proceed with the pregnancy.

Prenatal tests include amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of epidermolysis bullosa", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of epidermolysis bullosa

EB is caused by a faulty gene (gene mutation) that makes skin more fragile.

Usually, a child with EB will have inherited the faulty gene from a parent who also has EB.

It's also possible for a child with EB to have inherited the faulty gene from both parents who are just "carriers" but don't have EB themselves.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment for epidermolysis bullosa", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for epidermolysis bullosa

There's currently no cure for EB, so treatment aims to relieve symptoms and prevent complications developing, such as infection.

A team of medical specialists will help you decide what treatment is best for your child and offer advice about living with the condition.

You can manage EB at home by:

  • popping blisters with a sterile needle
  • applying protective dressings
  • avoiding things that make the condition worse

Medicines can be used to treat infection or to reduce pain. Surgery may be needed if EB causes narrowing of the food pipe or problems with the hands.

Read more about treating epidermolysis bullosa.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) is an acquired form of EB with similar symptoms.

Like EB, EBA causes the skin to blister easily. It can also affect the mouth, throat and digestive tract.

But EBA isn't inherited, and symptoms don't usually appear until later life.

It's an autoimmune disease, which means your immune system starts to attack healthy body tissue. It's not known exactly what causes this.

EBA is a very rare condition that tends to affect people over the age of 40.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Charities and support groups", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Charities and support groups

If your child is diagnosed with EB, it can be a frightening and overwhelming experience. You'll probably want to find out as much as possible about the condition and available treatments.

DEBRA is a national charity that provides help, advice and support for people in the UK living with EB.

DEBRA International is a worldwide network of national groups working on behalf of people affected by EB.

Support for carers

It's important not to neglect your own health and wellbeing when caring for a child with a complex and demanding condition such as EB.

Read about carers' breaks and respite care and get tips on caring for a disabled child.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Information about you", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Information about you

If you or your child has EB, your clinical team will pass information about you or your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Diseases Registration Service (NCARDRS).

This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

Find out more about the register

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Epidural:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Epidural", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Epidural", "alternateName": []}, "description": "An epidural is an injection in your back to stop you feeling pain in part of your body, commonly given for pain relief in childbirth and in some types of surgery.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epidural/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-03-11T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-03-11T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epidural/", "name": "Epidural", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-20T13:01:35+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epidural/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Epidural", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epidural/side-effects/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Side effects"}], "keywords": ["Anaesthesia", "Epidural", "anaesthetic"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

An epidural is an injection in your back to stop you feeling pain in part of your body.

This page covers\u00a0epidural anaesthesia, a type of epidural commonly given for pain relief in childbirth and\u00a0in\u00a0some types of surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When epidurals are used", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epidurals can be used:

  • during labour and childbirth, including caesareans
  • during some types of surgery
  • after some types of surgery

Steroid medicine can also be given with an epidural injection, to treat pain in your back or leg that's caused by sciatica or a slipped (prolapsed) disc.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preparing for an epidural", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have any concerns or questions about having an epidural, discuss these with your doctor. Let them know about any medicines you're taking.

You may be given specific advice about eating, drinking and medicines before the epidural.

As you will not be able to drive for 24 hours after having an epidural, so you'll need to arrange for someone to take you home.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How an epidural is given", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epidurals are given by a specialist doctor called an anaesthetist.

You're usually awake during an epidural, but for some types of surgery you may have it while\u00a0under general anaesthetic.

  • A drip will be placed in your arm so you can be given fluids while you're having the epidural.
  • You'll be asked to sit down and lean forwards, or lie on your side with your knees up close your chest.
  • You'll be given an injection of local anaesthetic\u00a0to numb the skin where the epidural will be inserted.
  • A\u00a0needle is used to insert a fine plastic tube called an epidural catheter into your back (spine) near the nerves that carry pain messages to your brain.
  • The needle is then removed, leaving just the catheter in your spine.
  • You may feel mild discomfort when the epidural needle is positioned and the catheter is inserted.

The epidural can be inserted at different levels of your spine, depending on the area of your body that needs pain relief.

Pain relief medicines are then given through the catheter. These take about 20 to 30 minutes to take full effect.

Your chest, tummy and legs may feel numb while the epidural medicines are being used, and your legs may not feel as strong as usual.

While the catheter remains in your back, it can be used to top up your pain relief medicines manually or using an automatic pump.

This can be for several hours (during childbirth) or for a few days (after major surgery).

Mobile epidurals, which use a lower dose of pain relief medicines, are sometimes used in childbirth, allowing you to walk around during labour.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Recovering from an epidural", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When the epidural is stopped, the numbness usually lasts for a few hours before its effects begin to wear off.

While the medicine wear off, you'll probably be advised to rest in a lying or sitting position until the feeling in your legs returns.

This can take a couple of hours, and you may feel a slight tingling sensation in your skin.

Tell the doctor or nurse if you feel any pain. They can give you medicines to help control it.

Do not drive, operate machinery or drink alcohol for 24 hours after having an epidural.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Risks and side effects of an epidural", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epidurals are usually safe, but there's a small risk of side effects and complications, including:

  • low blood pressure, which can make you feel lightheaded or nauseous
  • temporary loss of bladder control
  • itchy skin
  • feeling sick
  • headaches
  • nerve damage

Read more about the side effects and complications of an epidural.

Epilepsy:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Epilepsy", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Epilepsy", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about epilepsy, where sudden bursts of electrical activity in the brain cause seizures or fits.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-09-18T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-09-18T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/", "name": "Epilepsy", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-02T17:09:18+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/#overview", "description": "Epilepsy is a common condition where sudden bursts of electrical activity in the brain cause seizures or fits.", "text": "

There are lots of possible symptoms of epilepsy seizures, including uncontrollable shaking or losing awareness of things around you.

The main treatment for epilepsy is medicine to stop seizures.

It's often not clear what causes epilepsy. Sometimes it runs in families or is caused by damage to the brain from things like a severe head injury.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/#symptoms", "description": "There are lots of possible symptoms of epilepsy seizures, including uncontrollable shaking or losing awareness of things around you.", "text": "

Seizures can affect people in different ways, depending on which part of the brain is involved.

Possible symptoms include:

  • uncontrollable jerking and shaking, called a \"fit\"
  • losing awareness and\u00a0staring blankly into space
  • becoming stiff
  • strange sensations, such as\u00a0a \"rising\" feeling in the tummy, unusual smells or tastes, and a tingling feeling in your arms or legs
  • collapsing

Sometimes you might pass out and not remember what happened.

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of epilepsy"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/#treatments-summary", "description": "The main treatment for epilepsy is medicine to stop seizures.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/#treatments-other", "description": "The main treatment for epilepsy is medicine to stop seizures.", "text": "

Treatment can help most people with epilepsy have fewer seizures or stop having seizures completely.

Treatments include:

  • medicines called anti-epileptic drugs\u00a0\u2013 these are the main treatment
  • surgery to remove a small part of the brain that's causing the seizures
  • a procedure to put a small electrical device inside the body that can help control seizures
  • a special diet (ketogenic diet) that can help control seizures

Some people need treatment for life. But you might be able to stop treatment if your seizures disappear over time.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for epilepsy"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/#causes", "description": "It's often not clear what causes epilepsy. Sometimes it runs in families or is caused by damage to the brain from things like a severe head injury.", "text": "

In epilepsy, the electrical signals in the brain become scrambled and there\u00a0are\u00a0sometimes sudden bursts of electrical activity. This is what causes seizures.

In most cases, it's not clear why this happens. It's possible it could be partly caused by your genes affecting how your brain works,\u00a0as around\u00a01 in\u00a03 people with epilepsy have a family member with it.

Occasionally,\u00a0epilepsy can be\u00a0caused by damage to the brain, such as damage from:

  • a\u00a0stroke
  • a\u00a0brain tumour
  • a\u00a0severe head injury
  • drug abuse\u00a0or\u00a0alcohol misuse
  • a brain infection
  • a lack of oxygen during birth
", "title": "Causes\u00a0of epilepsy"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Epilepsy", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/epilepsy/living-with/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Living with"}], "keywords": ["Epilepsy", "Convulsions"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epilepsy is a common condition that affects the brain and causes frequent seizures.

Seizures are bursts of electrical activity in the brain that temporarily affect how it works. They can cause\u00a0a wide range of symptoms.

Epilepsy can start at any age, but usually starts either in childhood or in people over 60.

It's often lifelong, but can sometimes get slowly better over time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

  • Epilepsy Action: coronavirus and epilepsy
  • Epilepsy Society: epilepsy and coronavirus FAQs
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of epilepsy", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of epilepsy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Seizures can affect people in different ways, depending on which part of the brain is involved.

Possible symptoms include:

  • uncontrollable jerking and shaking, called a "fit"
  • losing awareness and\u00a0staring blankly into space
  • becoming stiff
  • strange sensations, such as\u00a0a "rising" feeling in the tummy, unusual smells or tastes, and a tingling feeling in your arms or legs
  • collapsing

Sometimes you might pass out and not remember what happened.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP if you think you might have had a seizure for the first time.

This does not mean\u00a0you have epilepsy, as a seizure can have several causes and sometimes they're just a one-off, but\u00a0you should see a doctor to find out why it happened.

Find out more about the tests for epilepsy you might have\u00a0

Call 999 for an ambulance\u00a0if someone:

  • is having a seizure for the first time
  • has a seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes
  • has lots of seizures in a row
  • has breathing problems or\u00a0has\u00a0seriously injured themselves

Find out what to do if someone has a seizure

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for epilepsy", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for epilepsy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment can help most people with epilepsy have fewer seizures or stop having seizures completely.

Treatments include:

  • medicines called anti-epileptic drugs\u00a0\u2013 these are the main treatment
  • surgery to remove a small part of the brain that's causing the seizures
  • a procedure to put a small electrical device inside the body that can help control seizures
  • a special diet (ketogenic diet) that can help control seizures

Some people need treatment for life. But you might be able to stop treatment if your seizures disappear over time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Living\u00a0with epilepsy", "text": "Living\u00a0with epilepsy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epilepsy is usually a lifelong condition, but most people with it are able to have normal lives if their seizures are well controlled.

Most\u00a0children with epilepsy\u00a0are able to go to a mainstream school, take part in most activities and sports, and get a job when they're older.

But\u00a0you may have to think about your epilepsy before you do things such as driving, certain jobs, swimming, using contraception and planning a pregnancy.

Advice is available from a GP or support groups to help you adjust to life with epilepsy.

Find out more about living with epilepsy

In epilepsy, the electrical signals in the brain become scrambled and there\u00a0are\u00a0sometimes sudden bursts of electrical activity. This is what causes seizures.

In most cases, it's not clear why this happens. It's possible it could be partly caused by your genes affecting how your brain works,\u00a0as around\u00a01 in\u00a03 people with epilepsy have a family member with it.

Occasionally,\u00a0epilepsy can be\u00a0caused by damage to the brain, such as damage from:

  • a\u00a0stroke
  • a\u00a0brain tumour
  • a\u00a0severe head injury
  • drug abuse\u00a0or\u00a0alcohol misuse
  • a brain infection
  • a lack of oxygen during birth

Erectile dysfunction (impotence):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Erectile dysfunction (impotence)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Erectile dysfunction (impotence)", "alternateName": ["Impotence"]}, "description": "Read about erectile dysfunction, which is the inability to get and maintain an erection that is sufficient for satisfactory sexual intercourse.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-08-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-08-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/", "name": "Erectile dysfunction (impotence)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-23T13:18:23+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#overview", "description": "Erectile dysfunction is a common problem where a man finds it hard to get or keep an erection.", "text": "

The main symptom of erectile dysfunction is not being able to get or keep an erection.

Erectile dysfunction is often linked to things like stress, tiredness or alcohol. It can also be caused by physical or emotional problems.

Treatment for erectile dysfunction depends on the cause. Treatments include medicines, vacuum pumps, healthy lifestyle changes and talking therapy.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of erectile dysfunction is not being able to get or keep an erection.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#causes", "description": "Erectile dysfunction is often linked to things like stress, tiredness or alcohol. It can also be caused by physical or emotional problems.", "text": "

Most men occasionally fail to get or keep an erection.

This is usually caused by stress, tiredness, anxiety or drinking too much alcohol, and it's nothing to worry about.

If it happens more often, it may be caused by physical health or emotional problems.

", "title": "Causes of erection problems"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatment for erectile dysfunction depends on the cause. Treatments include medicines, vacuum pumps, healthy lifestyle changes and talking therapy.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatment for erectile dysfunction depends on the cause. Treatments include medicines, vacuum pumps, healthy lifestyle changes and talking therapy.", "text": "

Treatments for erectile dysfunction are usually effective and the problem often goes away.

There are also specific treatments for some of the causes of erectile dysfunction.

Possible cause: Narrowing of penis blood vessels, high blood pressure, high cholesterol
Treatment: Medicine to lower blood pressure, statins to lower cholesterol

Possible cause: Hormone problems
Treatment: Hormone replacement (for example, testosterone)

Possible cause: Side effects of prescribed medicine
Treatment: Change to medicine after discussion with GP

Medicine such as sildenafil (sold as Viagra) is also often used by doctors to treat erectile dysfunction. It's also available from pharmacies.

Because of changes in regulations, you no longer need a prescription to get sildenafil.

But you'll have to have a consultation with the pharmacist to make sure it's safe for you to take it.

There are other similar medicines called tadalafil (Cialis), vardenafil (Levitra) and avanafil (Spedra) that work in a similar way.

You'll still need a prescription to get these medicines.

", "title": "Treatment for erection problems depends on the cause"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/#self-care", "description": "Treatment for erectile dysfunction depends on the cause. Treatments include medicines, vacuum pumps, healthy lifestyle changes and talking therapy.", "text": "

Healthy lifestyle changes can sometimes help erectile dysfunction.


Do

  • lose weight if you're overweight

  • stop smoking

  • eat a healthy diet

  • exercise daily

  • try to reduce stress and anxiety


Don't

  • do not cycle for a while (if you cycle for more than 3 hours a week)

  • do not drink more than 14 units of alcohol a week

", "title": "Things you can do to help with erectile dysfunction"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/erection-problems-erectile-dysfunction/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Erectile dysfunction (impotence)"}], "keywords": ["Erectile dysfunction"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Erection problems (impotence) are very common, particularly in men over 40. It's usually nothing to worry about, but you should see a GP if it keeps happening. It could be the sign of a more serious problem.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of erection problems", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most men occasionally fail to get or keep an erection.

This is usually caused by stress, tiredness, anxiety or drinking too much alcohol, and it's nothing to worry about.

See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if:

  • erection problems keep happening

It could be a sign of an underlying health condition such as diabetes.

"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

How sexual health clinics can help with erection problems

Sexual health clinics treat problems with sexual health. They can provide the same treatment you would get at your GP surgery.

Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service, where you do not need an appointment.

They'll often get test results quicker than GP practices.

Find a sexual health clinic near you

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

The doctor or nurse will ask about your lifestyle and relationships, and any problems you might be having.

They'll carry out basic health checks, such as taking your blood pressure.

They'll also examine your genitals to rule out any obvious physical cause.

If you have symptoms like needing to pee more often, you may also need to have an examination of your prostate.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Buying Viagra online", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You can buy sildenafil (Viagra) over the internet. Be very careful if you do this as many websites sell fake medicines.

Online medicines are not always regulated and the ingredients in them can vary from one pack to another. They can cause unpleasant side effects, or may not be suitable for you.

It's best to see a doctor before buying medicines online. They know your medical history and can discuss whether you might benefit from treatment.

If you choose to buy sildenafil (Viagra) on the internet, make sure:

  • any online pharmacy is registered with the General Pharmaceutical Council (GPhC)
  • any online doctor service is registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC)
  • all doctors are registered with the General Medical Council (GMC)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

Never buy off-prescription Viagra tablets online.

Make sure they're prescribed by a doctor or come from a UK pharmacy.
