The main symptom of Gilbert's syndrome is short episodes of jaundice, where the skin and whites of the eyes turn yellow.

Gilbert's syndrome is caused by a faulty gene that runs in families. It's not related to lifestyle or serious liver problems like cirrhosis.

There's no treatment for Gilbert's syndrome. But avoiding things that trigger your symptoms can help.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gilberts-syndrome/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of Gilbert's syndrome is short episodes of jaundice, where the skin and whites of the eyes turn yellow.", "text": "

Most\u00a0people with Gilbert's syndrome experience occasional and short-lived episodes of yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes\u00a0(jaundice) caused by the build-up of bilirubin in the blood.

As Gilbert's syndrome usually only causes a slight increase in bilirubin levels, the yellowing of\u00a0jaundice is often\u00a0mild. The eyes are usually affected most.

Some people also report other problems during episodes of jaundice, including:

  • tummy (abdominal) pain
  • feeling very tired (fatigue)
  • loss of appetite
  • feeling sick
  • dizziness
  • irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a common digestive disorder that causes stomach cramps, bloating, diarrhoea and constipation
  • problems concentrating and thinking clearly (brain fog)
  • a general sense of feeling unwell

But these problems are not necessarily thought to be directly related to increased bilirubin levels, and could indicate a condition other than Gilbert's syndrome.

Around 1 in 3 people with Gilbert's syndrome do not experience any symptoms at all.

You may not realise you have the syndrome until tests for an unrelated problem are carried out.

", "title": "Symptoms of Gilbert's syndrome"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gilberts-syndrome/#causes", "description": "Gilbert's syndrome is caused by a faulty gene that runs in families. It's not related to lifestyle or serious liver problems like cirrhosis.", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome is a genetic disorder that runs in families.

People with the syndrome have a faulty gene, which causes the liver to have problems removing bilirubin from the blood.

Normally, when red blood cells reach the end of their life (after about 120 days), haemoglobin, the red pigment that carries oxygen in the blood,\u00a0breaks down into bilirubin.

The liver converts bilirubin into a water-soluble form, which passes into bile (a fluid produced by the liver to help with digestion) and is eventually removed from the body in pee or poo.

In Gilbert's syndrome, the faulty gene means bilirubin is not passed into bile at the normal rate. Instead, it builds up in the bloodstream, giving the skin and white of the eyes a yellowish tinge.

Other than inheriting the faulty gene, there are no known risk factors for developing Gilbert's syndrome. It's not related to lifestyle habits, environmental factors or serious underlying liver problems, such as cirrhosis\u00a0or hepatitis C.

", "title": "What causes Gilbert's syndrome?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gilberts-syndrome/#treatments-summary", "description": "There's no treatment for Gilbert's syndrome. But avoiding things that trigger your symptoms can help.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gilberts-syndrome/#self-care", "description": "There's no treatment for Gilbert's syndrome. But avoiding things that trigger your symptoms can help.", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome is a lifelong disorder. But it does not require treatment because it does not pose a threat to health and does not cause complications or an increased risk of liver disease.

Episodes of jaundice and any associated symptoms are usually short-lived and eventually pass.

Changing your\u00a0diet or the amount of\u00a0exercise you do will not affect whether you have the condition.

But it's still important to make sure you eat a healthy, balanced diet and get plenty of exercise.

You may find it useful to avoid the things you know trigger episodes of jaundice, such as dehydration and stress.

If you have\u00a0Gilbert's syndrome, the problem with your liver may also mean you're at risk of developing jaundice or other\u00a0side effects after taking certain medications, such as medicines for high cholesterol.

You should talk to a GP before taking any new medicine and make sure you mention that you have Gilbert's syndrome to any doctors treating you for the first time.

", "title": "Living with Gilbert's syndrome"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gilberts-syndrome/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gilbert's syndrome"}], "keywords": ["Gilbert's syndrome"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

In Gilbert's syndrome, slightly higher than normal\u00a0levels of a substance called bilirubin build up in the blood.

Bilirubin is a yellow substance found naturally in the blood. It forms as a by-product\u00a0when old red blood cells are broken down.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and liver disease from the British Liver Trust

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of Gilbert's syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most\u00a0people with Gilbert's syndrome experience occasional and short-lived episodes of yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes\u00a0(jaundice) caused by the build-up of bilirubin in the blood.

As Gilbert's syndrome usually only causes a slight increase in bilirubin levels, the yellowing of\u00a0jaundice is often\u00a0mild. The eyes are usually affected most.

Some people also report other problems during episodes of jaundice, including:

  • tummy (abdominal) pain
  • feeling very tired (fatigue)
  • loss of appetite
  • feeling sick
  • dizziness
  • irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a common digestive disorder that causes stomach cramps, bloating, diarrhoea and constipation
  • problems concentrating and thinking clearly (brain fog)
  • a general sense of feeling unwell

But these problems are not necessarily thought to be directly related to increased bilirubin levels, and could indicate a condition other than Gilbert's syndrome.

Around 1 in 3 people with Gilbert's syndrome do not experience any symptoms at all.

You may not realise you have the syndrome until tests for an unrelated problem are carried out.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When to see a GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See your GP\u00a0if you experience an episode of jaundice for the first time.

The jaundice of Gilbert's syndrome is usually mild, but jaundice can be associated with more serious liver problems, such as cirrhosis or hepatitis C.

It's important to seek immediate medical advice from\u00a0a GP if you have jaundice.

If you cannot get in touch with aGP, call NHS 111 or\u00a0your\u00a0local out-of-hours service for advice.

If you have been diagnosed with Gilbert's syndrome, you do not usually need to seek medical advice during an episode of jaundice, unless you have additional or unusual symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes Gilbert's syndrome?", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome is a genetic disorder that runs in families.

People with the syndrome have a faulty gene, which causes the liver to have problems removing bilirubin from the blood.

Normally, when red blood cells reach the end of their life (after about 120 days), haemoglobin, the red pigment that carries oxygen in the blood,\u00a0breaks down into bilirubin.

The liver converts bilirubin into a water-soluble form, which passes into bile (a fluid produced by the liver to help with digestion) and is eventually removed from the body in pee or poo.

In Gilbert's syndrome, the faulty gene means bilirubin is not passed into bile at the normal rate. Instead, it builds up in the bloodstream, giving the skin and white of the eyes a yellowish tinge.

Other than inheriting the faulty gene, there are no known risk factors for developing Gilbert's syndrome. It's not related to lifestyle habits, environmental factors or serious underlying liver problems, such as cirrhosis\u00a0or hepatitis C.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What triggers the symptoms?", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

People with Gilbert's syndrome often find there are certain triggers that can bring on an\u00a0episode of jaundice.

Some of the possible triggers linked with the condition include:

  • being dehydrated
  • going without food for long periods of time (fasting)
  • being ill with an infection
  • being stressed
  • physical exertion
  • not getting enough sleep
  • having surgery
  • in women, having their monthly period

Where possible, avoiding known triggers can reduce your chance of experiencing episodes of jaundice.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Who's affected", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome is common, but\u00a0it's difficult to know exactly\u00a0how many people are affected because it does not always cause obvious symptoms.

In the UK, it's thought\u00a0at least 1\u00a0in 20 people (probably\u00a0more) are affected by Gilbert's syndrome.

Gilbert's syndrome affects more men than women. It's usually diagnosed in a person's late teens or early 20s.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Diagnosing Gilbert's syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome can be diagnosed using a blood test\u00a0to measure the levels of bilirubin in your blood and a liver function test.

When the liver is damaged, it releases enzymes into the blood. At the same time, levels of proteins that the liver produces to keep the body healthy begin to drop.

By measuring the levels of these enzymes and proteins, it's possible to build up a reasonably accurate picture of how well the liver is functioning.

If the test results show you have high levels of bilirubin in your blood, but your liver is otherwise working normally, a confident diagnosis of Gilbert's syndrome can usually be made.

In certain cases, a genetic test\u00a0may be necessary to confirm a diagnosis of Gilbert's syndrome.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 10, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Living with Gilbert's syndrome", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gilbert's syndrome is a lifelong disorder. But it does not require treatment because it does not pose a threat to health and does not cause complications or an increased risk of liver disease.

Episodes of jaundice and any associated symptoms are usually short-lived and eventually pass.

Changing your\u00a0diet or the amount of\u00a0exercise you do will not affect whether you have the condition.

But it's still important to make sure you eat a healthy, balanced diet and get plenty of exercise.

You may find it useful to avoid the things you know trigger episodes of jaundice, such as dehydration and stress.

If you have\u00a0Gilbert's syndrome, the problem with your liver may also mean you're at risk of developing jaundice or other\u00a0side effects after taking certain medications, such as medicines for high cholesterol.

You should talk to a GP before taking any new medicine and make sure you mention that you have Gilbert's syndrome to any doctors treating you for the first time.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Glutaric aciduria type 1:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Glutaric aciduria type 1", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Glutaric aciduria type 1", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Glutaric aciduria type 1 (GA1) is a rare but serious inherited condition. It means the body can’t process certain amino acids, causing a harmful build-up of substances in the blood and urine.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glutaric-aciduria/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-07-23T15:38:00+00:00", "2021-07-23T15:38:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glutaric-aciduria/", "name": "Glutaric aciduria type 1", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-10-03T19:57:05+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glutaric-aciduria/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Glutaric aciduria type 1"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glutaric aciduria type 1 (GA1) is a rare but serious inherited condition. It means the body can't process certain amino acids ("building blocks" of protein), causing a harmful build-up of substances in the blood and urine.

Normally, our bodies break down protein foods like meat and fish into amino acids. Any amino acids that aren't needed are usually broken down and removed from the body.

Babies with GA1 are unable to break down the amino acids lysine, hydroxylysine and tryptophan.

Normally, these amino acids are broken down into a substance called glutaric acid, which is then converted into energy. Babies with GA1 don't have the enzyme that breaks down glutaric acid, leading to a harmfully high level of this and other substances in the body.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Diagnosing GA1", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing GA1

At around 5 days old, babies are now offered newborn blood spot screening to check if they have GA1. This involves pricking your baby's heel to collect drops of blood to test.

If GA1 is diagnosed, treatment can be given straight away to reduce the risk of serious complications.

With early diagnosis and the correct treatment, the majority of children with GA1 are able to live normal, healthy lives. However, treatment for GA1 must be continued for life.

Without treatment, severe and life-threatening symptoms can develop, including seizures (fits) or falling into a coma. Some children with untreated GA1 are also at risk of brain damage, which can affect muscle movement. This may lead to problems with walking, talking and swallowing.

Around 1 in 100,000 children worldwide are thought to be affected by GA1.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms of GA1", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of GA1

Symptoms of GA1 usually don't appear until a few months after birth, although some babies are born with a larger-than-average head (macrocephaly).

Children with GA1 may develop some floppiness or weakness in their muscles (hypotonia) during their first year and there's a risk of developing bleeding around their brain (subdural haematoma). In rarer cases, bleeding can develop around the back of the eyes (retinal haemorrhage).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Metabolic crisis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Metabolic crisis

Children with GA1 may have episodes known as a metabolic crisis, sometimes early in their life. Symptoms of a metabolic crisis include:

  • poor feeding or loss of appetite
  • lack of energy
  • abnormal movements
  • vomiting
  • irritability
  • breathing difficulties

It's important to get medical help immediately if your baby develops symptoms of a metabolic crisis. Your doctor will give you advice to help recognise the signs.

In some cases, a metabolic crisis may be triggered later in childhood by an infection or illness. The hospital should provide you with emergency treatment instructions to follow if your child is ill, which helps to prevent these symptoms developing.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treating GA1", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating GA1

Diet

Children diagnosed with GA1 are referred to a specialist metabolic dietitian and given a low-protein diet. This is tailored to reduce the amount of amino acids your baby receives, especially lysine and tryptophan.

High-protein foods need to be limited, including:

  • meat
  • fish
  • cheese
  • eggs
  • pulses
  • nuts

Your dietitian will provide detailed advice and guidance, as your baby still needs some of these foods for healthy growth and development.

Breastfeeding and baby milk also need to be monitored and measured, as advised by your dietitian. Regular baby milk contains the amino acids that need to be restricted, so a special formula is used instead. This contains all the vitamins, minerals and other amino acids your baby needs.

People with GA1 may need to follow a restricted protein diet for the rest of their life to reduce their risk of a metabolic crisis. As your child gets older, they'll need to learn how to control their diet and stay in contact with a dietitian for advice and monitoring.

Medication

Your child will be prescribed a medication called L-carnitine, which helps to clear some of the excess glutaric acid.

L-carnitine is given as a tablet and needs to be taken regularly, as directed by your doctor.

Emergency treatment

If your baby develops an infection, such as a high temperature or cold, their risk of having a metabolic crisis increases. It's possible to reduce the risk by changing to an emergency diet while they're ill.

Your dietitian will provide detailed instructions, but the aim is to replace milk and food containing protein with special high-sugar drinks. Medication should still be taken as normal.

Your dietitian may provide you with a feeding tube (nasogastric tube) and show you how to use it safely. This can be useful in an emergency if your baby isn't feeding well while they are ill.

If your baby can't keep down their emergency feeds, or develops repeated diarrhoea, you should contact the metabolic team at the hospital to let them know you're heading straight to the accident and emergency (A&E) department.

You should also have been provided with a leaflet to bring with you in case of an emergency, in case the doctors haven't seen GA1 before.

Once in hospital, your baby can be monitored and treated with intravenous fluids (given directly into a vein).

You should also take your baby to hospital if they develop symptoms of a metabolic crisis, such as irritability, loss of energy or breathing difficulties.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How GA1 is inherited", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How GA1 is inherited

The genetic cause (mutation) of GA1 is passed on by the parents, who usually don’t have any symptoms of the condition.

The way this mutation is passed on is known as autosomal recessive inheritance. This means a baby needs to receive 2 copies of the mutated gene to develop the condition – 1 from their mother and 1 from their father. If the baby only receives 1 mutated gene, they’ll just be a carrier of GA1.

If you're a carrier of the affected gene and you have a baby with a partner who's also a carrier, your baby has:

  • a 25% chance of developing the condition
  • a 50% chance of being a carrier of GA1
  • a 25% chance of receiving a pair of normal genes

Although it's not possible to prevent GA1, it's important to let your midwife and doctor know if you have a family history of the condition. Any further children you have can be tested for the condition as soon as possible and given appropriate treatment.

You may also wish to consider genetic counselling for support, information and advice about genetic conditions.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Information about you", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Information about you

If you or your child has GA1, your clinical team will pass information about you/your child on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Diseases Registration Service (NCARDRS).

This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

Find out more about the register.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegene:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "alternateName": ["Wegener's granulomatosis"]}, "description": "Find out about granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), including what the symptoms are, why it happens and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-30T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-07-30T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-19T14:16:10+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/granulomatosis-with-polyangiitis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis)"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Deep vein thrombosis", "Urine tests", "Nose", "Lungs and airways"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a rare\u00a0condition where the blood vessels become inflamed. It mainly affects the ears, nose, sinuses, kidneys and lungs.

Anyone can get it, including children, but it's most common in adults and\u00a0older people.

GPA can be very serious but, with medicine, most people are able to manage the symptoms and keep the condition under control.

GPA\u00a0used to be called\u00a0Wegener's granulomatosis.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of GPA

GPA can cause a range of symptoms depending on which parts of the body are affected.

General symptoms include:

  • tiredness
  • a high temperature
  • muscle weakness
  • loss of appetite
  • unintentional weight loss\u00a0
  • joint pain

Ear, nose and throat problems:

  • a blocked or runny nose
  • nosebleeds
  • crusts around the nostrils
  • face pain (sinusitis)
  • earache
  • hearing loss

Lung problems:

  • a\u00a0cough that does not go away
  • shortness of breath
  • wheezing
  • chest pain

Kidney problems:

  • blood in pee
  • high blood pressure
  • inflammation of the kidneys (glomerulonephritis)

Skin problems:

  • rashes
  • lumps
  • small\u00a0purple spots

Eye problems

  • irritated eyes (conjunctivitis)
  • swollen eyelids
  • double vision

Gut problems:

  • tummy pain
  • diarrhoea
  • blood in poo

If it's not treated, GPA can cause permanent damage to some parts of the body. For example, it can change the shape of the nose or stop the kidneys working properly.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

See a GP\u00a0if you have symptoms of GPA, especially if they do not go away.

The GP can do some simple checks to try to find out what's causing your symptoms and can refer you to a hospital specialist for further tests, if needed.

If you've already been diagnosed with GPA, contact your doctor if any of your old symptoms come back or you get any new symptoms.\u00a0Your treatment may need to be changed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tests\u00a0for GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tests\u00a0for GPA

GPA can be difficult to diagnose. It causes a range of symptoms that are often similar to other common conditions.

A specialist doctor may:

  • ask about your\u00a0symptoms and examine the affected parts of your body
  • do a urine test to\u00a0check how well your kidneys are working
  • do a blood test to look for substances called\u00a0ANCAs (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies), which are\u00a0thought to be involved in\u00a0GPA
  • remove a small sample of tissue\u00a0(a biopsy) and check it for signs of inflammation
  • organise an X-ray, CT scan\u00a0or MRI scan to\u00a0look at the affected\u00a0parts of the body in more detail
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for GPA

GPA is thought to be caused by a problem with the immune system. It's treated with medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

There are 3 main stages of treatment.

Stage 1: Bringing the condition under control

The first aim of treatment is to bring the symptoms of GPA under control. This usually involves:

  • having injections of a medicine called cyclophosphamide every 2 or 3 weeks, or taking it as tablets every day (occasionally, other medicines \u2013\u00a0such as methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil or rituximab \u2013\u00a0may be used instead)
  • taking steroid\u00a0tablets\u00a0every day or having\u00a0steroid injections into your blood\u00a0at\u00a0the same time as\u00a0the\u00a0cyclophosphamide injections

These\u00a0are all strong medicines, so make sure you discuss the possible side effects with your doctor.

Some people also need a\u00a0plasma exchange, where a machine is used to filter\u00a0the blood to remove the harmful antibodies linked to GPA.

This first stage of treatment lasts until your symptoms are under control, which usually takes a few months.

Stage 2: Keeping the condition under control

Once the condition is under control, treatment aims to stop your symptoms coming back. This usually involves:

  • stopping treatment\u00a0with cyclophosphamide
  • taking\u00a0medicine that helps "calm" (or control) your body's immune system, such as an immunosuppressant like methotrexate or azathioprine
  • taking steroid tablets every day

This stage of treatment typically lasts for 2 to 5 years.

Stage 3: Treating\u00a0symptoms if they come back

If your symptoms come back or you\u00a0get new symptoms (a relapse) at any point, your treatment may be changed or restarted.

For example, your dose of steroids may be increased, and you may need to have more cyclophosphamide injections, start treatment with rituximab, or possibly have a course of plasma exchange.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Living\u00a0with GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living\u00a0with GPA

GPA is a serious condition but, with treatment, it can usually be kept under control.

You might need to take medicine for several years and you'll have regular check-ups in case your symptoms come back.

About\u00a0half of people with GPA have a relapse\u00a0within a few years\u00a0of their treatment stopping. Further treatment can help bring\u00a0the condition back under control if this happens.

If\u00a0GPA is\u00a0severe or\u00a0is not treated quickly, there\u00a0is a risk that life-threatening problems could develop, such as permanent damage to the kidneys that may require a kidney transplant.

This is why it's important to contact your doctor as soon as possible if your symptoms come back or you start getting new ones.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Support\u00a0and advice if you have GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support\u00a0and advice if you have GPA

For\u00a0more information and advice, you may find it useful to\u00a0check the Vasculitis UK website.

Vasculitis UK is an organisation for people with vasculitis (inflammation of the blood vessels). GPA is a type of vasculitis.

The Vasculitis UK website has information about living and coping with vasculitis, including advice about general health, benefits and insurance.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of GPA", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of GPA

The exact cause of GPA is unknown.

It may be due to problems with the immune system, which makes it attack and inflame the blood vessels. But it's not clear why this happens.

People with GPA may have a gene that makes them more likely to\u00a0get the condition.\u00a0It might then be triggered by something like a virus or bacterial infection, although this has not been proven.

Genes alone are not responsible for GPA because it's very unusual for\u00a02 people in the same family to have it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Information about you", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service

If you have GPA, your clinical team will pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

The NCARDRS helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat GPA. You can opt out of the register at any time.

GOV.UK has more information about the register

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Growing pains:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Growing pains", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Growing pains", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Growing pains are aches or pains, most commonly in the lower legs, that occur in the evening or at night and affect children aged between 3 and 12.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/growing-pains/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-04-09T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-04-09T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/growing-pains/", "name": "Growing pains", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-04-18T11:25:19+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/growing-pains/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Growing pains"}], "keywords": ["Aches,", "pains and soreness", "Restless legs syndrome", "Children", "Leg cramps"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Growing pains are common in children, mainly in the legs. They're harmless, but can be very painful. They usually stop by around age 12.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Check if it's growing pains

Growing pains can come and go over months, even years.

The pain is usually:

  • an aching or throbbing in both legs
  • in the muscles, not the joints
  • in the evening or night-time (and goes away by morning)

Growing pains are more common in active children and can come on after playing a lot of sports.

They're also more common in children with flexible joints (double jointed).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do to ease growing pains

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • gently massage your child's legs
  • put a covered hot water bottle (or heat pack) on the painful area
  • give children's ibuprofen or paracetamol to ease the pain
  • encourage them to wear supportive shoes, such as trainers, during the day
  • give them a warm bath before bedtime
"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not give aspirin to a child under the age of 16 unless a doctor prescribes it
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • the pain is only in 1 leg
  • the pain carries on the next morning
  • the pain is bad enough to stop your child walking or makes them limp
  • the pain is in a joint, such as their knees or ankles
  • there's a rash, swelling or unusual bruising on the legs
  • your child has a high temperature
  • your child does not want to eat or is losing weight
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes growing pains

It's not clear what causes growing pains. They can run in families.

They're not caused by growing and they're not a sign of anything serious.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Predictive genetic tests for cancer risk:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Predictive genetic tests for cancer risk genes", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Predictive genetic tests for cancer risk genes", "alternateName": ["Genetic test for cancer gene"]}, "description": "Cancer is not usually inherited, but some types \u2013 mainly breast, ovarian, colorectal and prostate cancer \u2013 can be strongly influenced by genes and can run in families.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/predictive-genetic-tests-cancer/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-04-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-04-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/predictive-genetic-tests-cancer/", "name": "Predictive genetic tests for cancer risk genes", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-07-13T16:30:16+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/predictive-genetic-tests-cancer/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Predictive genetic tests for cancer risk genes"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Cancer is not usually inherited, but some types\u00a0\u2013 mainly breast, ovarian, colorectal\u00a0and prostate cancer\u00a0\u2013 can be strongly influenced by genes and can run in families.

We all carry certain genes that are normally protective against cancer. These genes correct any DNA damage that naturally happens when cells divide.

Inheriting\u00a0faulty versions or "variants" of these genes significantly raises your risk of developing cancer, because the altered genes cannot repair the damaged cells, which can build up and form a tumour.

BRCA1 and BRCA2 are two examples of genes that raise your cancer risk if they become altered. Having a variant BRCA gene\u00a0greatly increases a woman's chance of developing\u00a0breast cancer and ovarian cancer.\u00a0This was the reason Angelina Jolie had\u00a0preventative breast cancer surgery,\u00a0followed by ovarian cancer surgery. They also increase a man's chance of\u00a0developing\u00a0male breast cancer and prostate cancer.\u00a0

BRCA genes are not the only cancer risk genes. Researchers recently identified more than 100 new gene variants associated with an increased risk of breast, prostate and ovarian cancer. Individually, these new gene variants only slightly increase the risk of cancer, but a\u00a0combination could mean a high risk overall.

If you or your partner have a high-risk cancer gene, such as an\u00a0altered version of\u00a0BRCA1, it can be passed on to any children you have.\u00a0

If you're concerned, read on.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What to do if you're worried", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What to do if you're worried\u00a0

Speak to a GP if cancer runs in your family and you're worried you may get it too.\u00a0They\u00a0may refer you to a\u00a0local genetics\u00a0service for\u00a0an NHS\u00a0genetic\u00a0test, which will tell you if you have inherited\u00a0one of the cancer risk genes.\u00a0

This type of testing is known as\u00a0predictive genetic testing. It's "predictive" because\u00a0a positive result means you have a greatly increased risk of developing cancer. It does not mean you have cancer or are definitely going to develop it.

You may be eligible for this NHS test if the faulty gene has already been identified in one of your relatives, or if there is a strong family history of cancer in your family. See what testing involves, below.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Pros and cons of having a predictive genetic test", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Pros and cons of having a predictive genetic test\u00a0

Not everyone who is eligible for the NHS test will want to have it. It's a personal decision, and should only be made after you've had\u00a0genetic counselling sessions and talked\u00a0through what having the test means, how you may feel and how you will cope.

Advantages

A positive result means you can take steps to manage your risk of developing cancer.

You can\u00a0make certain lifestyle changes to lower your risk, have regular screening and\u00a0have preventative treatment. Find out more about\u00a0managing your risk.

Knowing the result may reduce any stress and anxiety that comes from not knowing.

Disadvantages

The results of some genetic tests are inconclusive. This means doctors may identify a variation in a gene, but not know what effect it may have.

A positive result may cause permanent anxiety. Some people would rather not know\u00a0about their risk and only want to be told if they actually develop cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What\u00a0testing involves", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What\u00a0testing involves\u00a0\u00a0

There are usually 2 steps to genetic testing:

  1. A\u00a0relative with cancer has a diagnostic blood test to see if they have a cancer risk gene (this must happen before any healthy relatives are tested). Their result will be ready\u00a04 to 8\u00a0weeks later.
  2. If your relative's test is positive, you can have the predictive genetic test to see if you have the same faulty gene. Your GP will\u00a0refer you to a local genetics service for a blood test (you'll need a copy of your relative's test results). The result will take\u00a0up to\u00a02 weeks to come through after a blood sample is taken, but\u00a0this may not happen at\u00a0your first appointment.\u00a0This test is fully predictive as a "clear" negative test, which will mean you have not inherited the family high risk of cancer.

The charity\u00a0Breakthrough Breast Cancer explains the importance of these 2 steps:

"Without looking at the genes of an affected relative first, testing a healthy individual would be like reading through an entire book looking for a spelling mistake without knowing where the mistake is, or if there is a mistake at all."

When there are no affected relatives available, full testing of BRCA1 and BRCA2 may be possible for those with at least a 10% chance of having a genetic fault. This usually means having a very strong family history of early onset breast and particularly ovarian cancer. It takes 4 to 8 weeks to get the result, but this is not fully predictive as a negative test, so cannot rule out that the problem in relatives is due to a different gene.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What\u00a0a positive result means", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What\u00a0a positive result means\u00a0

If your predictive genetic test result is positive, it means you have a faulty gene that raises your risk of developing cancer.

It does not\u00a0mean you are guaranteed to get cancer\u00a0\u2013\u00a0your genes only partly influence your future health risks. Other factors, such as your medical history, lifestyle and your environment, also play a role.

If you have one of the\u00a0faulty BRCA genes, there is a 50% chance you will pass\u00a0this on to\u00a0any children you have and a 50% chance that each of your siblings also has it.

You may want to discuss your results with other members of your family, who may also be affected.\u00a0The genetics clinic will discuss with you how a positive or negative result will affect your life and your relationships with your family.

You can read more about this in the\u00a0beginner's guide to BRCA1 and BRCA2 (PDF, 866kb) produced by The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust.

Insurance companies cannot ask you to disclose the\u00a0results of predictive genetic tests for the majority of policies, but this may change in the future.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Managing your risk", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Managing your risk\u00a0\u00a0

If your test result is positive, you have a\u00a0range of options to manage your risk. Risk-reducing surgery is not the only option.

Ultimately, there's no right or wrong answer about what you should do\u00a0\u2013 it's a decision only you can make.

Regularly examining your breasts

If you have\u00a0the\u00a0faulty\u00a0BRCA1/2 gene,\u00a0it's a good idea to be aware of changes in your breasts.\u00a0Find out more about being breast cancer aware.

This advice\u00a0applies to\u00a0men with a faulty BRCA2 gene too, as they are also at increased risk of breast cancer (although to a lesser extent).

Screening

In the case of breast cancer,\u00a0annual breast screening\u00a0in the form of mammograms and\u00a0MRI scans\u00a0can also monitor your condition and catch cancer early, if it does develop.

Detecting breast cancer at an early stage means it may be easier to treat. The chance of making a full recovery from breast cancer, especially if it is detected early, is relatively high compared with other forms of cancer.

Unfortunately, there's currently no reliable screening test\u00a0for ovarian cancer or prostate cancer.\u00a0Read more about screening for\u00a0prostate cancer.\u00a0However, annual PSA tests for prostate cancer may benefit men who carry the faulty BRCA2 gene.

Lifestyle changes

Changes in your lifestyle can sometimes reduce your individual cancer risk. These include taking plenty of exercise and\u00a0eating a healthy diet.

If you\u00a0have a\u00a0faulty BRCA gene, be aware\u00a0of other factors\u00a0that could increase your risk of breast cancer. It's recommended that you avoid:

  • the\u00a0oral contraceptive pill\u00a0if you are\u00a0over 35
  • combined\u00a0hormone replacement therapy (HRT)\u00a0if you\u2019re over 50
  • drinking more than the maximum recommended\u00a0daily\u00a0limits\u00a0of alcohol
  • being overweight

The National Institute\u00a0for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) also recommends that women with a family history of breast cancer breastfeed their children, if\u00a0possible.

Find out more about things that may help to prevent ovarian cancer.

Medicine (chemoprevention)

NICE recommends medicines called tamoxifen, raloxifene\u00a0and anastrozole for some women who are at an increased\u00a0risk of breast cancer.

These can reduce\u00a0your risk of getting breast cancer for\u00a0many years.

Find out more about medicine to prevent breast cancer.

Risk-reducing surgery

Risk-reducing surgery means removing all the tissue (such as the breasts or ovaries) that could become cancerous. Carriers of\u00a0a faulty BRCA gene may wish to consider\u00a0a preventative mastectomy.\u00a0\u00a0

Women who have risk-reducing mastectomies reduce their risk of developing breast cancer by around 90%. However, a mastectomy is\u00a0a major\u00a0operation\u00a0and recovering from it can be physically and emotionally difficult.

Surgery can also be used to reduce ovarian cancer risk. Women who have their ovaries removed before the\u00a0menopause not only dramatically reduce their risk of developing ovarian cancer, but also reduce their risk of developing breast cancer by up to 50%. However, this\u00a0will trigger an early menopause and mean you're not able to have your own children (unless you store eggs or embryos).\u00a0Read more about surgery to remove the ovaries, including the risks and after-effects.

The risk of ovarian cancer in women who carry a BRCA gene fault does not begin to rise significantly until about the age of 40. Therefore, carriers of the faulty gene\u00a0who are younger than 40 usually\u00a0wait to have this operation.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Telling\u00a0close relatives", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Telling\u00a0close relatives\u00a0\u00a0

Your genetics unit will not approach your relatives about your result\u00a0\u2013 it will usually be up to you to tell your family.

You may be given a standard letter to share with relatives, which explains your test result and contains all the information they need to be referred for the test themselves.

However,\u00a0not everyone will want to have the genetic test. Women who are closely related\u00a0to you\u00a0(such as your sister or\u00a0daughter) can have cancer screening without having genetic testing.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Planning a family", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Planning a family\u00a0

Cancer risk genes can be passed on to any children you have. If your predictive genetic test is positive and you want to start a family, you have several options. You can:

  • have your children without any intervention, and risk your child inheriting the faulty gene
  • adopt a baby
  • use donor eggs or donor sperm (depending on who carries the faulty gene) to avoid passing on the faulty gene
  • discuss prenatal testing with your doctor \u2013 but testing an unborn baby for genes that may cause cancer in later life, using CVS or amniocentesis, is not routinely offered
  • have pre-implantation genetic diagnosis \u2013 a technique\u00a0used to select embryos that have not inherited the faulty gene; but there's no guarantee this technique will result in a successful pregnancy, and NHS funding for it may not be available to all patients
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Paying\u00a0for private testing", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Paying\u00a0for private testing

If there is not a strong family history of cancer in your family and the faulty gene has not otherwise been identified in any of your relatives, you will not be eligible for the NHS genetic test.

You'll have to pay for it privately if you still wish to have the test. Consider this carefully, because:

  • if you do not have any family history of cancer, it's unlikely you have one of the\u00a0faulty genes
  • the tests can be expensive, potentially costing up to \u00a3500 to \u00a32,000 or more
  • there's no guarantee they will predict whether you'll develop cancer
  • you may not be\u00a0offered\u00a0genetic counselling to help you make a decision and support you once you get your results
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "About BRCA1 and BRCA2", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

About BRCA1 and BRCA2

If\u00a0you have a fault (mutation) in one of the BRCA genes, your risk of developing\u00a0breast cancer and ovarian cancer\u00a0is greatly increased.\u00a0\u00a0

Women with the faulty BRCA1 gene, for example,\u00a0have a 60 to 90% lifetime risk of breast cancer and a 40 to 60% risk of ovarian cancer. In other words, out of every 100 women with\u00a0the faulty BRCA1 gene, between 60 and 90 will develop breast cancer in their lifetime and between 40 and 60 will develop ovarian cancer.

The faulty BRCA genes affect around\u00a01 in every 400 people, but people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent are at a much higher risk (as many as\u00a01 in 40 may carry the\u00a0faulty gene).

For more information, The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust has produced a beginner's guide to BRCA1 and BRCA2 (PDF, 867kb).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

"https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gallbladder-removal/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Cholecystectomy"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gallbladder removal surgery, also known as a cholecystectomy, is a very common procedure.

The gallbladder is a small, pouch-like organ in the upper right part of your tummy.

It stores bile, a fluid produced by the liver that helps break down fatty foods.

You don't need a gallbladder, so surgery to take it out is often recommended if you develop any problems with it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Why does my gallbladder need to be removed?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why does my gallbladder need to be removed?

Surgery to remove the gallbladder is usually carried out if you have painful gallstones.

These are small stones that can form in the gallbladder as a result of an imbalance in the substances that make up bile.

Gallstones often cause no symptoms and you may not realise you have them, but occasionally they can block the flow of bile and irritate the gallbladder (acute cholecystitis) or pancreas (acute pancreatitis).

This can cause symptoms such as:

  • sudden and intense tummy pain
  • feeling and being sick
  • yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes (jaundice)

Very occasionally it may be possible to take tablets to dissolve gallstones, but surgery to remove the gallbladder is the most effective treatment in the vast majority of cases.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What happens during gallbladder removal surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens during gallbladder removal surgery

There are 2 main ways of removing a gallbladder:

  • laparoscopic (keyhole) cholecystectomy – several small cuts (incisions) are made in your tummy (abdomen) and fine surgical instruments are used to access and remove your gallbladder
  • open cholecystectomy – a single larger incision is made in your tummy to access and remove your gallbladder

Keyhole surgery is used most often because you can leave hospital sooner, recover faster and are left with smaller scars than with an open procedure.

Both techniques are performed under general anaesthetic, which means you'll be asleep during the operation and won't feel any pain while it's carried out.

Find out more about how gallbladder removal surgery is performed

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Recovering from gallbladder removal surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from gallbladder removal surgery

It doesn't usually take long to recover from keyhole surgery to remove your gallbladder.

Most people can leave hospital the same day or the next morning.

You'll probably be able to return to most of your normal activities within 2 weeks.

It takes longer to recover from open surgery. You may need to stay in hospital for 3 to 5 days and it could be 6 to 8 weeks before you're feeling back to normal.

Find out more about recovering from gallbladder removal surgery

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Living without a gallbladder", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Living without a gallbladder

You can lead a perfectly normal life without a gallbladder.

Your liver will still make enough bile to digest your food, but instead of being stored in the gallbladder, it drips continuously into your digestive system.

You may have been advised to eat a special diet before surgery, but this doesn't need to be continued afterwards.

Instead, you should aim to have a generally healthy, balanced diet.

Some people experience problems such as bloating or diarrhoea after surgery, although this usually improves within a few weeks. 

If you notice certain foods or drinks trigger these symptoms, you may wish to avoid them in the future.

Find out more about diet after gallbladder surgery

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Risks of gallbladder removal surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks of gallbladder removal surgery

Gallbladder removal surgery is considered to be a safe procedure, but, like any type of surgery, there's a risk of complications.

Possible complications include:

  • wound infection
  • bile leaking into the tummy
  • damage to one of the openings (ducts) carrying bile out of the liver
  • blood clots

Speak to your surgeon about the benefits and risks of surgery before your operation.

Find out more about the complications of gallbladder removal surgery

Gallstones can cause sudden episodes of severe tummy pain. But many people with gallstones have no symptoms.

Gallstones are thought to be caused by too much cholesterol in your gallbladder. Women and people who are overweight or over 40 are most at risk.

Gallstones do not always need to be treated. If they're causing problems, you may need surgery to remove your gallbladder.

Gallstones often have no symptoms.

But if a gallstone becomes trapped in an opening (duct) inside the gallbladder, it can trigger a sudden, intense pain in your tummy that usually lasts between 1 and 5 hours.

This type of abdominal pain is known as biliary colic.

Some people with gallstones can also develop complications, such as inflammation of the gallbladder (cholecystitis).

This can cause:

  • persistent pain
  • yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
  • a high temperature

When gallstones cause symptoms or complications, it's known as gallstone disease or cholelithiasis.

Women and people who are overweight or over 40 are most at risk.", "text": "

Gallstones are thought to develop because of an imbalance in the chemical make-up of bile inside the gallbladder.

In most cases the levels of cholesterol in bile become too high and the excess cholesterol forms into stones.

Gallstones are very common. It's estimated more than\u00a01 in every 10 adults in the UK\u00a0has gallstones, although only\u00a0a minority\u00a0of\u00a0people develop symptoms.

You're more at risk of developing gallstones if you're:

  • overweight\u00a0or obese
  • female\u00a0(particularly if you have had children)
  • 40 or over\u00a0(the risk increases as you get older)

If they're causing problems, you may need surgery to remove your gallbladder.", "text": "

Treatment is usually only necessary if gallstones are causing:

  • symptoms,\u00a0such as tummy pain
  • complications, such as jaundice or acute pancreatitis

In these cases, keyhole surgery to remove the gallbladder may be recommended.\u00a0

This procedure,\u00a0known as a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, is relatively simple\u00a0to perform and has a low risk of complications.

It's possible to lead a normal life without a gallbladder.

Your liver will still produce bile to digest food, but\u00a0the bile will drip continuously into the small intestine, rather than\u00a0build up in the gallbladder.

The gallbladder

The gallbladder is a small pouch-like organ found underneath the liver. Its main purpose is to store and concentrate bile.

Bile is a liquid produced by the liver to help digest fats. It's passed from the liver\u00a0into the gallbladder\u00a0through a series of channels known as bile ducts.

The bile is stored in the gallbladder and, over time, becomes more concentrated, which makes it better at digesting fats.

The gallbladder releases bile into the digestive system when it's needed.

In most cases the levels of cholesterol in bile become too high and the excess cholesterol forms into stones.

Gallstones are very common. It's estimated more than\u00a01 in every 10 adults in the UK\u00a0has gallstones, although only\u00a0a minority\u00a0of\u00a0people develop symptoms.

You're more at risk of developing gallstones if you're:

  • overweight\u00a0or obese
  • female\u00a0(particularly if you have had children)
  • 40 or over\u00a0(the risk increases as you get older)

  • symptoms,\u00a0such as tummy pain
  • complications, such as jaundice or acute pancreatitis

In these cases, keyhole surgery to remove the gallbladder may be recommended.\u00a0

This procedure,\u00a0known as a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, is relatively simple\u00a0to perform and has a low risk of complications.

It's possible to lead a normal life without a gallbladder.

Your liver will still produce bile to digest food, but\u00a0the bile will drip continuously into the small intestine, rather than\u00a0build up in the gallbladder.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook

Gallstone disease is usually easily treated with surgery.\u00a0

Very severe cases can be life threatening, particularly in people who are already in poor health.

But deaths from gallstone disease\u00a0are rare in the UK.

Gangrene:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Gangrene", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Gangrene", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Gangrene is a serious condition in which a loss of blood supply causes tissue to die. It can affect any part of the body but typically starts in the toes, feet, fingers and hands.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-16T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-16T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/", "name": "Gangrene", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-09-05T08:46:52+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gangrene", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/prevention/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Prevention"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Appendix", "Antibiotics", "Bacterial infections"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gangrene is a serious condition where a loss of blood supply causes body tissue to die. It can affect any part of the body but typically starts in the toes, feet, fingers and hands.

Gangrene can occur as a result of an injury, infection or a long-term condition that affects blood circulation.

Symptoms of gangrene include:

  • redness and swelling in the affected area
  • either a loss of sensation or severe pain in the affected area
  • sores or blisters in the affected area that bleed or produce a foul-smelling pus

You should see your GP immediately if you're worried you may have gangrene.

Read more about the symptoms of gangrene and diagnosing gangrene.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

Anyone can develop gangrene, particularly after a serious injury, but there are certain groups of people who are more at risk.

These include people with long-term conditions that can affect the blood vessels, such as:

  • diabetes – a lifelong condition that causes a person's blood sugar level to become too high
  • atherosclerosis – where the arteries become clogged up with a fatty substance called plaque, narrowing them and restricting blood flow 
  • peripheral arterial disease – where a build-up of fatty deposits in the arteries restricts blood supply to leg muscles
  • Raynaud's – where blood vessels in certain parts of the body, usually the fingers or toes, react abnormally to cold temperatures

Read more about the causes of gangrene.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How gangrene is treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How gangrene is treated

The earlier treatment for gangrene begins, the more successful it's likely to be. The main treatments include surgery to remove damaged tissue, known as debridement, and antibiotics to treat any underlying infection.

In some cases, surgery may be needed to restore blood flow to the affected area.

In more severe cases, it may be necessary to remove an entire body part such as a toe, foot, or lower leg. This is known as amputation.

Read more about treating gangrene.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Preventing gangrene", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing gangrene

Many cases of gangrene can be prevented.

If you have a condition that increases your risk of getting gangrene, such as diabetes, it's important you have regular check-ups to assess the state of your feet. Report any problems to your GP as soon as possible.

Stopping smoking if you smoke and adopting a healthy lifestyle, with a low-fat diet and regular exercise, can also improve your circulation and reduce your risk of developing gangrene.

Read more about preventing gangrene.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Gastrectomy:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Gastrectomy", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Gastrectomy", "alternateName": []}, "description": "A gastrectomy is a medical procedure that involves surgically removing all or part of the stomach.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gastrectomy/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-03-02T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-03-02T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gastrectomy/", "name": "Gastrectomy", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2018-03-05T15:24:25+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gastrectomy/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gastrectomy", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gastrectomy/recovery/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Recovery"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gastrectomy/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Stomach surgery", "Stomach", "Obesity", "Stomach cancer"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A gastrectomy is a medical procedure where all or part of the stomach is surgically removed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When a gastrectomy is needed", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When a gastrectomy is needed

A gastrectomy is often used to treat stomach cancer.

Less commonly, it's used to treat:

  • life-threatening obesity
  • oesophageal cancer
  • stomach ulcers (peptic ulcers)
  • non-cancerous tumours

Gastrectomy is usually an effective treatment for cancer and obesity.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How a gastrectomy is performed", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How a gastrectomy is performed

There are 4 main types of gastrectomy, depending on which part of your stomach needs to be removed:

  • total gastrectomy – the whole stomach is removed
  • partial gastrectomy – the lower part of the stomach is removed
  • sleeve gastrectomy – the left side of the stomach is removed
  • oesophagogastrectomy – the top part of the stomach and part of the oesophagus (gullet), the tube connecting your throat to your stomach, is removed

The top of the stomach is connected to the gullet, the bottom of the stomach to the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), and the gullet to either the small intestine or the remaining section of stomach. This means you will still have a working digestive system, although it won't function as well as it did before.

All types of gastrectomy are carried out under general anaesthetic, so you'll be asleep during the operation.

Techniques for gastrectomy

Two different techniques can be used to carry out a gastrectomy:

  • open gastrectomy – where a large cut is made in your stomach or chest
  • keyhole surgery (laparoscopic gastrectomy) – where several smaller cuts are made and special surgical instruments are used

People who have keyhole surgery usually recover faster and have less pain after the procedure than those who have an open gastrectomy. You may also be able to leave hospital a little sooner.

Complication rates after keyhole surgery are similar to those for open gastrectomies.

Open gastrectomies are usually more effective in treating advanced stomach cancer than keyhole surgery is. This is because it's usually easier to remove affected lymph nodes (small glands that are part of the immune system) during an open gastrectomy.

Before you decide which procedure to have, discuss the advantages and disadvantages of both with your surgeon.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Recovering after a gastrectomy", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering after a gastrectomy

A gastrectomy is a major operation, so recovery can take a long time. You'll usually stay in hospital for 1 or 2 weeks after the procedure, where you may receive nutrition directly into a vein until you can eat and drink again.

You'll eventually be able to digest most foods and liquids. However, you may need to make changes to your diet, such as eating frequent small meals instead of 3 large meals a day. You may also need vitamin supplements to ensure you're getting the correct nutrition.

Read more about recovering from a gastrectomy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Complications", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications

As with any type of surgery, a gastrectomy carries a risk of complications, such as infection, bleeding and leaking from the area that's been stitched together.

A gastrectomy may also lead to problems caused by a reduction in your ability to absorb vitamins, such as anaemia or osteoporosis.

Read more about the possible complications of a gastrectomy.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
