  • a severe sore throat
  • swelling either side of your neck \u2013 swollen glands
  • extreme tiredness or exhaustion
  • tonsillitis that is not getting better

These are glandular fever symptoms.

You do not usually get glandular fever more than once.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

The GP might order a blood test to confirm it's glandular fever and to rule out other illnesses, like tonsillitis. This will test for the Epstein-Barr virus, which causes glandular fever.

The GP will not give you antibiotics. Glandular fever is caused by a virus so antibiotics will not work.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Go to A&E or call 999 if you have:

  • difficulty swallowing
  • difficulty breathing
  • severe stomach pain
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to treat glandular fever yourself", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's no cure for glandular fever \u2013 it gets better by itself.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • rest and sleep

  • drink plenty of fluids (to avoid dehydration)

  • take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen (do not give aspirin to children under 16)

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not drink alcohol \u2013 your liver might be weak while you have glandular fever

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"@type": "VideoObject", "name": "How to treat glandular fever", "embedUrl": "//players.brightcove.net/79855382001/WwRvWyF4zr_default/index.html?videoId=5712769656001", "content_url": "https://manifest.prod.boltdns.net/manifest/v1/hls/v4/clear/79855382001/bde12bad-25d1-4b27-95a1-4c5f42143c9d/10s/master.m3u8?fastly_token=NWZmY2FhNzhfYTZiM2UyNjI4YWJhNzNjMjk5ZGM1ZDNmMjE2ZWNhNmY0M2VhYWVjOGJlMDJiZjhkZWM2NjJlODhlN2E4ZDY0NQ%3D%3D", "duration": "PT47.232S", "position": 0, "identifier": "14", "alternateName": "5712769656001", "description": "This video explains how to treat glandular fever yourself.", "uploadDate": "2020-12-09T00:04:56.235000+00:00", "lastReviewed": ["2020-06-01", "2023-06-01"], "thumbnailUrl": "https://cf-images.eu-west-1.prod.boltdns.net/v1/static/79855382001/bde12bad-25d1-4b27-95a1-4c5f42143c9d/168d2542-5ce4-4828-94b4-8c14ea553cfc/160x90/match/image.jpg", "text": ""}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How long glandular fever lasts", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You should feel better within 2 to 3 weeks. Some people might feel extremely tired for months.

Try to gradually increase your activity when your energy starts to come back.

Glandular fever can cause your spleen to swell. For the first month, avoid heavy lifting and sports or activities that might increase your risk of falling, as this may damage your spleen.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 10, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to stop glandular fever spreading", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glandular fever is spread through spit, so you can get it through kissing or by sharing cups or cutlery.

You're infectious for up to 7 weeks before you get symptoms.

You can go back to school or work as soon as you start to feel better.

To prevent glandular fever spreading:

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • wash your hands regularly

  • wash bedding and clothes that may have spit on them

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not kiss others (glandular fever is known as the kissing disease)

  • do not share cups, cutlery or towels

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 11, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Glandular fever complications", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most people get better with no problems. But sometimes glandular fever may lead to other problems like:

  • mild liver inflammation (hepatitis), which causes yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)
  • low levels of blood cells called platelets (thrombocytopenia)
  • neurological conditions, such as Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome or Bell's palsy
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 12, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Glaucoma:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Glaucoma", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Glaucoma", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what glaucoma is, what the symptoms are, why it happens and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-02-15T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-02-15T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/", "name": "Glaucoma", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-17T14:41:10+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/#overview", "description": "Glaucoma is a common eye condition where the optic nerve, which connects the eye to the brain, becomes damaged.", "text": "

Symptoms of glaucoma can include blurred vision or seeing rainbow-coloured circles around bright lights. Both eyes are usually affected.

Your age, ethnicity, family history and some medical conditions can increase your chances of getting glaucoma.

Treatment for glaucoma will depend on your symptoms. It can include eye drops, laser treatment and surgery.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of glaucoma can include blurred vision or seeing rainbow-coloured circles around bright lights. Both eyes are usually affected.", "text": "

Glaucoma does not usually cause any symptoms to begin with.

It tends to develop slowly over many years and affects the edges of your vision (peripheral vision) first.

For this reason, many people do not realise they have glaucoma, and it's often only picked up during a routine eye test.

If you do notice any symptoms, they might include blurred vision, or seeing rainbow-coloured circles around bright lights.

Both eyes are usually affected, although it may be worse in 1 eye.

Very occasionally, glaucoma can develop suddenly and cause:

  • intense eye pain
  • nausea and vomiting
  • a red eye
  • a headache
  • tenderness around the eyes
  • seeing rings around lights
  • blurred vision
", "title": "Symptoms of glaucoma"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/#causes", "description": "Your age, ethnicity, family history and some medical conditions can increase your chances of getting glaucoma.", "text": "

Glaucoma can occur for a number of reasons.

Most cases are caused by a build-up of pressure in the eye when fluid is unable to drain properly.

This increase in pressure then damages the nerve that connects the eye to the brain (optic nerve).

It's often unclear why this happens, although certain things can increase the risk, including:

  • your age \u2013 glaucoma becomes more common as you get older
  • your ethnicity \u2013 people of African, Caribbean or Asian origin are at a higher risk
  • your family history \u2013 you're more likely to develop glaucoma if you have a parent or sibling with the condition
  • other medical conditions \u2013 such as short-sightedness, long-sightedness and diabetes

It's not clear whether you can do anything to prevent glaucoma, but having regular eye tests should pick it up as early as possible.

", "title": "Causes of glaucoma"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatment for glaucoma will depend on your symptoms. It can include eye drops, laser treatment and surgery.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatment for glaucoma will depend on your symptoms. It can include eye drops, laser treatment and surgery.", "text": "

It's not possible to reverse any loss of vision that occurred before glaucoma was diagnosed, but treatment can help stop your vision getting worse.

The treatment recommended for you will depend on the type of glaucoma you have, but the options are:

  • eye drops \u2013 to reduce the pressure in your eyes
  • laser treatment \u2013 to open up the blocked drainage tubes or reduce the production of fluid in your eyes
  • surgery \u2013 to improve the drainage of fluid

You'll also probably need regular appointments to monitor your condition and check the treatment is working.

", "title": "Treatments for glaucoma"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Glaucoma", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glaucoma/treatments/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Eye", "Glaucoma", "Eye injuries", "Eye conditions"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glaucoma is a common eye condition where the optic nerve, which connects the eye to the brain, becomes damaged.

It's usually caused by fluid building up in the front part of the eye, which increases pressure inside the eye.

Glaucoma can lead to loss of vision if it's not diagnosed and treated early.

It can affect people of all ages, but is most common in adults in their 70s and 80s.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of glaucoma", "text": "Symptoms of glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glaucoma does not usually cause any symptoms to begin with.

It tends to develop slowly over many years and affects the edges of your vision (peripheral vision) first.

For this reason, many people do not realise they have glaucoma, and it's often only picked up during a routine eye test.

If you do notice any symptoms, they might include blurred vision, or seeing rainbow-coloured circles around bright lights.

Both eyes are usually affected, although it may be worse in 1 eye.

Very occasionally, glaucoma can develop suddenly and cause:

  • intense eye pain
  • nausea and vomiting
  • a red eye
  • a headache
  • tenderness around the eyes
  • seeing rings around lights
  • blurred vision
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to get medical advice

Visit an opticians or a GP if you have any concerns about your vision.

If you have glaucoma, early diagnosis and treatment can help stop your vision getting worse.

Without treatment, glaucoma can eventually lead to blindness.

If you develop symptoms of glaucoma suddenly, go to your nearest eye casualty unit or A&E as soon as possible.

This is a medical emergency that may require immediate treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of glaucoma

There are several different types of glaucoma.

The most common is called primary open angle glaucoma. This tends to develop slowly over many years.

It's caused by the drainage channels in the eye becoming gradually clogged over time.

Other types of glaucoma include:

  • acute angle closure glaucoma \u2013 an uncommon type caused by the drainage in the eye becoming suddenly blocked, which can raise the pressure inside the eye very quickly
  • secondary glaucoma \u2013 caused by an underlying eye condition, such as inflammation of the eye (uveitis)
  • childhood glaucoma (congenital glaucoma) \u2013 a rare type that occurs in very young children, caused by an abnormality of the eye
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of glaucoma", "text": "Causes of glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glaucoma can occur for a number of reasons.

Most cases are caused by a build-up of pressure in the eye when fluid is unable to drain properly.

This increase in pressure then damages the nerve that connects the eye to the brain (optic nerve).

It's often unclear why this happens, although certain things can increase the risk, including:

  • your age \u2013 glaucoma becomes more common as you get older
  • your ethnicity \u2013 people of African, Caribbean or Asian origin are at a higher risk
  • your family history \u2013 you're more likely to develop glaucoma if you have a parent or sibling with the condition
  • other medical conditions \u2013 such as short-sightedness, long-sightedness and diabetes

It's not clear whether you can do anything to prevent glaucoma, but having regular eye tests should pick it up as early as possible.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tests for glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tests for glaucoma

Glaucoma can usually be detected during a routine eye test at an opticians, often before it causes any noticeable symptoms.

The tests are carried out in the opticians by an optometrist.

You should have a routine eye test at least every 2 years.

Find out if you're eligible for free NHS eye tests

Several quick and painless tests can be carried out to check for glaucoma, including vision tests and measurements of the pressure inside your eye.

If tests suggest you have glaucoma, you should be referred to a specialist eye doctor (ophthalmologist) to discuss treatment.

Find out how glaucoma is diagnosed

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments for glaucoma", "text": "Treatments for glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's not possible to reverse any loss of vision that occurred before glaucoma was diagnosed, but treatment can help stop your vision getting worse.

The treatment recommended for you will depend on the type of glaucoma you have, but the options are:

  • eye drops \u2013 to reduce the pressure in your eyes
  • laser treatment \u2013 to open up the blocked drainage tubes or reduce the production of fluid in your eyes
  • surgery \u2013 to improve the drainage of fluid

You'll also probably need regular appointments to monitor your condition and check the treatment is working.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Further support for glaucoma", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Further support for glaucoma

The Royal National Institute of Blind People (RNIB) and the International Glaucoma Association have more information on glaucoma and offer further support for people affected by glaucoma.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Glomerulonephritis:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Glomerulonephritis", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Glomerulonephritis", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about glomerulonephritis, which is damage to the tiny filters inside your kidneys (the glomeruli).", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glomerulonephritis/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-12-05T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-12-05T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glomerulonephritis/", "name": "Glomerulonephritis", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-12-12T16:28:13+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glomerulonephritis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Glomerulonephritis", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glomerulonephritis/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Glomerulonephritis", "Hypertension", "Kidney disease"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glomerulonephritis is damage to the tiny filters inside your kidneys (the glomeruli). It's often caused by your immune system attacking healthy body tissue.

Glomerulonephritis does not usually cause any noticeable symptoms. It's more likely to be diagnosed when blood or urine tests are carried out for another reason.

Although mild cases of glomerulonephritis can be treated effectively, for some people the condition can lead to long-term kidney problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms of glomerulonephritis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of glomerulonephritis

In severe cases of glomerulonephritis, you may see blood in your urine. However, this is usually noticed when a urine sample is tested.

Your urine may be frothy if it contains a large amount of protein.

If a lot of protein leaks into your urine, swelling of the legs or other parts of the body can also develop. This is known as nephrotic syndrome.

Depending on your type of glomerulonephritis, other parts of your body can be affected and cause symptoms such as:

  • rashes
  • joint pain
  • breathing problems
  • tiredness

Many people with glomerulonephritis also have high blood pressure.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to get medical advice

See a GP if you notice blood in your urine. This does not always mean you have glomerulonephritis, but the cause should be investigated.

If the GP suspects glomerulonephritis, they'll usually arrange:

  • a blood test – to measure your creatinine level
  • a urine test – to check for blood or protein in your urine

If you do have glomerulonephritis, further blood tests may be needed to help find out the cause.

If your kidney problem needs to be investigated further, it may be recommended that you have:

  • an ultrasound scan – this is to check the size of your kidneys, make sure there are no blockages, and look for any other problems
  • a biopsy – this is to remove a small sample of kidney tissue, carried out using local anaesthetic to numb the area; an ultrasound machine locates your kidneys and a small needle is used to take a sample
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes of glomerulonephritis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of glomerulonephritis

Glomerulonephritis is often caused by a problem with your immune system. Sometimes it's part of a condition such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or vasculitis.

In some cases, it can be caused by infections, such as:

  • HIV
  • hepatitis B and hepatitis C
  • infection of the heart valves (endocarditis)

In most cases, glomerulonephritis does not run in families.

If you're diagnosed with an inherited type of glomerulonephritis, a doctor can advise you about the chances of someone else in your family being affected.

They may recommend screening, which can identify people who may be at increased risk of developing the condition.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating glomerulonephritis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating glomerulonephritis

Treatment for glomerulonephritis depends on the cause and severity of your condition. Mild cases may not need any treatment.

Treatment can be as simple as making changes to your diet, such as eating less salt to reduce the strain on your kidneys.

Medicine to lower blood pressure, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, is commonly prescribed because it helps protect the kidneys.

If the condition is caused by a problem with your immune system, medicine called immunosuppressants may be used.

Read about treating glomerulonephritis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of glomerulonephritis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of glomerulonephritis

Although treatment for glomerulonephritis is effective in many cases, further problems can sometimes develop.

These include:

  • high blood pressure
  • high cholesterol
  • blood clots – including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or a pulmonary embolism
  • damage to other organs
  • chronic kidney disease
  • kidney failure

If you're diagnosed with glomerulonephritis, a doctor may prescribe medicine to help lower your blood pressure, lower your cholesterol or protect against blood clots.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Glue ear:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Glue ear", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Glue ear", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what glue ear is, what causes it, what a GP can do to help, and how it's treated in hospital.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-28T08:57:00+00:00", "2023-07-28T08:57:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/", "name": "Glue ear", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-13T15:59:30+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/#overview", "description": "Glue ear is where the empty middle part of the ear canal fills up with fluid. It's more common in children but adults can sometimes get it.", "text": "

The main symptom of glue ear is temporary loss of hearing in 1 or both ears.

Glue ear often gets better on its own. If needed, a GP may suggest treatment to drain the fluid, such as blowing up a small balloon using your nose.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of glue ear is temporary loss of hearing in 1 or both ears.", "text": "

The most common symptom of glue ear is temporary hearing loss. It can affect both ears at the same time.

Other symptoms may include:

  • earache or ear pain
  • hearing sounds like ringing or buzzing (tinnitus)

Glue ear is much more common in children, but adults with glue ear have the same symptoms.

", "title": "Check if it's glue ear"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/#treatments-summary", "description": "Glue ear often gets better on its own. If needed, a GP may suggest treatment to drain the fluid, such as blowing up a small balloon using your nose.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/glue-ear/#treatments-other", "description": "Glue ear often gets better on its own. If needed, a GP may suggest treatment to drain the fluid, such as blowing up a small balloon using your nose.", "text": "

Glue ear is not always treated. The GP will usually wait to see if the symptoms get better on their own.

This is because there's no effective medicine for glue ear, and it often clears up on its own within 3 months.

Your child may be monitored for up to a year in case their symptoms change or get worse.

The GP may suggest trying a treatment called autoinflation while waiting for symptoms to improve. Autoinflation can help fluid in the ear to drain.

It's done by either:

  • blowing up a special balloon using 1 nostril at a time
  • swallowing while holding the nostrils closed

As autoinflation has to be done several times a day, it's not usually recommended for children under 3 years old.

Antibiotics may be prescribed if glue ear causes an ear infection.

Glue ear is where the empty middle part of the ear canal fills up with fluid. This can cause temporary hearing loss. It usually clears up within 3 months, but see a GP about any hearing problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Check if it's glue ear", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The most common symptom of glue ear is temporary hearing loss. It can affect both ears at the same time.

Other symptoms may include:

  • earache or ear pain
  • hearing sounds like ringing or buzzing (tinnitus)

Glue ear is much more common in children, but adults with glue ear have the same symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "Other conditions that cause ear pain", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Symptoms Possible condition
Ear pain with a change in hearing earwax build-up, an object stuck in the ear (do not try to remove it yourself – see a GP), perforated eardrum (particularly after a loud noise or accident)
Ear pain with toothache children teething, dental abscess
Ear pain with pain when swallowing sore throat, tonsillitis
Ear pain with a fever ear infection, flu, cold
"}]}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if your child has hearing problems

Your child may be struggling to hear if they often:

  • speak loudly
  • are difficult to understand
  • ask people to repeat what they say
  • ask for the TV or music to be turned up loud
  • struggle to hear people far away
  • become easily distracted when people are talking
  • seem tired and irritable because it's harder to listen
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

The GP should be able to tell if it's glue ear by looking for fluid inside the ear.

They'll use a small scope with a light and magnifying glass. This should not be painful.

If your child has had glue ear for more than 3 months, they may be referred to a specialist for hearing tests.

Hearing tests can help find out how severe any hearing loss is and what's causing it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for glue ear from a GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Glue ear is not always treated. The GP will usually wait to see if the symptoms get better on their own.

This is because there's no effective medicine for glue ear, and it often clears up on its own within 3 months.

Your child may be monitored for up to a year in case their symptoms change or get worse.

The GP may suggest trying a treatment called autoinflation while waiting for symptoms to improve. Autoinflation can help fluid in the ear to drain.

It's done by either:

  • blowing up a special balloon using 1 nostril at a time
  • swallowing while holding the nostrils closed

As autoinflation has to be done several times a day, it's not usually recommended for children under 3 years old.

Antibiotics may be prescribed if glue ear causes an ear infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Hospital treatment for glue ear", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Your child may be referred to a specialist in hospital if:

  • glue ear symptoms are affecting their learning and development
  • they already had severe hearing loss before glue ear
  • they have Down's syndrome or a cleft lip and palate, as glue ear is less likely to get better by itself

The 2 main treatments are temporary hearing aids or grommets (small tubes implanted in the ear).

Occasionally, surgery may be recommended to remove some glands at the back of the nose (adenoids). This is known as an adenoidectomy.

The specialist in hospital will help you decide on the best treatment option.

Grommets for treating glue ear

A grommet is a small tube that's placed in your child's ear during surgery. It drains fluid away and keeps the eardrum open.

The grommet should fall out naturally within 6 to 12 months as your child's ear gets better.

If your child needs grommets, you might find these links useful:

  • Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH): treatment of glue ear with grommets
  • National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS): Harvey gets grommets
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Goitre:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Goitre", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Goitre", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about a goitre (sometimes spelled \"goiter\"), an abnormal swelling of the thyroid gland that causes a lump to form in the neck.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-04-15T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-04-15T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/", "name": "Goitre", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-11T12:47:32+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/#overview", "description": "A goitre is a swelling of the thyroid gland that causes a lump in the front of your neck.", "text": "

Goitres are usually small and do not cause symptoms. A large goitre may cause coughing, a tight throat, hoarseness and difficulty swallowing.

Treatments for a goitre include medicines, hormone therapy and sometimes surgery. Goitres with no symptoms do not usually need treatment.

Causes for a goitre include problems with your thyroid gland, puberty, the menopause and not enough iodine in your diet.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/#symptoms", "description": "Goitres are usually small and do not cause symptoms. A large goitre may cause coughing, a tight throat, hoarseness and difficulty swallowing.", "text": "

The size of a goitre can vary from person to person. In most cases, the swelling is small and does not cause any symptoms.

In more severe cases, symptoms may include:

  • coughing
  • a tight feeling in your throat
  • changes to your voice, such as hoarseness
  • difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • difficulty breathing\u00a0\u2013\u00a0there may be a high-pitched sound when you breathe
", "title": "Symptoms of a goitre"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatments for a goitre include medicines, hormone therapy and sometimes surgery. Goitres with no symptoms do not usually need treatment.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatments for a goitre include medicines, hormone therapy and sometimes surgery. Goitres with no symptoms do not usually need treatment.", "text": "

The treatment for\u00a0a goitre depends on the underlying cause.

If the goitre is small and not causing any problems, a wait-and-see approach is usually recommended.

Other possible treatments include radioiodine treatment and thyroid surgery.

Although most goitres are non-cancerous, it's estimated that in 1 in 20 cases they may be a sign of thyroid cancer.

", "title": "Treating a\u00a0goitre"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/#causes", "description": "Causes for a goitre include problems with your thyroid gland, puberty, the menopause and not enough iodine in your diet.", "text": "

A goitre can have several possible causes, including:

  • an overactive thyroid gland\u00a0(hyperthyroidism)
  • an underactive thyroid gland\u00a0(hypothyroidism)
  • hormone changes during puberty, pregnancy\u00a0or the menopause
  • not enough\u00a0iodine in your diet
  • taking some types of\u00a0medicine,\u00a0such as lithium, a medicine used to treat some mental health conditions
  • an inflamed thyroid gland (thyroiditis)
  • having\u00a0radiation treatment to your neck or chest area, such as radiotherapy\u00a0for neck cancer
  • nodules or cysts within the thyroid\u00a0\u2013 most are harmless, but they should be assessed
  • thyroid cancer\u00a0\u2013 a rare type of cancer in the UK

Anyone can develop a goitre, but the chances increase with age. Women are also more likely to develop\u00a0a goitre.

", "title": "Causes of a\u00a0goitre"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Goitre", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/goitre/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Underactive thyroid"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A goitre (sometimes spelled "goiter") is a swelling of the thyroid gland that causes a lump in the front of the\u00a0neck. The lump will move up and down when you swallow.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The thyroid gland is a small butterfly-shaped gland in the neck, just in front of the windpipe (trachea).

It produces thyroid hormones, which help regulate the body's metabolism, the chemical processes that occur in the body.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of a goitre", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The size of a goitre can vary from person to person. In most cases, the swelling is small and does not cause any symptoms.

In more severe cases, symptoms may include:

  • coughing
  • a tight feeling in your throat
  • changes to your voice, such as hoarseness
  • difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • difficulty breathing\u00a0\u2013\u00a0there may be a high-pitched sound when you breathe
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing a goitre

See your GP if you think you have a goitre. They'll examine your neck to see whether your\u00a0thyroid gland is swollen.

The GP may also request a thyroid function test to see how well your thyroid gland is working.

A thyroid function test measures the level of certain hormones in your blood.

It can show whether you have an underactive or overactive thyroid, both of which are associated with goitre.

If necessary, you may be referred to a specialist in hospital for further tests or treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating a\u00a0goitre", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The treatment for\u00a0a goitre depends on the underlying cause.

If the goitre is small and not causing any problems, a wait-and-see approach is usually recommended.

Other possible treatments include radioiodine treatment and thyroid surgery.

Although most goitres are non-cancerous, it's estimated that in 1 in 20 cases they may be a sign of thyroid cancer.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of a\u00a0goitre", "text": "Causes of a\u00a0goitre", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A goitre can have several possible causes, including:

  • an overactive thyroid gland\u00a0(hyperthyroidism)
  • an underactive thyroid gland\u00a0(hypothyroidism)
  • hormone changes during puberty, pregnancy\u00a0or the menopause
  • not enough\u00a0iodine in your diet
  • taking some types of\u00a0medicine,\u00a0such as lithium, a medicine used to treat some mental health conditions
  • an inflamed thyroid gland (thyroiditis)
  • having\u00a0radiation treatment to your neck or chest area, such as radiotherapy\u00a0for neck cancer
  • nodules or cysts within the thyroid\u00a0\u2013 most are harmless, but they should be assessed
  • thyroid cancer\u00a0\u2013 a rare type of cancer in the UK

Anyone can develop a goitre, but the chances increase with age. Women are also more likely to develop\u00a0a goitre.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of goitre

There are 2\u00a0main types of goitre:

  • diffuse goitre \u2013 where the entire thyroid gland swells and feels smooth to the touch
  • nodular goitre\u00a0\u2013 where solid or fluid-filled lumps called\u00a0nodules develop within the thyroid and make the thyroid gland feel lumpy to touch; the nodules can be single or multiple and may contain fluid

It used to be known as 'the clap'.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-06-29T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-06-29T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/", "name": "Gonorrhoea", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:08:41+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/#overview", "description": "Gonorrhoea is a common sexually transmitted infection.", "text": "

Gonorrhoea is mainly spread through unprotected vaginal, oral or anal sex.

Not everyone with gonorrhoea has symptoms. Common symptoms include unusual discharge from your vagina or penis and pain when peeing.

Gonorrhoea is treated with antibiotics. You can get treatment from a sexual health clinic.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/#causes", "description": "Gonorrhoea is mainly spread through unprotected vaginal, oral or anal sex.", "text": "

The bacteria that cause gonorrhoea are mainly found in discharge from the penis and in vaginal fluid.

Gonorrhoea is easily passed between people through:

  • unprotected vaginal, oral or anal sex
  • sharing vibrators or other sex\u00a0toys that have not been washed or covered with a new condom each time they're used

The bacteria can infect the entrance to the womb (cervix), the tube that passes urine out of the body (urethra), the rectum and, less commonly, the throat or eyes.

The infection can also be passed from a pregnant woman to her baby. If\u00a0you're pregnant and may have gonorrhoea, it's important to get tested and\u00a0treated before\u00a0your baby is born.

Without treatment, gonorrhoea can\u00a0cause permanent blindness in a newborn baby.

Gonorrhoea is not spread by kissing, hugging, swimming pools, toilet seats or sharing baths, towels, cups, plates or cutlery. The bacteria cannot survive outside the human body for long.

", "title": "How gonorrhoea is spread"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/#symptoms", "description": "Not everyone with gonorrhoea has symptoms. Common symptoms include unusual discharge from your vagina or penis and pain when peeing.", "text": "

Typical\u00a0symptoms of gonorrhoea include a thick green or yellow discharge from the vagina or penis, pain when peeing and, in women, bleeding between periods.

But\u00a0around 1 in 10 infected men and almost half of infected women do not experience any symptoms.

", "title": "Symptoms of gonorrhoea"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/#treatments-summary", "description": "Gonorrhoea is treated with antibiotics. You can get treatment from a sexual health clinic.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gonorrhoea/#treatments-other", "description": "Gonorrhoea is treated with antibiotics. You can get treatment from a sexual health clinic.", "text": "

Gonorrhoea is usually treated with a single antibiotic injection and a single antibiotic tablet. With effective treatment, most of your symptoms should improve within a few days.

It's usually recommended you attend a follow-up appointment a week or 2 after treatment so another test can be carried out to see if you're clear of infection.

You should avoid having sex until you have been told you no longer have the infection.

Previous successful treatment for gonorrhoea does not make you immune to catching it again.

Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI)\u00a0caused by bacteria called Neisseria gonorrhoeae or gonococcus. It used to be known as "the clap".

The bacteria that cause gonorrhoea are mainly found in discharge from the penis and in vaginal fluid.

Gonorrhoea is easily passed between people through:

  • unprotected vaginal, oral or anal sex
  • sharing vibrators or other sex\u00a0toys that have not been washed or covered with a new condom each time they're used

The bacteria can infect the entrance to the womb (cervix), the tube that passes urine out of the body (urethra), the rectum and, less commonly, the throat or eyes.

The infection can also be passed from a pregnant woman to her baby. If\u00a0you're pregnant and may have gonorrhoea, it's important to get tested and\u00a0treated before\u00a0your baby is born.

Without treatment, gonorrhoea can\u00a0cause permanent blindness in a newborn baby.

Gonorrhoea is not spread by kissing, hugging, swimming pools, toilet seats or sharing baths, towels, cups, plates or cutlery. The bacteria cannot survive outside the human body for long.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of gonorrhoea", "text": "Signs and symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Typical\u00a0symptoms of gonorrhoea include a thick green or yellow discharge from the vagina or penis, pain when peeing and, in women, bleeding between periods.

But\u00a0around 1 in 10 infected men and almost half of infected women do not experience any symptoms.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Getting tested", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Getting tested

If you have any of the symptoms of gonorrhoea or you're worried you may have an STI, you should visit a sexual health clinic for a sexual health test.

Find a sexual health clinic.

You can also contact the FPA sexual health helpline on 0345 122 8687.

Gonorrhoea can be easily diagnosed\u00a0by testing a sample of discharge picked up\u00a0using a swab. In men, testing a sample of urine can also diagnose the condition.

It's important to get tested as soon as possible because gonorrhoea can lead to more serious long-term health problems if it's not treated, including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in women or infertility.

Read more about:

  • diagnosing gonorrhoea\u00a0
  • possible complications of gonorrhoea
  • visiting an STI clinic
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating gonorrhoea", "text": "Treating gonorrhoea", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gonorrhoea is usually treated with a single antibiotic injection and a single antibiotic tablet. With effective treatment, most of your symptoms should improve within a few days.

It's usually recommended you attend a follow-up appointment a week or 2 after treatment so another test can be carried out to see if you're clear of infection.

You should avoid having sex until you have been told you no longer have the infection.

Previous successful treatment for gonorrhoea does not make you immune to catching it again.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

Anyone who's sexually active can\u00a0catch gonorrhoea, particularly people who change partners frequently or do not use a barrier method of contraception, such as a condom, when having sex.

Gonorrhoea is the second most common bacterial STI in the UK after chlamydia.

In 2017, more than 44,500 people were diagnosed with gonorrhoea in England, with most cases affecting young men and women under the age of\u00a025.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing gonorrhoea", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing gonorrhoea

Gonorrhoea and other STIs can be successfully prevented by using appropriate contraception and taking other precautions, such as:

  • using\u00a0male condoms or\u00a0female condoms every time you have vaginal sex,\u00a0or male condoms during anal sex
  • using a condom to cover the penis or a latex or plastic square (dam) to cover the female genitals if you have oral sex
  • not sharing sex toys, or washing them and covering them with a new condom before anyone else uses them

If you're worried you may have an STI,\u00a0visit a sexual health clinic for advice.

Find a sexual health clinic.

Get more advice about STIs.

Read about the symptoms, causes and treatments.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-09T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-09T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/", "name": "Gout", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-11T12:28:50+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/#overview", "description": "Gout causes sudden swelling and severe pain in your joints.", "text": "

Symptoms of gout include sudden pain and swelling in a joint, such as your big toe or knees.

An attack of gout can be treated with anti-inflammatories. Regular exercise, being a healthy weight and reducing alcohol can help prevent attacks.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of gout include sudden pain and swelling in a joint, such as your big toe or knees.", "text": "

See a GP if you have:

  • sudden severe pain in a joint \u2013 usually your big toe, but it can be in other joints in your feet, hands, wrists, elbows or knees
  • hot, swollen, red skin over the affected joint

These are symptoms of gout.

An attack of gout usually lasts 5 to 7 days, then gets better. It may not cause lasting damage to joints if you get treatment immediately.

Ask for an urgent GP appointment or call 111 if:

  • the pain is getting worse
  • you also have a very high temperature (you feel hot and shivery)
  • you also feel sick or cannot eat

These symptoms could mean you have an infection inside your joint and need urgent medical help.

", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/#treatments-summary", "description": "An attack of gout can be treated with anti-inflammatories. Regular exercise, being a healthy weight and reducing alcohol can help prevent attacks.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/#treatments-other", "description": "An attack of gout can be treated with anti-inflammatories. Regular exercise, being a healthy weight and reducing alcohol can help prevent attacks.", "text": "

Attacks of gout are usually treated with a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory (NSAID) like ibuprofen.

If the pain and swelling does not improve you may be given steroids as tablets or an injection.


Do

  • take any medicine you've been prescribed as soon as possible \u2013 it should start to work within 2 days

  • rest and raise the limb

  • keep the joint cool \u2013 apply an ice pack, or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a towel, for up to 20 minutes at a time

  • drink lots of water (unless a GP tells you not to)

  • try to keep bedclothes off the affected joint at night


Don't

  • do not put pressure on the joint

Treatment to prevent gout coming back

Gout can come back every few months or it may be years. It can come back more often if it's not treated.

If you have frequent attacks or high levels of uric acid in your blood, you may need to take uric acid-lowering medicine.

Important

It's important to take uric acid-lowering medicine regularly, even when you no longer have symptoms.

", "title": "Treatment to reduce pain and swelling"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/#self-care", "description": "An attack of gout can be treated with anti-inflammatories. Regular exercise, being a healthy weight and reducing alcohol can help prevent attacks.", "text": "

Making lifestyle changes may mean you can stop or reduce further attacks.


Do

  • get to a healthy weight, but avoid crash diets \u2013 try the NHS weight loss plan

  • eat a healthy, balanced diet \u2013 your doctor may give you a list of foods to include or limit

  • have some alcohol-free days each week

  • drink plenty of fluids to avoid getting dehydrated

  • exercise regularly \u2013 but avoid intense exercise or putting lots of pressure on joints

  • stop smoking

  • ask a GP about vitamin C supplements


Don't

  • do not eat offal, such as kidneys or liver, or seafood

  • do not have lots of sugary drinks and snacks

  • do not eat lots of fatty foods

  • do not drink more than 14 units of alcohol a week, and spread your drinking over 3 or more days if you drink as much as 14 units

", "title": "Things you can do to prevent gout coming back"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gout/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gout"}], "keywords": ["Gout"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gout is a type of arthritis that causes sudden, severe joint pain. See a GP for treatment to help during an attack and to stop further attacks.

The GP may ask about your diet and if you drink alcohol.

They may refer you to see a specialist (rheumatologist) and arrange a blood test and scan. Sometimes a thin needle is used to take a sample of fluid from inside the affected joint, to test it.

The blood test will find out how much of a chemical called uric acid there is in your blood.

Having too much uric acid in your blood can lead to crystals forming around your joints, which causes pain.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Things that can trigger a gout attack", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You might get an attack if you:

  • have an illness that causes a high temperature
  • drink too much alcohol or eat a very large, fatty meal
  • get dehydrated
  • injure a joint
  • take certain medicines

Get treatment immediately if you feel an attack starting.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Who gets gout", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gout sometimes runs in families.

It's more common in men, especially as they get older.

You might have a higher chance of getting gout if you:

  • are overweight
  • drink alcohol
  • have been through the menopause
  • take medicines such as diuretics (water tablets), or medicines for high blood pressure (such as ACE inhibitors)
  • have high cholesterol, high blood pressure, kidney problems, osteoarthritis or diabetes
  • have had surgery or an injury
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Complications of gout", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's rare to get lots of attacks (chronic gout), but if you do, it can damage your joint.

Chronic gout can also cause tiny white lumps, called tophi, to appear under your skin, usually on your ears, fingers or elbows.

This is where urate crystals form under your skin. They can be painful.

You can get kidney stones if your uric acid levels are very high, so you'll need treatment to reduce the levels.

Social care and support guide

Read our guide to care and support if you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled (including family members)

"https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/guillain-barre-syndrome/recovery/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Recovery"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Guillain-Barr\u00e9 (pronounced ghee-yan bar-ray) syndrome is a very rare and serious condition that affects the nerves.

It mainly affects the feet, hands and limbs, causing problems such as numbness, weakness and pain.

It can be treated and most people will eventually make a full recovery, although\u00a0it can occasionally be life-threatening and some people are left with long-term problems.

Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome affects people of all ages but it is more common in adults and males.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome

Symptoms often start in your feet and hands before spreading to your arms and legs.

At first you may have:

  • numbness
  • pins and needles
  • muscle weakness
  • pain
  • problems with balance and co-ordination

These symptoms may continue to get worse over the next few days or weeks before they start to\u00a0slowly improve. In severe cases, you may have difficulty moving, walking, breathing and/or swallowing.

Read more about the symptoms of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome.\u00a0

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical help

See a GP if you notice any of the early symptoms of Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome, such as numbness or weakness.

Call 999 for an ambulance\u00a0or go to\u00a0your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department immediately\u00a0if someone:

  • has difficulty breathing, swallowing or speaking
  • cannot move their\u00a0limbs or face

This is a medical emergency and the person needs to be seen in hospital as soon as possible.

Read more about\u00a0how\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome is diagnosed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome

Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome is thought to be caused by a problem with the immune system, the body's natural defence against illness and infection.

Normally the immune system attacks any germs that get into the body. But in people with\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome, something goes wrong and it mistakenly attacks and damages\u00a0the nerves.

It's not clear exactly why this happens, but the condition often happens after an infection; especially an infection of the airways, such as flu, or an infection of the digestive system, such as food poisoning or a stomach bug (gastroenteritis).

Read more about\u00a0causes of\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome

Most people with Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome are treated in hospital.

The main treatments are:

  • intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)\u00a0\u2013 a treatment made from donated blood that helps bring your immune system under control
  • plasma exchange (plasmapheresis)\u00a0\u2013 an alternative to IVIG where a machine is used to filter your blood to remove\u00a0the harmful substances that are attacking your nerves
  • treatments to reduce symptoms such as painkillers
  • treatments to support body functions, such as a machine to help with breathing and/or a feeding tube

Most people need to stay in hospital for a few weeks to a few months.

Read more about how\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome is treated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering\u00a0from\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering\u00a0from\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome

Most people with Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome make a full recovery within a few weeks.

However, around 1 in 5 people are left with long-term problems such as:

  • being unable to walk without assistance
  • weakness in your arms, legs or face
  • numbness, pain or a tingling or burning sensation
  • balance and co-ordination problems
  • extreme tiredness

Therapies such as\u00a0physiotherapy,\u00a0occupational therapy and speech and language therapy may help you recover and cope with any lasting difficulties.

In a minority of cases,\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome can cause life-threatening problems such as severe breathing difficulties or blood clots. Overall, around 1 in 20 cases are fatal.

Read more about recovering from\u00a0Guillain-Barr\u00e9 syndrome.

Gum disease:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Gum disease", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Gum disease", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Gum disease is a very common condition where the gums become swollen, sore or infected.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-02-19T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-02-19T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/", "name": "Gum disease", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:14:28+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/#overview", "description": "Gum disease is where your gums are red and swollen.", "text": "

Gum disease is caused by a build-up of a sticky substance called plaque on your teeth. This can happen if you do not brush your teeth regularly.

Brushing your teeth twice a day and flossing regularly can help gum disease. A dental hygienist may need to thoroughly clean your teeth.

Symptoms of gum disease include bleeding gums, swollen gums and bad breath.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/#causes", "description": "Gum disease is caused by a build-up of a sticky substance called plaque on your teeth. This can happen if you do not brush your teeth regularly.", "text": "

Gum disease is caused by a build-up of plaque on the teeth. Plaque is a sticky substance that contains bacteria.

Some bacteria in plaque\u00a0are harmless, but some are harmful for the health of your gums.

If you do not remove plaque from your teeth by brushing them, it\u00a0builds up and irritates your gums.

This can lead to redness with bleeding, swelling and soreness.

", "title": "What causes gum disease?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/#treatments-summary", "description": "Brushing your teeth twice a day and flossing regularly can help gum disease. A dental hygienist may need to thoroughly clean your teeth.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/#treatments-other", "description": "Brushing your teeth twice a day and flossing regularly can help gum disease. A dental hygienist may need to thoroughly clean your teeth.", "text": "

Mild cases of gum disease can usually be treated by maintaining a good level of oral hygiene.

This includes brushing your teeth at least twice a day and flossing regularly.

You should also make sure you go for regular dental check-ups.

In most cases, your dentist or dental hygienist will be able to give your teeth a thorough clean and remove any hardened plaque (tartar).

They'll also be able to show you how to clean your teeth effectively to help prevent plaque building up in the future.

If you have severe gum disease, you'll\u00a0usually need to have further medical and dental treatment.

In some cases, surgery may need to be carried out.\u00a0This will usually be performed by a specialist in gum\u00a0problems (periodontics).

", "title": "Preventing and treating gum disease"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/symptoms/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of gum disease include bleeding gums, swollen gums and bad breath.", "text": "

Gum disease is not always painful and you may be unaware you have it.

The initial symptoms of gum disease can include:

  • red and swollen gums
  • bleeding gums after brushing or flossing your teeth

This stage of gum disease is called gingivitis.

Advanced symptoms

If gingivitis is untreated, the tissues and bone that support the teeth can also become affected. This is known as periodontitis, or periodontal disease.

Symptoms of periodontitis can include:

  • bad breath (halitosis)
  • an\u00a0unpleasant\u00a0taste in your mouth
  • loose teeth that can make eating difficult
  • collections of pus that\u00a0develop under your gums or\u00a0teeth (gum abscesses)
", "title": "Early symptoms of gum disease"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Gum disease", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/gum-disease/complications/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Immune system", "Gingivitis and periodontitis"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gum disease\u00a0is a very common condition where the gums become swollen,\u00a0sore or\u00a0infected.

Most adults in the\u00a0UK have gum disease to some degree, and\u00a0most people experience it at least once. It's much less common in children.

If you have gum disease, your\u00a0gums may bleed when\u00a0you brush your teeth and you may have bad breath. This early stage of gum disease is known as gingivitis.

If gingivitis is not treated, a condition called periodontitis can develop. This affects the tissues that support teeth and\u00a0hold them in place.

If\u00a0periodontitis\u00a0is not treated, the bone in your jaw\u00a0may be damaged and small spaces can open up\u00a0between the gum and teeth.\u00a0

Your teeth can become loose and may eventually fall out.

Find out more about the symptoms of gum disease

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes gum disease?", "text": "What causes gum disease?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Gum disease is caused by a build-up of plaque on the teeth. Plaque is a sticky substance that contains bacteria.

Some bacteria in plaque\u00a0are harmless, but some are harmful for the health of your gums.

If you do not remove plaque from your teeth by brushing them, it\u00a0builds up and irritates your gums.

This can lead to redness with bleeding, swelling and soreness.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Seeing your dentist", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Seeing your dentist

You should make an appointment to see your dentist if your gums are painful,\u00a0swollen,\u00a0or bleed when you brush your teeth.

Find a dentist near you

Your dentist\u00a0can carry out a thorough dental examination to check the health of your gums, which may involve inserting a thin\u00a0metal stick with a bend in 1 end\u00a0(periodontal probe) beside your teeth.

In some cases, a number of X-rays may be needed to check the condition of your teeth and jaw bone.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing and treating gum disease", "text": "Preventing and treating gum disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mild cases of gum disease can usually be treated by maintaining a good level of oral hygiene.

This includes brushing your teeth at least twice a day and flossing regularly.

You should also make sure you go for regular dental check-ups.

In most cases, your dentist or dental hygienist will be able to give your teeth a thorough clean and remove any hardened plaque (tartar).

They'll also be able to show you how to clean your teeth effectively to help prevent plaque building up in the future.

If you have severe gum disease, you'll\u00a0usually need to have further medical and dental treatment.

In some cases, surgery may need to be carried out.\u00a0This will usually be performed by a specialist in gum\u00a0problems (periodontics).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Dental check-ups", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Dental check-ups

It's important\u00a0to have regular dental\u00a0check-ups so any problems with your teeth and gums can be detected and treated early.

If you have never had gum disease and have good oral health, you may only need to visit your dentist every 1 to 2\u00a0years for a check-up.

You may need to visit your dentist more frequently if you have had problems with gum disease in the past.

At each appointment your dentist will advise when you need your next appointment.

If you have an increased risk of developing gum problems\u00a0(for example, you smoke or have diabetes), you may be advised to visit your dentist more often so your teeth and gums can be closely monitored.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of gum disease", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of gum disease

If you have untreated gum disease that develops into periodontitis, it can lead to further complications.

These include:

  • painful collections of pus (gum abscesses)
  • receding gums
  • loose teeth
  • loss of teeth

Find out more about the complications of gum disease

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "NHS dentists", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

NHS dentists

Everyone should be able to access good-quality NHS dental services. There's no need to register with a dentist.

Simply find a practice that's convenient for you, whether it's near home or work, and phone to see if any appointments are available.

Find out more about how to find an NHS\u00a0dentist

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
