Early signs of a low blood sugar level include:

  • sweating
  • feeling tired
  • dizziness
  • feeling hungry
  • tingling lips
  • feeling shaky or trembling
  • a fast or pounding heartbeat (palpitations)
  • becoming easily irritated, tearful, anxious or moody
  • turning pale

If a low blood sugar level is not treated, you may get other symptoms, such as:

  • weakness
  • blurred vision
  • confusion or difficulty concentrating
  • unusual behaviour, slurred speech or clumsiness (like being drunk)
  • feeling sleepy
  • seizures or fits
  • collapsing or passing out

A low blood sugar level, or hypo, can also happen while you're sleeping. This may cause you to wake up during the night or cause\u00a0headaches, tiredness or damp sheets (from sweat) in the morning.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to treat a low blood sugar level yourself", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Follow these steps if your blood sugar level is less than 4mmol/L or you have hypo symptoms:

  1. Have a sugary drink or snack \u2013\u00a0like a small glass of fizzy drink (not a diet variety) or fruit juice, a small handful of sweets, 3 or 6\u00a0glucose tablets or 1 to 2 tubes of glucose gel.
  2. Test your blood sugar after 10 to 15 minutes \u2013\u00a0if it's improved and you feel better, move on to step 3. If there's little or no change, treat again with a sugary drink or snack and take another reading after 10 to 15 minutes.
  3. You may need to eat your main meal (containing a slow-release carbohydrate) if it's the right time to have it. Or, have a snack that contains a slow-release carbohydrate, such as a\u00a0slice of bread or toast, a couple of biscuits, or a glass of cows' milk.

You do not usually need to get medical help once you're feeling better if you only have a few hypos.

But tell your diabetes team if you keep having hypos or if you stop having symptoms when your blood sugar level is low.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to treat someone who's unconscious\u00a0or very sleepy (drowsy)", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Follow these steps:

  1. Put the person in the recovery position and do not put anything in their mouth \u2013\u00a0so\u00a0they do not choke.
  2. Call 999 for an ambulance if an injection of glucagon is not available, you do not know how to use it, or the person had alcohol before their hypo.
  3. If an injection of glucagon is available and you know how to use it, give it to them immediately.
  4. If they wake up within 10 minutes of getting the injection and feel better, move on to step 5. If they do not improve within 10 minutes, call 999 for an ambulance.
  5. If they're fully awake and able to eat and drink safely, give them a carbohydrate snack.

They may need to go to hospital if they're being sick (vomiting), or their blood sugar level drops again.

Tell your diabetes care team if you ever have a severe hypo that caused you to lose consciousness.

How to treat someone who's having a seizure or fit

Follow these steps if someone has a seizure or fit caused by a low blood sugar level:

  1. Stay with them and stop them hurting themselves \u2013 lie them down on something soft and move them away from anything dangerous (like a road or hot radiator).
  2. Call 999 for an ambulance if the seizure or fit lasts more than 5 minutes.
  3. After the seizure or fit stops, give them a sugary snack.

Tell your diabetes care team if you ever have a severe hypo that caused you to have a seizure or fit.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes\u00a0a low blood sugar level", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

In people with diabetes, the main causes of a low blood sugar level are:

  • the effects of medicine \u2013 especially taking too much insulin, medicines called sulfonylureas (such as glibenclamide and gliclazide), medicines called glinides (such as repaglinide and nateglinide), or some antiviral medicines to treat hepatitis C
  • skipping or delaying a meal
  • not eating enough carbohydrate foods in your last meal, such as bread, cereals, pasta, potatoes and fruit
  • exercise, especially if it's intense or unplanned
  • drinking alcohol

Sometimes there's no obvious reason why a low blood sugar level happens.

Very occasionally, it can happen in people who do not have diabetes.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing\u00a0a low blood sugar level", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have diabetes, you can reduce your chance of getting a low blood sugar level if you:

  • Check your blood sugar level regularly and be aware of the\u00a0symptoms of a\u00a0low blood sugar level so you can treat it quickly.
  • Always carry a sugary snack or drink with you, such as glucose tablets, a carton of fruit juice or some sweets. If you have a glucagon injection kit, always keep it with you.
  • Do not skip meals.
  • Be careful when drinking\u00a0alcohol. Do not drink large amounts, check your blood sugar level regularly, and eat a carbohydrate snack afterwards.
  • Be careful when exercising; eating a carbohydrate snack before exercise can help to reduce the risk of a hypo. If you take some types of diabetes medicine, your doctor may recommend you take a lower dose before or after doing intense exercise.
  • Have a carbohydrate snack,\u00a0such as toast,\u00a0if your blood sugar level drops too low while you're asleep (nocturnal hypoglycaemia)

If you keep getting a low blood sugar level, talk to your diabetes care team about things you can do to help prevent it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "A low\u00a0blood sugar level without diabetes", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A low blood sugar level is uncommon in people who do not have diabetes.

Possible causes include:

  • your body releasing too much insulin after eating, (called reactive hypoglycaemia or postprandial hypoglycaemia)
  • not eating (fasting) or malnutrition
  • a complication of pregnancy
  • a gastric bypass (a type of weight loss surgery)
  • other medical conditions, such as problems with your hormone levels, pancreas, liver, kidneys, adrenal glands or heart
  • some\u00a0medicines, including quinine (taken for malaria)

See a GP if you think you keep\u00a0getting symptoms of a low blood sugar level. They can arrange some simple tests to check if your blood sugar level is low and try to find out what's causing it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "A low blood sugar level and driving", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You may still be allowed to drive if you have diabetes or you're at risk of a low blood sugar level for another reason, but you'll need to do things to reduce the chance of this happening while you're driving.

You also need to tell the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) and your car insurance company about your condition.

For more information, see:

  • Diabetes UK:\u00a0driving and diabetes
  • Diabetes.co.uk:\u00a0driving and hypoglycaemia
  • GOV.UK:\u00a0hypoglycaemia and driving
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Mitral valve problems:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Mitral valve problems", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Mitral valve problems", "alternateName": ["Heart valve problems"]}, "description": "Find out about the problems that can affect the heart's mitral valve, including prolapse, regurgitation and stenosis. Also, read about the different types of mitral valve surgery.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/mitral-valve-problems/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-14T01:00:00+00:00", "2023-10-14T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/mitral-valve-problems/", "name": "Mitral valve problems", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-23T17:33:24+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/mitral-valve-problems/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Mitral valve problems"}], "keywords": ["Surgery", "Blood", "Mitral valve disease", "Rheumatic heart disease", "Heart specialists", "Heart", "Congestive heart failure", "Heart failure"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The mitral valve is a small flap in the heart that stops blood flowing the wrong way.\u00a0Problems with it can affect how blood flows around the body.

The main problems that affect the mitral valve are:

  • mitral valve prolapse\u00a0\u2013 the valve becomes too floppy
  • mitral regurgitation\u00a0\u2013\u00a0the valve leaks and blood flows the wrong way
  • mitral stenosis\u00a0\u2013 the valve does not open as wide as it should

These conditions can be serious, but they're often treatable.

In some cases, mitral valve surgery may be needed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Mitral\u00a0valve prolapse", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mitral\u00a0valve prolapse

Mitral valve prolapse is where the mitral valve is too floppy and does not close tightly.

Symptoms

Many people with a mitral valve prolapse do not have symptoms and it may only be spotted during a heart scan (echocardiogram) carried out for another reason.

Mitral valve prolapse can sometimes cause:

  • dizziness
  • breathlessness
  • tiredness
  • an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia) or noticeable heartbeats (palpitations)
  • mitral regurgitation

Treatment

You probably will not need treatment if you do not have any symptoms.

Your doctor may suggest:

  • making lifestyle changes, such as giving up smoking, caffeine and alcohol \u2013\u00a0these things can make your heart work too hard
  • having regular check-ups to monitor your condition

If you have symptoms or your mitral valve is very floppy, your doctor may recommend:

  • medicine\u00a0to\u00a0relieve your symptoms, such as\u00a0beta blockers for an irregular heartbeat
  • mitral valve surgery to repair or replace the mitral valve

Causes

Mitral valve prolapse is usually caused by problems with the tissues that join the mitral valve to the heart muscles.

Some people with the condition are born with it, and it's more common in people with connective tissue disorders, such as Marfan syndrome.

Rarely, it can be caused by damage to the heart muscles themselves \u2013 for example, as the result of a heart attack.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Mitral\u00a0regurgitation", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mitral\u00a0regurgitation

Mitral regurgitation is where some blood flows the wrong way in the heart because the mitral valve does not close properly.

Symptoms

Mitral valve regurgitation does not always\u00a0have symptoms.

Sometimes it can cause:

  • dizziness
  • breathlessness
  • tiredness
  • chest pain

If not treated, it\u00a0can lead to:

  • atrial fibrillation\u00a0\u2013 an irregular and fast heartbeat
  • pulmonary hypertension\u00a0\u2013 high blood pressure in the blood vessels that supply the lungs
  • heart failure\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where the heart cannot pump enough blood around the body

Treatment

You might not need treatment if you do not have any symptoms. Your doctor may just suggest having regular check-ups to monitor your condition.

If\u00a0you have symptoms or the problem with your valve is serious, your doctor may recommend:

  • medicines\u00a0to\u00a0relieve your symptoms \u2013 such as diuretics to reduce breathlessness and medicines for atrial fibrillation
  • open heart surgery\u00a0\u2013 to repair or replace the mitral valve
  • keyhole surgery \u2013 a small clip is attached to the mitral valve to help it close; the clip is guided into the heart through a thin tube inserted into a vein in the groin

Causes

Mitral regurgitation happens if the mitral valve cannot close properly.

This is usually caused by either:

  • the mitral valve becoming too floppy\u00a0(mitral valve prolapse)
  • the ring of muscle around the valve becoming too wide

These problems often develop with age\u00a0\u2013 for example, because of\u00a0"wear and tear"\u00a0over time or damage caused by\u00a0untreated high blood pressure.

Mitral regurgitation\u00a0can sometimes be\u00a0caused by a\u00a0problem such as:

  • cardiomyopathy\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where the walls of the heart become stretched, thickened or stiff
  • endocarditis\u00a0\u2013 infection of the inner lining of the heart
  • congenital heart disease\u00a0\u2013 birth defects affecting the heart
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Mitral\u00a0stenosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mitral\u00a0stenosis

Mitral valve stenosis is where the mitral valve does not open as wide as it should, restricting the flow of blood through the heart.

Symptoms

Mitral valve stenosis may not\u00a0have any symptoms.

Sometimes it can cause:

  • dizziness
  • breathlessness
  • tiredness
  • noticeable heartbeats (palpitations)
  • chest pain

If not treated, it\u00a0can lead to:

  • atrial fibrillation\u00a0\u2013 an irregular and fast heartbeat
  • pulmonary hypertension\u00a0\u2013 high blood pressure in the blood vessels that supply the lungs
  • heart failure\u00a0\u2013 where the heart\u00a0cannot pump blood around the body properly

Treatment

You might not need treatment if you do not have any symptoms. Your doctor may just suggest having regular check-ups to monitor your condition.

If\u00a0you have symptoms or\u00a0the problem with your valve is serious, your doctor may recommend:

  • medicine\u00a0to\u00a0relieve your symptoms \u2013 such as\u00a0medicines called diuretics to reduce breathlessness and medicines for atrial fibrillation
  • mitral valve surgery\u00a0\u2013 to replace the valve or a procedure to stretch it with a small balloon\u00a0(balloon valvuloplasty)

Causes

One of the main causes of mitral valve stenosis is\u00a0rheumatic heart disease.

This is where an infection causes the heart to become inflamed. Over time, it can cause the flaps of the mitral valve to become\u00a0hard and thick.

Other causes include hard deposits\u00a0that form\u00a0around the valve with age,\u00a0or\u00a0a problem with the heart from birth (congenital heart disease).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Mitral\u00a0valve surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Mitral\u00a0valve surgery

Mitral valve surgery may be recommended if you have symptoms caused by a problem with your mitral valve or\u00a0if\u00a0the problem is quite serious.

The most common\u00a0mitral valve procedures are:

  • mitral valve repair
  • mitral valve replacement
  • balloon valvuloplasty\u00a0\u2013 where the mitral valve is stretched with a small balloon

Mitral\u00a0valve repair

Mitral valve repair is an operation to make the flaps of the mitral valve stay closer together. This will help stop blood flowing the wrong way through the valve.

It's\u00a0mainly used to treat mitral valve prolapse or regurgitation, if the problem is serious and causing symptoms.

The operation is carried out under\u00a0general anaesthetic, where you're asleep.\u00a0

Your surgeon will usually get to your heart through a single cut along the middle of your chest, but\u00a0smaller cuts between your ribs are sometimes\u00a0used.

The flaps of the mitral valve are then partially sewn together.

The operation may be done as keyhole surgery, where a small clip is attached to the mitral valve to help it close.

Most people experience a significant improvement in their symptoms after surgery, but speak to your surgeon about the possible complications.

Mitral\u00a0valve replacement

Mitral valve replacement is an operation to\u00a0replace\u00a0your mitral valve with a mechanical valve\u00a0or a valve\u00a0made from animal tissue (a bioprosthetic valve).

This is usually only\u00a0done if you have\u00a0mitral stenosis or mitral prolapse or regurgitation and are unable to have a valve repair.

The operation is carried out under\u00a0general anaesthetic, where you're asleep.\u00a0Your surgeon will usually replace the valve through a single cut along the middle of your chest.

Most people experience a significant improvement in their symptoms after surgery, but speak to your surgeon about the possible complications. The risk of serious problems is generally higher than with mitral valve repair.

You'll also need to take medicine to prevent blood clots for a long time after this operation. If you have a mechanical valve, you'll need to take this medicine for life.

Balloon\u00a0valvuloplasty

Balloon valvuloplasty, also\u00a0called percutaneous mitral commissurotomy, is a procedure that can be used to widen the mitral valve if you have mitral stenosis.

It's usually done using local anaesthetic, where you remain awake but your skin is numbed.

A small cut is made in your groin or neck and a thin tube is passed along a\u00a0blood vessel to your heart.

The end of the\u00a0catheter has a small balloon attached to it. This is inflated inside the narrowed valve to stretch it wider. The balloon is then deflated and removed along with the catheter.

This procedure is generally less effective than replacing the mitral valve, but recovery tends to be quicker and it may be a better option if your valve is not too narrow or you're at an increased risk of surgery complications (for example, if you're pregnant or frail).

Neonatal herpes (herpes in a baby):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Neonatal herpes (herpes in a baby)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Neonatal herpes (herpes in a baby)", "alternateName": ["Herpes in babies"]}, "description": "Information on neonatal herpes (herpes in newborn babies), with links to other useful resources.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/neonatal-herpes/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-07-27T14:06:00+00:00", "2021-07-27T14:06:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/neonatal-herpes/", "name": "Neonatal herpes (herpes in a baby)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-03T11:06:30+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/neonatal-herpes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Neonatal herpes (herpes in a baby)"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Neonatal herpes is a herpes infection in a young baby. The younger the baby, the more vulnerable they are to the harmful effects of infection. It's caused by the herpes simplex virus, a highly contagious virus that can cause cold sores and genital ulcers in adults.

Herpes can be very serious for a young baby,\u00a0whose immune system will not have fully developed to fight off the virus.

Neonatal herpes is rare in the UK and\u00a0can be prevented by following some simple advice.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How does\u00a0a newborn baby catch herpes?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How does\u00a0a newborn baby catch herpes?

During pregnancy and labour

A newborn baby\u00a0is at risk of catching herpes if\u00a0the mother had genital herpes\u00a0for the first time within the last 6 weeks of her pregnancy.

There's a risk the mother will have passed the infection on to her baby if she had a vaginal delivery.\u00a0

This risk is much lower if the mother has had genital herpes before.

After birth

The herpes simplex virus can be passed to a baby through a cold sore if a person has a cold sore and kisses the baby.

The herpes virus can also be spread to the baby if a mother has a blister caused by herpes on her breast and she feeds the baby with the affected breast or expressed breast milk from the affected breast.

A baby is most at risk of getting a herpes infection in the first 4 weeks after birth.

You should not kiss a baby if you have a cold sore to reduce the risk of spreading infection.

Cold sores and other blisters caused by the herpes virus are at their most contagious when they burst. They remain contagious until completely healed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What are the warning signs in babies?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What are the warning signs in babies?

Because newborn babies have underdeveloped immune systems, they can quickly become seriously ill after catching the virus.

Call a GP or your health visitor straight away if your baby:

  • is lethargic or irritable
  • is not feeding
  • has a high temperature (fever)\u00a0\u2013 find out how to take your baby's temperature
  • has a rash or sores on the skin, eyes and inside the mouth

These are early warning signs that your baby may be unwell.

Call 999 immediately if your baby:

  • is lacking in energy (listless)
  • is becoming floppy and unresponsive
  • is difficult to wake up from sleep
  • has breathing difficulties or starts grunting
  • breathes rapidly
  • has a blue tongue and skin (cyanosis)

Very often the baby will not have any specific herpes symptoms, such as a rash.

But they can become unwell very quickly, so you need to act fast.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How is neonatal herpes treated?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How is neonatal herpes treated?

Neonatal herpes is usually treated with antiviral drugs\u00a0given directly into the baby's\u00a0vein (intravenously).\u00a0

This treatment may be needed for several weeks.

Any related complications, such as fits (seizures), will also need to be treated.

The baby can be breastfed while receiving treatment, unless the mother has herpes sores around her nipples.

If the mother is taking antiviral treatment too, this can be\u00a0excreted in her breast milk, but is not thought to cause any harm to the baby.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How serious is herpes for a baby?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How serious is herpes for a baby?

Sometimes neonatal herpes will only affect the baby's eyes, mouth or skin.

In these cases, most babies will make a complete recovery with antiviral treatment.

But the condition is much more serious if it's spread to the baby's organs.

Nearly a third of infants with this type of neonatal herpes will die, even after they have been treated.\u00a0

If widespread herpes is not\u00a0treated immediately, there's a high chance the baby will die.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How can neonatal herpes be prevented?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How can neonatal herpes be prevented?

If you're pregnant and have a history of genital herpes, tell your doctor or midwife.\u00a0

You may need to take medication during the\u00a0last month of pregnancy to prevent an outbreak of vaginal sores during labour.

Delivery by\u00a0caesarean section is recommended if the genital herpes has occurred for the first time in the last 6 weeks of your pregnancy.

If you develop\u00a0a cold sore or have any signs of a herpes\u00a0infection, take these precautions:

  • do not kiss any babies
  • wash your hands before contact with a baby
  • wash your hands before breastfeeding
  • cover up any cold sores, lesions or signs of a herpes infection anywhere on your body to avoid passing on the virus
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Support and advice if you have been affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Support and advice if you have been affected

You may find these resources helpful:

  • cold sores
  • genital herpes
  • Sands
  • World Health Organization (WHO):\u00a0herpes simplex virus
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Tension-type headaches:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Tension-type headaches", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Tension-type headaches", "alternateName": ["Headaches (tension-type)"]}, "description": "A tension-type headache is the most common type of headache and the one we think of as a normal, everyday headache.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-07-16T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-07-16T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/", "name": "Tension-type headaches", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-17T10:21:59+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/#overview", "description": "A tension-type headache is the most common type of headache.", "text": "

The main symptom of a tension-type headache is pain on both sides of your head. Your neck may also ache.

Tension-type headaches can be triggered by things like stress, tiredness, dehydration and loud noises.

Tension-type headaches are usually treated with painkillers. Putting a cool flannel on your forehead or a warm flannel on your neck may help.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/#symptoms", "description": "The main symptom of a tension-type headache is pain on both sides of your head. Your neck may also ache.", "text": "

It may feel like a constant ache that affects both sides of the head. You may also feel the neck muscles tighten and a feeling of pressure behind the eyes.

A tension headache normally is not severe enough to prevent you doing everyday activities.

It usually lasts for 30 minutes to several hours, but can last for several days.

", "title": "Symptoms of tension-type headaches"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/#causes", "description": "Tension-type headaches can be triggered by things like stress, tiredness, dehydration and loud noises.", "text": "

The exact cause of tension-type headaches is not clear, but certain things have been known to trigger them.

These include:

  • stress and anxiety
  • squinting
  • poor posture
  • tiredness
  • dehydration
  • missing meals
  • lack of physical activity
  • bright sunlight
  • noise
  • certain smells

Tension-type headaches are known as primary headaches, which means they're not caused by an underlying condition.\u00a0

Other primary headaches include\u00a0cluster headaches and migraines.

", "title": "What causes tension headaches?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/#treatments-summary", "description": "Tension-type headaches are usually treated with painkillers. Putting a cool flannel on your forehead or a warm flannel on your neck may help.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/#self-care", "description": "Tension-type headaches are usually treated with painkillers. Putting a cool flannel on your forehead or a warm flannel on your neck may help.", "text": "

Tension-type headaches are not life threatening and are usually relieved by painkillers or lifestyle changes.

Lifestyle changes

Relaxation techniques can often help with stress-related headaches.

This may include:

  • yoga
  • massage
  • exercise
  • applying a cool flannel to your forehead or a warm flannel to the back of your neck

Painkillers

Painkillers such as\u00a0paracetamol or\u00a0ibuprofen can be used to help relieve pain.\u00a0Aspirin\u00a0may also sometimes be recommended.

If you're taking these medicines, you should always follow the instructions on the packet.

Paracetamol is usually the best choice if you're pregnant. Do not take ibuprofen during pregnancy without speaking to a GP, midwife or pharmacist first.

Children under 16 should not be given aspirin.

Medicine should not be taken for more than a few days at a time.

Medicines containing codeine, such as co-codamol, should be avoided unless recommended by a GP.

", "title": "How\u00a0are tension headaches\u00a0treated?"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/tension-headaches/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Tension-type headaches"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A tension-type headache is the most common type of headache and the one we think of as a normal everyday headache.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of tension-type headaches", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It may feel like a constant ache that affects both sides of the head. You may also feel the neck muscles tighten and a feeling of pressure behind the eyes.

A tension headache normally is not severe enough to prevent you doing everyday activities.

It usually lasts for 30 minutes to several hours, but can last for several days.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who gets tension headaches?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who gets tension headaches?

Most people are likely to have experienced a tension headache at some point.

They can develop at any age, but are more common in teenagers and adults.

Women tend to suffer from them more commonly than men.

Some adults experience tension-type headaches more than 15 times a month for at least 3 months in a row.

This is known as having chronic tension-type headaches.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to seek medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to seek medical help

There's usually no need to see a GP if you only get occasional headaches.

But see a GP if you get headaches several times a week or they're severe.

They'll ask questions about your headaches, family history, diet and lifestyle to help diagnose the type of headache you have.

You should seek immediate\u00a0medical advice\u00a0for headaches that:

  • come on suddenly and are unlike anything you have had before
  • are accompanied by a very stiff neck, fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion
  • follow an accident, especially if it involved a blow to your head
  • are accompanied by weakness, numbness, slurred speech or confusion

These symptoms suggest there could be\u00a0a more serious problem, which may require further investigation\u00a0and emergency treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes tension headaches?", "text": "What causes tension headaches?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The exact cause of tension-type headaches is not clear, but certain things have been known to trigger them.

These include:

  • stress and anxiety
  • squinting
  • poor posture
  • tiredness
  • dehydration
  • missing meals
  • lack of physical activity
  • bright sunlight
  • noise
  • certain smells

Tension-type headaches are known as primary headaches, which means they're not caused by an underlying condition.\u00a0

Other primary headaches include\u00a0cluster headaches and migraines.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How\u00a0are tension headaches\u00a0treated?", "text": "How\u00a0are tension headaches\u00a0treated?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tension-type headaches are not life threatening and are usually relieved by painkillers or lifestyle changes.

Lifestyle changes

Relaxation techniques can often help with stress-related headaches.

This may include:

  • yoga
  • massage
  • exercise
  • applying a cool flannel to your forehead or a warm flannel to the back of your neck

Painkillers

Painkillers such as\u00a0paracetamol or\u00a0ibuprofen can be used to help relieve pain.\u00a0Aspirin\u00a0may also sometimes be recommended.

If you're taking these medicines, you should always follow the instructions on the packet.

Paracetamol is usually the best choice if you're pregnant. Do not take ibuprofen during pregnancy without speaking to a GP, midwife or pharmacist first.

Children under 16 should not be given aspirin.

Medicine should not be taken for more than a few days at a time.

Medicines containing codeine, such as co-codamol, should be avoided unless recommended by a GP.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Painkiller headaches

Taking painkillers over a long period (usually 10 days or more) may lead to medicine-overuse headaches developing.

Your body can get used to the medicine and a headache can develop if you stop taking them.\u00a0

If a GP\u00a0suspects your headache is caused by the persistent use of medicines, they may ask you to stop taking it.

But you should not stop taking your medicine without first consulting a GP.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing\u00a0tension headaches", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing\u00a0tension headaches

If you experience frequent tension-type headaches, you may wish to keep a diary to try to identify what could be triggering them.

It may then be possible to alter your diet or lifestyle to prevent them occurring as often.

Regular exercise and relaxation are also important measures to help reduce stress and tension that may be causing headaches.

Maintaining good posture and ensuring you're well rested and hydrated can also help.

Guidelines from the\u00a0National Institute\u00a0for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) state that a course of up to 10 sessions of\u00a0acupuncture\u00a0over a 5- to 8-week period may be beneficial in preventing chronic tension-type headaches.

In some cases, an antidepressant medication called amitriptyline may be prescribed to help prevent chronic tension-type headaches, although there's limited evidence of\u00a0its effectiveness.

This medicine does not treat a headache instantly, but\u00a0must be taken daily for several months\u00a0until the headaches lessen.

"name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/antiphospholipid-syndrome/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/antiphospholipid-syndrome/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": signs", "Deep vein thrombosis", "Thrombosis", "Immune system"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), sometimes known as Hughes syndrome, is a disorder of the immune system that causes an increased risk of blood clots.

This means people with APS are at greater risk of developing conditions such as:

  • deep vein thrombosis (DVT), a blood clot that usually develops in the leg
  • arterial thrombosis (a clot in an artery), which can cause a stroke or heart attack
  • blood clots in the brain, leading to problems with balance, mobility, vision, speech and memory

Pregnant women with APS also have an increased risk of having a miscarriage, although the exact reasons for this are uncertain.

APS doesn't always cause noticeable problems, but some people have general symptoms that can be similar to those of multiple sclerosis (a common condition affecting the central nervous system).

Find out more about signs and symptoms of APS

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What causes antiphospholipid syndrome?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What causes antiphospholipid syndrome?

APS is an autoimmune condition. This means the immune system, which usually protects the body from infection and illness, attacks healthy tissue by mistake.

In APS, the immune system produces abnormal antibodies called antiphospholipid antibodies.

These target proteins attached to fat molecules (phospholipids), which makes the blood more likely to clot.

It's not known what causes the immune system to produce abnormal antibodies.

As with other autoimmune conditions, genetic, hormonal and environmental factors are thought to play a part.

Find out more about the causes of APS

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Who's affected", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Who's affected

APS can affect people of all ages, including children and babies.

But most people are diagnosed with APS between 20 and 50 years of age, and it affects 3 to 5 times as many women as men.

It's not clear how many people in the UK have the condition.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Diagnosing APS", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Diagnosing APS

Diagnosing APS can sometimes be tricky, as some of the symptoms are similar to multiple sclerosis.

This means blood tests to identify the antibodies responsible for APS are essential in diagnosing the condition.

Find out more about diagnosing APS

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How antiphospholipid syndrome is treated", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How antiphospholipid syndrome is treated

Although there's no cure for APS, the risk of developing blood clots can be greatly reduced if it's correctly diagnosed.

An anticoagulant medicine, such as warfarin, or an antiplatelet, such as low-dose aspirin, is usually prescribed.

These reduce the likelihood of unnecessary blood clots forming, but still allow clots to form when you cut yourself.

Treatment with these medications can also improve a pregnant woman's chance of having a successful pregnancy.

With treatment, it's estimated there's about an 80% chance of having a successful pregnancy.

Most people respond well to treatment and can lead normal, healthy lives.

But a small number of people with APS continue to experience blood clots despite extensive treatment.

Find out more about treating APS

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome

In very rare cases, blood clots can suddenly form throughout the body, resulting in multiple organ failure. This is known as catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome (CAPS).

CAPS requires immediate emergency treatment in hospital with high-dose anticoagulants.

Find out more about catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome (CAPS)

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

replacement", "Heart"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

An aortic valve replacement is a type of open heart surgery used to treat problems with the heart's aortic valve.

The aortic valve controls the flow of blood out from the heart to the rest of the body.

An aortic valve replacement involves removing a faulty or damaged valve and replacing it with a new valve made from synthetic materials or animal tissue.

It's a major operation that isn't suitable for everyone and can take a long time to recover from.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When is it necessary to replace the aortic valve?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When is it necessary to replace the aortic valve?

The aortic valve may need to be replaced for 2 reasons:

  • the valve has become narrowed (aortic stenosis) – the opening of the valve becomes smaller, obstructing the flow of blood out of the heart
  • the valve is leaky (aortic regurgitation) – the valve allows blood to flow back through into the heart

The problems can get worse over time and in severe cases can lead to life-threatening problems such as heart failure if left untreated.

There are no medicines to treat aortic valve problems, so replacing the valve will be recommended if you're at risk of serious complications but are otherwise well enough to have surgery. 

Find out more about why aortic valve replacements are carried out

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How is an aortic valve replacement carried out?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How is an aortic valve replacement carried out?

An aortic valve replacement is carried out under general anaesthetic.

This means you'll be asleep during the operation and won't feel any pain while it's carried out.

During the procedure:

  • a large cut (incision) about 25cm long is made in your chest to access your heart – although sometimes a smaller cut may be made
  • your heart is stopped and a heart-lung (bypass) machine is used to take over the job of your heart during the operation
  • the damaged or faulty valve is removed and replaced with the new one
  • your heart is restarted and the opening in your chest is closed

The operation usually takes a few hours. You'll have a discussion with your doctor or surgeon before the procedure to decide whether a synthetic or animal tissue replacement valve is most suitable for you.

Find out what happens during an aortic valve replacement

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Recovering from an aortic valve replacement", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from an aortic valve replacement

You'll usually need to stay in hospital for about a week after an aortic valve replacement, although it may be 2 to 3 months before you fully recover.

You should take things easy when you first get home, but you can start to gradually return to your normal activities over the next few weeks.

You'll be given specific advice about any side effects you can expect while you recover and any activities you should avoid.

You won't usually be able to drive for around 4 to 6 weeks and you'll probably need 6 to 12 weeks off work, depending on your job.

Read more about recovering from an aortic valve replacement.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Risks of an aortic valve replacement", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks of an aortic valve replacement

An aortic valve replacement is a big operation and, like any type of surgery, carries a risk of complications.

Some of the main risks of an aortic valve replacement include:

  • wound, lung, bladder or heart valve infections
  • blood clots
  • strokes
  • a temporarily irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia)
  • reduced kidney function for a few days

The risk of dying from an aortic valve replacement is around 1 to 3%, although this risk is much smaller than that of leaving severe aortic valve problems untreated.

Most people who survive surgery have a life expectancy close to normal.

Read more about the risks of aortic valve replacement.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Alternatives to an aortic valve replacement", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Alternatives to an aortic valve replacement

An aortic valve replacement is the most effective treatment for aortic valve conditions. 

Alternative procedures are usually only used if open heart surgery is too risky.

Possible alternatives include:

  • transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) – the replacement valve is guided into place through the blood vessels, rather than through a large incision in the chest
  • aortic valve balloon valvuloplasty – the valve is widened using a balloon
  • sutureless aortic valve replacement – the valve is not secured using stitches (sutures) to minimise the time spent on a heart-lung machine

Read more about the alternatives to an aortic valve replacement.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bad breath:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bad breath", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bad breath", "alternateName": ["Halitosis"]}, "description": "Find out what causes bad breath (halitosis), how to treat and prevent it, and when to seek medical advice.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-10T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-01-10T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "name": "Bad breath", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-01-17T14:11:25+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bad-breath/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bad breath"}], "keywords": ["Dental health", "Mouth and dental conditions", "Bad breath"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bad breath (sometimes called halitosis) is very common. You can usually treat it yourself.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How to treat bad breath yourself", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to treat bad breath yourself

The best way of making sure you do not have bad breath is to keep your teeth, tongue and mouth clean.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • gently brush your teeth and gums at least twice a day for 2 minutes
  • use a fluoride toothpaste
  • gently clean your tongue once a day using a tongue scraper or cleaner
  • clean between your teeth with interdental brushes or floss at least once a day
  • get regular dental check-ups
  • keep dentures clean and remove them at night
  • use sugar-free mints or chewing gum after having strong-smelling food and drinks
  • try using an antibacterial mouthwash or toothpaste
"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not smoke
  • do not rinse your mouth with water straight after brushing your teeth
  • do not have lots of sugary foods and drinks
  • do not brush so hard your gums or tongue bleed
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Causes of bad breath", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of bad breath

Causes of bad breath may include:

  • eating or drinking strong-smelling or spicy foods and drinks
  • problems with your teeth or gums, such as gum disease, holes in your teeth or an infection
  • crash dieting
  • some medical conditions, like tonsillitis or acid reflux
  • smoking
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a dentist if you have:

  • bad breath that does not go away after treating it yourself for a few weeks
  • painful, bleeding or swollen gums
  • toothache or wobbly adult teeth
  • problems with your dentures
"}]}]}

"headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) is a surgical procedure used to treat coronary heart disease.

It diverts blood around narrowed or clogged parts of the major arteries to improve blood flow and oxygen supply to the heart.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Why\u00a0they're carried out", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why\u00a0they're carried out

Like all organs in the body, the heart needs a constant supply of blood.

This is supplied by 2 large blood vessels called the left and right coronary arteries.

Over time, these arteries can become narrowed and hardened by the build-up of fatty deposits called plaques.

This process is known as atherosclerosis.

People with atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries are said to have coronary heart disease.

Your chances of developing coronary heart disease increase with age.

You're also much more likely to be affected if:

  • you smoke
  • you're overweight or obese
  • you have a high-fat diet

Coronary heart disease can cause angina, which is chest pain that occurs when the supply of oxygen-rich blood to the heart becomes restricted.

While many cases of angina can be treated with medication, severe angina may require a coronary artery bypass graft to improve the blood supply to the heart.

Another risk associated with coronary heart disease is the possibility of one of the plaques in the coronary artery rupturing (splitting), creating a blood clot.

If the blood clot blocks the blood supply to the heart, it can trigger a\u00a0heart attack.

A\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft may be recommended to reduce your chances of having a heart attack.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "The procedure", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The procedure

A\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft involves taking a blood vessel from another part of the body (usually the chest, leg or arm) and attaching it to the coronary artery above and below the narrowed area or blockage.

This new blood vessel is known as a graft. The number of grafts needed will depend on how severe your coronary heart disease is and how many of the coronary blood vessels\u00a0are narrowed.

A\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft is carried out under general anaesthetic, which means you'll be unconscious during the operation. It usually takes between 3 and 6 hours.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "13", "@type": "ImageObject", "name": "Illustrated diagram showing the location of internal mammary arteries in the chest, radial arteries in the forearms and greater saphenous veins in the legs", "url": "https://assets.nhs.uk/nhsuk-cms/images/NHSC_0918_CABG_sites.max-600x600.jpg", "provider": "NHS Digital/Annabel King", "license": "NHS Digital/Annabel King", "datePublished": "2018-09-14T12:50:52+00:00", "keywords": []}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovery

Most people will need to stay in hospital for at least 7 days after having a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft.

You should have a follow-up appointment, typically about 6 to 8 weeks after your operation.

Recovering takes time and everyone recovers at slightly different speeds.

Generally, you should be able to sit in a chair after 1 day, walk after 3 days, and walk up and down stairs after 5 or 6 days.

When you go home, you'll need to take things easy for a few weeks.

You should be able to return to most of your normal activities after about 6 weeks, including working, driving and having sex.

Most people make a full recovery within 12 weeks.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Risks of surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks of surgery

As with all types of surgery, a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft\u00a0carries a risk of complications.

These are usually relatively minor and treatable, such as an irregular heartbeat or a wound infection, but there's also a risk of serious complications, such as a stroke or heart attack.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "After surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

After surgery

After having a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft, most people will experience a significant improvement in symptoms such as\u00a0breathlessness and chest pain, and their heart attack risk will be lowered.

But a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft isn't a cure for coronary heart disease.

If you don't make lifestyle changes, such as eating a\u00a0healthy diet and\u00a0exercising regularly, your grafted arteries will also eventually become hardened and narrowed.

In some cases, a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft may need to be repeated or you may need a procedure to widen your arteries using a small balloon and a tube called a stent (coronary angioplasty).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Alternatives", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Alternatives

A coronary angioplasty is the main alternative to a\u00a0coronary artery bypass graft.

It's a less invasive operation where a long, flexible, hollow plastic tube called a catheter is inserted into a blood vessel in your arm or groin.

The tip of the catheter is guided under X-ray to the arteries that supply your heart, to the point where the narrowing of the artery has occurred.

A balloon attached to the catheter is then inflated to widen the artery and a small metal tube called a stent is often used to help keep the artery open.

It\u00a0usually takes less time to recover from a coronary angioplasty than from a coronary artery bypass graft, but there's a higher chance that the procedure will need to be repeated.

Also, a\u00a0coronary angioplasty may not be recommended if multiple coronary arteries have become blocked and narrowed or the structure of the blood vessels near your heart is abnormal.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How long will I have to wait for surgery?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How long will I have to wait for surgery?

The length of time you'll have to wait to have\u00a0a coronary artery bypass graft will vary from area to area.

Your GP or cardiac surgeon should be able to tell you what the waiting lists are like in your area or at the hospital you have chosen.

Ideally, you should be treated within 3 months of the decision to operate.

Coronary heart disease does not always have obvious symptoms. In some people, it can cause chest pain (angina) or serious problems like heart attacks.

Coronary heart disease is caused by a build-up of fatty substances in the blood vessels supplying the heart. It's often linked to an unhealthy diet.

The main treatments for coronary heart disease are healthy lifestyle changes and medicines. Some people may need surgery.

You can reduce your risk of getting coronary heart disease by making simple lifestyle changes, such as being active and having a healthy diet.

The main symptoms of CHD are:

  • chest pain (angina)
  • shortness of breath
  • pain throughout the body
  • feeling faint
  • feeling sick (nausea)

But not everyone has the same symptoms and some people may not have any before CHD is diagnosed.

It's often linked to an unhealthy diet.", "text": "

Coronary heart disease is the term that describes what happens when your heart's blood supply is blocked or interrupted by a build-up of fatty substances in the coronary arteries.

Over time, the walls of your arteries can become furred up with fatty deposits. This process is known as atherosclerosis and the fatty deposits are called atheroma.

Atherosclerosis can be caused by lifestyle factors, such as smoking and regularly drinking excessive amounts of alcohol.

You're also more at risk of getting atherosclerosis if you have conditions like high cholesterol, high blood pressure (hypertension)\u00a0or diabetes.

Coronary heart disease cannot be cured but treatment can help manage the symptoms and reduce the chances of\u00a0problems such as heart attacks.

  • lifestyle changes, such as regular exercise and stopping smoking

  • eating a healthy, balanced diet
  • being physically active
  • giving up smoking
  • controlling blood cholesterol and sugar levels

Keeping your heart healthy will also have other health benefits, such as helping\u00a0reduce your risk of stroke and dementia.

If you've been diagnosed with CHD, making simple lifestyle changes can reduce your risk of having further episodes.

For example,\u00a0stopping smoking after a heart attack quickly reduces your risk of having a\u00a0heart attack in the future to near that of a non-smoker.

Other lifestyle changes, such as\u00a0eating more healthily and doing regular exercise, will also reduce your future risk of heart disease.

Diagnosing coronary heart disease (CHD)

If a doctor feels you're at risk of CHD, they may carry out a risk assessment.

They'll ask you about your medical and family history and your lifestyle, and they'll take a blood test.

Further tests may be needed to confirm CHD, including:

  • a treadmill test
  • a radionuclide scan
  • a CT scan
  • an MRI scan
  • coronary angiography

Read more about how coronary heart disease is diagnosed.

  • lifestyle changes, such as regular exercise and stopping smoking
  • medicines
  • angioplasty \u2013 where balloons and stents are used to treat narrow heart arteries
  • surgery

Recovering from the effects of coronary heart disease (CHD)

If you've had a heart attack, an angioplasty, or heart surgery, it's possible to get back to a normal life.

Advice and support is available to help you deal with aspects of your life that may have been affected by CHD.

Read more about recovering from the effects of coronary heart disease.

You can reduce your risk of getting CHD by making some simple lifestyle changes.

These include:

  • eating a healthy, balanced diet
  • being physically active
  • giving up smoking
  • controlling blood cholesterol and sugar levels

Keeping your heart healthy will also have other health benefits, such as helping\u00a0reduce your risk of stroke and dementia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "The heart", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The heart

The heart is a muscle about the size of your fist. It pumps blood around your body and beats approximately 70 times a minute.

After the blood leaves the right side of the heart, it goes to your lungs where it picks up oxygen.

The oxygen-rich blood returns to your heart and is then pumped to the body's organs through a network of arteries.

The blood returns to your heart through veins before being pumped back to your lungs again. This process is called circulation.

The heart gets its own supply of blood from a network of blood vessels on the heart's surface called coronary arteries.

"text": "

Haemochromatosis is an inherited condition where iron levels in the body slowly build up over many years.

This build-up of iron, known as iron overload, can cause unpleasant symptoms. If it is not treated, this\u00a0can damage parts of the body such as the liver, joints, pancreas and heart.

Haemochromatosis most often affects people of white northern European background and is particularly common in countries where lots of people have a Celtic background, such as Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of haemochromatosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of haemochromatosis

Symptoms of haemochromatosis usually start between the ages of 30 and 60.

Common symptoms include:

  • feeling very tired all the time (fatigue)
  • weight loss
  • weakness
  • joint pain
  • an inability to get or maintain an erection (erectile dysfunction)
  • irregular periods or absent periods

Read more about symptoms of haemochromatosis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to see your GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a GP

See a GP if you have:

  • persistent or worrying symptoms that could be caused by haemochromatosis \u2013 particularly if you have a northern European family background
  • a parent or sibling with haemochromatosis, even if you do not have symptoms yourself \u2013 tests can be done to check if you're at risk of developing problems

Talk to the GP about whether you should have blood tests to check for haemochromatosis.

Read more about tests for haemochromatosis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for haemochromatosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments for haemochromatosis

There's currently no cure for haemochromatosis, but there are treatments that can reduce the amount of iron in the body and reduce the risk of damage.

There are 2 main treatments.

  • phlebotomy \u2013 a procedure to remove some of your blood; this may need to be done every week at first and can continue to be needed 2 to 4 times a year for the rest of your life
  • chelation therapy \u2013 where you take medicine to reduce the amount of iron in your body; this is only used if it's not easy to regularly remove some of your blood

You do not need to make any big changes to your diet to control your iron levels if you're having treatment, but you'll usually be advised to avoid:

  • breakfast cereals containing added iron
  • iron or vitamin C supplements
  • drinking too much alcohol

Read more about how haemochromatosis is treated

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of haemochromatosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of haemochromatosis

Haemochromatosis is caused by a faulty gene that affects how the body absorbs iron from your diet.

You're at risk of developing the condition if both of your parents have this faulty gene and you inherit 1 copy from each of them.

You will not get haemochromatosis if you only inherit 1 copy of the faulty gene but there's a chance you could pass the faulty gene on to any children you have.

And even if you do inherit 2 copies, you will not necessarily get haemochromatosis. Only a small number of people with 2 copies of this faulty gene will ever develop the condition. It's not known exactly why this is.

Read more about the causes of haemochromatosis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications\u00a0of haemochromatosis", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of haemochromatosis

If the condition is diagnosed and treated early on, haemochromatosis does not affect life expectancy and is unlikely to result in serious problems.

But if it's not found until it's more advanced, the high iron levels can damage parts of the body.

This can lead to potentially serious complications, such as:

  • liver problems \u2013 including scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) or liver cancer
  • diabetes \u2013 where the level of sugar in the blood becomes too high
  • arthritis \u2013 pain and swelling in the joints
  • heart failure \u2013 where the heart is unable to pump blood around the body properly

Read more about complications of haemochromatosis

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Further support", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Further support

Haemochromatosis UK is a patient-run UK charity that provides information and support to people living with haemochromatosis.

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Haemophilia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license":
