"Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Haemophilia", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about the causes, symptoms and treatment of haemophilia, an inherited condition that means you bleed more than usual.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-17T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-17T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/", "name": "Haemophilia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-04-23T14:42:19+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Haemophilia", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/haemophilia/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Haemophilia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Haemophilia is\u00a0a\u00a0rare condition that affects the blood's ability to clot. It's usually inherited. Most people who have it are male.

Normally, when\u00a0you cut yourself, substances\u00a0in your blood known as clotting factors mix with blood cells called platelets to make your blood sticky and form a clot. This makes the bleeding stop eventually.

People with haemophilia do not have\u00a0as many clotting factors\u00a0as they should have\u00a0in their blood.\u00a0This means they bleed\u00a0for longer than usual.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of haemophilia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The\u00a0symptoms of haemophilia can be mild to severe, depending on the level of clotting factors you have.

The main symptom is\u00a0bleeding that does not stop.

People with haemophilia may have:

  • nosebleeds that take a long time to stop
  • bleeding from wounds that\u00a0lasts a long time
  • bleeding gums
  • skin that bruises easily
  • pain and stiffness around joints, such as elbows, because of bleeding\u00a0inside the body (internal bleeding)

Read more about the\u00a0symptoms of haemophilia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP\u00a0if:

  • you or your child bruises easily and has bleeding that\u00a0does not stop
  • your or your child has symptoms of joint bleeds\u00a0\u2013 for example, tingling, pain, or stiffness in a joint, and the joint becoming hot, swollen, and tender
  • you have a family history of haemophilia and you're pregnant or planning to have a baby

There's a small risk that people with haemophilia may have a bleed inside their skull (a brain or subarachnoid haemorrhage).

Symptoms of a brain haemorrhage include:

  • a severe headache
  • a stiff neck
  • being sick (vomiting)
  • a change in mental state, such as confusion
  • difficulty speaking, such as slurred speech
  • changes in vision, such as double vision
  • loss of co-ordination and balance
  • paralysis of some or all the facial muscles

Call 999 and ask for an ambulance if you think someone's bleeding inside their skull.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Your local haemophilia centre", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have haemophilia, register at your local haemophilia centre. It's a useful source of advice and support.

People with haemophilia are cared for by a hospital haematology department.

Find\u00a0haematology services near you.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Tests and diagnosis", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Blood tests can diagnose haemophilia and find out how severe it is.\u00a0

If there's no family history of haemophilia, it's usually diagnosed when a child begins to walk or crawl.\u00a0

Mild haemophilia may only be discovered later, usually after an injury or a dental or surgical procedure.

Genetic tests and pregnancy

If you\u00a0have a family history of haemophilia and you're planning to\u00a0get pregnant,\u00a0genetic and genomic testing\u00a0can\u00a0help you find out the risk of passing the condition on to a child.

This may involve testing\u00a0a sample\u00a0of your tissue or blood to look for signs of the\u00a0genetic change that causes haemophilia.

Tests during pregnancy can diagnose haemophilia in the baby. These include:

  • chorionic villus sampling (CVS) \u2013\u00a0a small sample of the placenta is removed from the womb and tested for the haemophilia gene, usually\u00a0during weeks 11 to 14 of pregnancy
  • amniocentesis\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a sample of amniotic fluid is taken for testing, usually\u00a0during weeks 15 to 20 of pregnancy

There's a small risk of these procedures causing problems such as miscarriage or premature labour, so you may find it helpful to discuss this with your doctor.

If haemophilia is suspected after your child's born, a blood test can usually confirm the diagnosis. Blood from the umbilical cord can be tested at birth.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments for\u00a0haemophilia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There's no cure for haemophilia, but\u00a0treatment usually allows\u00a0a person with the condition\u00a0to enjoy a good quality of life.

Man-made clotting factors are given as medicines to prevent and treat prolonged bleeding. These medicines are\u00a0given as an injection.\u00a0

In milder cases, injections are usually only given in response to prolonged bleeding. More severe cases\u00a0are\u00a0treated with regular injections to prevent bleeding.

Read more about treatments for\u00a0haemophilia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Living\u00a0with haemophilia", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

With treatment, most people with haemophilia can live a normal life.

However, you should:

  • avoid contact sports, such as rugby
  • be careful taking other medicines\u00a0\u2013 some can affect your blood's ability to clot, such as\u00a0aspirin and\u00a0ibuprofen
  • take care of your teeth and gums and have regular check-ups at the dentist

Looking after your teeth\u00a0and gums helps you avoid problems such as gum disease, which can cause bleeding.\u00a0Most non-surgical dental treatment can be done\u00a0at a general dental surgery.

Your care team at the hospital can give you advice about surgical dental procedures, such as having a tooth removed, and further information and advice about living with haemophilia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Information about you", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have haemophilia, your clinical team\u00a0may pass information about you on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Diseases Registration Service (NCARDRS).

This helps scientists better understand the condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

Find out more about the NCARDRS in a leaflet you can download at GOV.UK

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Hair loss:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hair loss", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hair loss", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Alopecia is the general medical term for hair loss. There are many types of hair loss with different symptoms and causes.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hair-loss/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-01-04T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-01-04T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hair-loss/", "name": "Hair loss", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-04-26T15:10:10+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hair-loss/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hair loss"}], "keywords": ["Alopecia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Losing your hair isn't usually anything to be worried about, but it can be upsetting. Treatment may help with some types of hair loss.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of hair loss

It's normal to lose hair. We can lose between 50 and 100 hairs a day, often without noticing.

Hair loss isn't usually anything to be worried about, but occasionally it can be a sign of a medical condition.

Some types of hair loss are permanent, like male and female pattern baldness. This type of hair loss usually runs in the family.

Other types of hair loss may be temporary. They can be caused by:

  • an illness
  • stress
  • cancer treatment
  • weight loss
  • iron deficiency
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you have sudden hair loss
  • you develop bald patches
  • you're losing hair in clumps
  • your head also itches and burns
  • you're worried about your hair loss
"}, {"position": 1, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

Your GP should be able to tell you what's causing your hair loss by looking at your hair.

Tell your GP if your hair loss is affecting your wellbeing, and ask what treatments are available.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

See your GP first to get a clear and accurate idea of what's causing your hair loss before thinking about going to a commercial hair clinic, which can be expensive.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for hair loss

Most hair loss doesn't need treatment and is either:

  • temporary and it'll grow back
  • a normal part of getting older

Hair loss caused by a medical condition usually stops or grows back once you have recovered.

There are things you can try if your hair loss is causing you distress. But most treatments aren't available on the NHS, so you'll have to pay for them.

No treatment is 100% effective.

Finasteride and minoxidil

Finasteride and minoxidil are the main treatments for male pattern baldness.

Minoxidil can also be used to treat female pattern baldness. Women shouldn't use finasteride.

These treatments:

  • don't work for everyone
  • only work for as long as they're used
  • aren't available on the NHS
  • can be expensive

Wigs

Some wigs are available on the NHS, but you may have to pay unless you qualify for financial help.

Synthetic wigs:

  • last 6 to 9 months
  • are easier to look after than real-hair wigs
  • can be itchy and hot
  • cost less than real-hair wigs

Real-hair wigs:

  • last 3 to 4 years
  • are harder to look after than synthetic wigs
  • look more natural than synthetic wigs
  • cost more than synthetic wigs

Find out more about NHS wigs and costs

Other hair loss treatments

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Treatment Description
Steroid injection injections given into bald patches
Steroid creams cream applied to bald patches
Immunotherapy chemical applied to bald patches
Light treatment shining ultraviolet light on bald patches
Tattooing tattoo used to look like short hair and eyebrows
Hair transplant hair cells are moved to thinning patches
Scalp reduction surgery sections of scalp with hair are stretched and stitched together
Artificial hair transplant surgery to implant artificial hairs
"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some of these treatments may not be available on the NHS.

Find out more about cancer and hair loss

Emotional help

Losing hair can be upsetting. For many people, hair is an important part of who they are.

If your hair loss is causing you distress, your GP may be able to help you get some counselling.

You may also benefit from joining a support group, or speaking to other people in the same situation on online forums.

Try these online support groups:

  • Alopecia UK
  • Alopecia Awareness
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Hand tendon repair:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hand tendon repair", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": surgery is carried out, the recovery process and possible complications.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-tendon-repair/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-06-14T15:39:00+00:00", "Hand tendon repair", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-01-22T12:38:30+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-tendon-repair/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hand tendon repair", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-tendon-repair/what-happens/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "How it's performed"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-tendon-repair/recovery/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Recovery"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-tendon-repair/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Risks"}], "keywords": ["Rehabilitation", "Tendon repair", "Hand"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If any of the tendons in your hand are damaged, surgery may be needed to repair them and help restore movement in the affected fingers or thumb.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "What are tendons?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What are tendons?

Tendons are tough cords of tissue that connect muscles to bones. When a group of muscles contract (tighten), the attached tendons will pull on certain bones, allowing you to make a wide range of movements.

There are 2 groups of tendons in the hand:

  • extensor tendons – which run from the forearm across the back of your hand to your fingers and thumb, allowing you to straighten your fingers and thumb
  • flexor tendons – which run from your forearm through your wrist and across the palm of your hand, allowing you to bend your fingers

Surgery can often be done to repair damage to both these groups of tendons.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When hand tendon repair is needed", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When hand tendon repair is needed

Hand tendon repair is done when one or more tendons in your hand rupture or are cut, leading to the loss of normal hand movements.

If your extensor tendons are damaged, you'll be unable to straighten one or more fingers.

If your flexor tendons are damaged, you'll be unable to bend one or more fingers.

Tendon damage can also cause pain and swelling (inflammation) in your hand.

In some cases, damage to the extensor tendons can be treated without the need for surgery, using a rigid support called a splint that's worn around the hand.

Common causes of tendon injuries include:

  • cuts – cuts across the back or palm of your hand can result in injury to your tendons 
  • sports injuries – extensor tendons can rupture when stubbing a finger, such as trying to catch a ball; flexor tendons can occasionally be pulled off the bone when grabbing an opponent's jersey, such as in rugby; and the pulleys holding flexor tendons can rupture during activities that involve lots of strenuous gripping, such as rock climbing
  • bites – animal and human bites can cause tendon damage, and a person may damage their hand tendon after punching another person in the teeth
  • crushing injuries – jamming a finger in a door or crushing a hand in a car accident can divide or rupture a tendon 
  • rheumatoid arthritis – rheumatoid arthritis can cause tendons to become inflamed, which can lead to tendons rupturing in severe cases
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Tendon repair surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Tendon repair surgery

Tendon repair may involve a surgeon making a cut (incision) in your wrist, hand or finger so they can locate the ends of the divided tendon and stitch them together.

Extensor tendons are easier to reach, so repairing them is relatively straightforward.

Read more about how hand tendon repair is performed.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering from surgery", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from surgery

Both types of tendon surgery require a lengthy period of recovery (rehabilitation) because the repaired tendons will be weak until the ends heal together.

Depending on the location of the injury, it can take up to 3 months for the repaired tendon to regain its previous strength.

Rehabilitation involves protecting your tendons from overuse using a hand splint. You'll usually need to wear a hand splint for several weeks after surgery.

You'll also need to perform hand exercises regularly during your recovery to stop the repaired tendons sticking to nearby tissue, which can prevent you being able to fully move your hand.

When you can return to work will depend on your job. Light activities can often be resumed after 6 to 8 weeks, and heavy activities and sport after 10 to 12 weeks.

Read more about recovering from hand tendon repair.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Results", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Results

After an extensor tendon repair you should have a working finger or thumb, but you may not regain full movement.

The outcome is often better when the injury is a clean cut to the tendon, rather than one that involves crushing or damage to the bones and joints.

A flexor tendon injury is generally more serious because they're often put under more strain than extensor tendons.

After a flexor tendon repair, it's quite common for some fingers to not regain full movement. But the tendon repair will still give a better result than not having surgery.

In some cases, complications develop after surgery, such as infection or the repaired tendon snapping or sticking to nearby tissue.

In these circumstances, further treatment may be required.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

[{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you're considering having an operation or your GP has suggested you may need surgery, this guide is for you.

It'll take you through all the steps in the process, from referral to recovery, so you're fully prepared and know what questions to ask at each stage.

Before you start, you'll need to decide which hospital you'd like to be referred to. Our tips on choosing a hospital can help.

You can also compare hospitals by following these steps:

  • search for hospitals by surgical procedure
  • enter your postcode and the name of your operation
  • you'll be taken to a page listing the hospitals that can carry out the operation
  • using the columns and drop-down menu, you can compare hospitals based on things such as performance, safety, complaints and facilities

Once you have chosen your hospital, your GP will refer you to see a specialist at this hospital.

Symptoms of hay fever include sneezing, coughing, a runny nose and itchy, red eyes.

You can usually treat hay fever with things like antihistamine medicines bought from a pharmacy. See a GP if it does not get better.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hay-fever/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of hay fever include sneezing, coughing, a runny nose and itchy, red eyes.", "text": "

Symptoms of hay fever include:

  • sneezing and coughing
  • a runny or blocked nose
  • itchy, red or watery eyes
  • itchy throat, mouth, nose and ears
  • loss of smell
  • pain around your temples and forehead
  • headache
  • earache
  • feeling tired

If you have asthma, you might also:

  • have a tight feeling in your chest
  • be short of breath
  • wheeze and cough

Hay fever will last for weeks or months, unlike a cold, which usually goes away after 1 to 2 weeks.

", "title": "Check if you have hay fever"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hay-fever/#treatments-summary", "description": "You can usually treat hay fever with things like antihistamine medicines bought from a pharmacy. See a GP if it does not get better.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hay-fever/#self-care", "description": "You can usually treat hay fever with things like antihistamine medicines bought from a pharmacy. See a GP if it does not get better.", "text": "

There's currently no cure for hay fever and you cannot prevent it.

But you can do things to ease your symptoms when the pollen count is high.


Do

  • put Vaseline around your nostrils to trap pollen

  • wear wraparound sunglasses to stop pollen getting into your eyes

  • shower and change your clothes after you have been outside to wash pollen off

  • stay indoors whenever possible

  • keep windows and doors shut as much as possible

  • vacuum regularly and dust with a damp cloth

  • buy a pollen filter for the air vents in your car and a vacuum cleaner with a special HEPA filter


Don't

  • do not cut grass or walk on grass

  • do not spend too much time outside

  • do not keep fresh flowers in the house

  • do not smoke or be around smoke \u2013 it makes your symptoms worse

  • do not dry clothes outside \u2013 they can catch pollen

  • do not let pets into the house if possible \u2013 they can carry pollen indoors

", "title": "How to treat hay fever yourself"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hay-fever/#treatments-other", "description": "You can usually treat hay fever with things like antihistamine medicines bought from a pharmacy. See a GP if it does not get better.", "text": "

Your GP might prescribe steroids.

If steroids and other hay fever treatments do not work, your GP may refer you for immunotherapy.

This means you'll be given small amounts of pollen as an injection or tablet to slowly build up your immunity to pollen.

This kind of treatment usually starts in the winter about 3 months before the hay fever season begins.

Hay fever is usually worse between late March and September, especially when it's warm, humid and windy. This is when the pollen count is at its highest.

Head lice and nits:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Head lice and nits", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Head lice and nits", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out how to spot head lice, how to get rid of them and how they spread.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-01-10T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-01-10T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/", "name": "Head lice and nits", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:23:01+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/#overview", "description": "Head lice are tiny insects that can attach to your hair. They're spread by head-to-head contact.", "text": "

Symptoms of head lice include small brown or white eggs (nits) in your hair and an itchy scalp.

The main treatment for head lice involves using a special comb. You can get medicated lotions and sprays from a pharmacy if combing does not work.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of head lice include small brown or white eggs (nits) in your hair and an itchy scalp.", "text": "


Head lice are small insects, up to 3mm long.


They can be difficult to spot in your hair.


Head lice eggs (nits) are brown or white (empty shells) and attached to the hair.

Head lice can make your head feel:

  • itchy
  • like something is moving in your hair

The only way to be sure someone has head lice is by finding live lice.

You can do this by combing their hair with a special fine-toothed comb (detection comb). You can buy these online or at pharmacies.

", "title": "Check if it's head lice"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/#treatments-summary", "description": "The main treatment for head lice involves using a special comb. You can get medicated lotions and sprays from a pharmacy if combing does not work.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/#self-care", "description": "The main treatment for head lice involves using a special comb. You can get medicated lotions and sprays from a pharmacy if combing does not work.", "text": "

Important

You can treat head lice without seeing a GP.

Treat head lice as soon as you spot them.

You should check everyone in the house and start treating anyone who has head lice on the same day.

There's no need to keep your child off school if they have head lice.

Wet combing

Lice and nits can be removed by wet combing. You should try this method first.

You can buy a special fine-toothed comb (detection comb) online or from pharmacies to remove head lice and nits.

There may be instructions on the pack, but usually you:

  • wash hair with ordinary shampoo
  • apply lots of conditioner (any conditioner will do)
  • comb the whole head of hair, from the roots to the ends

It usually takes about 10 minutes to comb short hair, and 20 to 30 minutes for long, frizzy or curly hair.

Do wet combing on days 1, 5, 9 and 13 to catch any newly hatched head lice. Check again that everyone's hair is free of lice on day 17.

Medicated lotions and sprays

Ask a pharmacist for advice if you have tried wet combing for 17 days, but your child still has live head lice.

They may recommend using medicated lotions and sprays. These kill head lice in all types of hair, and you can buy them from pharmacies, supermarkets or online.

Head lice should die within a day. Some lotions and sprays come with a comb to remove dead lice and eggs.

Some treatments need to be repeated after a week to kill any newly hatched lice.

Check the pack to see if they're OK for you or your child and how to use them.

If lotions or sprays do not work, speak to a pharmacist about other treatments.

Some treatments are not recommended because they're unlikely to work.

For example:

  • products containing permethrin
  • head lice \"repellents\"
  • electric combs for head lice
  • tree and plant oil treatments, such as tea tree oil, eucalyptus oil and lavender oil herbal remedies
", "title": "How to get rid of head lice"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/head-lice-and-nits/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Head lice and nits"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Head lice and nits are very common in young children and their families. They do not have anything to do with dirty hair and are picked up by head-to-head contact.

The charity Community Health Concern has a video about wet combing for head lice.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Prevention", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You cannot prevent head lice

There's nothing you can do to prevent head lice.

You can help stop them spreading by wet or dry combing regularly to catch them early.

Do not use medicated lotions and sprays to prevent head lice. They can irritate the scalp.

There's no need for children to stay off school or to wash laundry on a hot wash.

Hearing loss:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hearing loss", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hearing loss", "alternateName": ["Deafness"]}, "description": "Find out about the signs of hearing loss and deafness, what can cause it, when to get medical help and what the main treatments are.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-08-01T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-08-01T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "name": "Hearing loss", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-10T14:54:28+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hearing loss", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-loss/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Hearing loss can be temporary or permanent. It\u00a0often comes on gradually as you get older, but it can sometimes\u00a0happen suddenly.

See a GP if you\u00a0notice any problems with your hearing so you can find out the cause and get advice on treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Signs\u00a0and symptoms of hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Signs\u00a0and symptoms of hearing loss

It's not always easy to tell if you're losing your hearing.

Common signs include:

  • difficulty hearing other people clearly, and misunderstanding what they say, especially in\u00a0noisy places
  • asking people to repeat themselves
  • listening to music or watching television loudly
  • having to concentrate hard to hear what other people are saying, which can be tiring or stressful

The signs can be slightly different if you only\u00a0have hearing loss in 1 ear or if a young child has hearing loss.

Read more about the\u00a0signs and symptoms of hearing loss.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to\u00a0get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to\u00a0get medical help

A GP can help\u00a0if you think you're losing your hearing.

  • if you or your child suddenly lose hearing (in 1 or both ears), call a GP or NHS 111\u00a0as soon as possible
  • if you think your or your child's hearing is getting\u00a0gradually worse, make an appointment to see a GP
  • if you're concerned\u00a0about a\u00a0friend's or family member's hearing, encourage them to see a GP

The GP will ask about your symptoms and look inside your ears\u00a0using a small handheld torch with a magnifying lens. They can also do some simple checks of your hearing.

If needed, they can refer you to a specialist for more hearing tests.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes\u00a0of hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes\u00a0of hearing loss

Hearing loss can have many different causes. For example:

  • sudden hearing loss in 1 ear may be\u00a0due to\u00a0earwax, an\u00a0ear infection, a\u00a0perforated (burst) eardrum\u00a0or\u00a0M\u00e9ni\u00e8re's disease
  • sudden hearing loss in both ears\u00a0may be\u00a0due to damage from a very loud noise, or taking certain medicines that can\u00a0affect hearing
  • gradual hearing loss in 1 ear\u00a0may be due to something inside the ear, such as fluid (glue ear),\u00a0a\u00a0bony growth\u00a0(otosclerosis) or a\u00a0build-up of\u00a0skin cells (cholesteatoma)
  • gradual hearing loss in both ears is usually caused by\u00a0ageing or exposure to loud noises over many years

This may give you an idea of\u00a0the reason for\u00a0hearing loss \u2013\u00a0but make sure you see\u00a0a GP to get a proper diagnosis. It might not always be possible to identify an obvious cause.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for hearing loss

Hearing loss sometimes gets\u00a0better on its own, or may be treated with medicine or a simple procedure. For example, earwax can be sucked out, or\u00a0softened with eardrops.

But other types\u00a0\u2013 such as gradual hearing loss, which\u00a0often happens as you get older \u2013\u00a0may be permanent. In these cases, treatment\u00a0can help make the most of the remaining hearing. This may involve using:

  • hearing aids\u00a0\u2013 several different types are available on the NHS or privately
  • implants\u00a0\u2013 devices that are attached to\u00a0your skull or placed deep inside your ear, if hearing aids are not suitable
  • different ways of\u00a0communicating\u00a0\u2013 such as sign language\u00a0or lip reading

Read more about treatments for\u00a0hearing loss

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Preventing\u00a0hearing loss", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Preventing\u00a0hearing loss

It's not always possible to prevent hearing loss, but there are some simple things you can do to reduce the risk of damaging your hearing.

These include:

  • not\u00a0having your television, radio or music on too loud
  • using headphones that block out more outside noise, instead of turning up the volume
  • wearing\u00a0ear protection (such as ear defenders) if you work in a noisy environment, such as a\u00a0garage workshop or\u00a0a building site; special vented earplugs that allow some noise in are also available for musicians
  • using ear protection at loud concerts and other events where there are high noise levels
  • not\u00a0inserting objects into your or your children's ears\u00a0\u2013 this includes fingers, cotton buds, cotton wool and tissues

Read more tips to protect your hearing

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Social care and support guide

If you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled \u2013 including family members

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Hearing tests:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hearing tests", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hearing tests", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about hearing tests that are used to assess your ability to hear different sounds and to determine if there are any problems.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-tests/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-11-30T01:00:00+00:00", "2023-11-30T01:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-tests/", "name": "Hearing tests", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-07T14:45:28+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hearing-tests/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hearing tests"}], "keywords": ["Hearing impairment", "Hearing loss", "Hearing tests", "Otitis externa", "Ear infections", "Ear", "Otitis media"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are several ways you can get your hearing tested.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How to get an NHS hearing test", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How to get an NHS hearing test

You can get a free hearing test on the NHS. A GP may refer you to a hearing specialist (audiologist) who can do the test.

It could take a few weeks to see a specialist so it might be quicker to get tested somewhere else, like at a large pharmacy or opticians. This is often free.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

Always see a GP first if:

  • you also have other symptoms, like earache or discharge – this could be something easily treatable like an earwax build-up or ear infection
  • you have sudden hearing loss in one ear
  • you're worried about your child's hearing
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Other ways to get a hearing test", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Other ways to get a hearing test

Online hearing test

There are simple hearing tests online.

This can tell you if you need to have a face-to-face hearing test.

Pharmacies and opticians

Lots of large pharmacies and opticians can do hearing tests.

The test is often free, but you'll normally have to pay for any treatment you might need (such as hearing aids).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "What happens during a hearing test", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

You may have a few different tests during your appointment to check if you have hearing loss and find out the cause.

Common hearing tests include:

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Table", "identifier": "21", "text": "
Test What happens
Pure tone audiometry you listen to different sounds through headphones and press a button or raise your hand each time you hear something
Speech perception test similar to a pure tone audiometry test but you listen to speech rather than sounds
Tympanometry a small device is placed in your ear to check for fluid behind your eardrum
"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

These are hearing tests for adults. Newborn hearing tests and some hearing tests for children are different.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}]}
Heart attack:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Heart attack", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Heart attack", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about heart attacks, a serious medical emergency in which the supply of blood to the heart is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-11-28T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-11-28T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/", "name": "Heart attack", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-11-13T16:44:30+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#overview", "description": "A heart attack is a serious condition where the supply of blood to the heart is suddenly blocked. It needs to be treated as quickly as possible.", "text": "

Symptoms of a heart attack include chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness and sweating. Call 999 if you think someone is having a heart attack.

A heart attack needs to be treated in hospital as quickly as possible. Medicine or surgery may be needed to restore the supply of blood to your heart.

The main cause of a heart attack is the blood vessels leading to the heart becoming blocked.

You can help reduce your risk of having a heart attack by eating a healthy diet, doing regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of a heart attack include chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness and sweating. Call 999 if you think someone is having a heart attack.", "text": "

Symptoms of\u00a0a heart attack\u00a0can include:

  • chest pain\u00a0\u2013\u00a0the chest can feel like it's being pressed or squeezed by a heavy object, and pain can radiate from the chest to the jaw, neck, arms and back
  • shortness of breath
  • feeling weak or lightheaded, or both
  • an overwhelming feeling of anxiety

It's important to know that not everyone experiences severe chest pain. This is particularly the case with many women. The pain can often be mild and mistaken for indigestion.

It's the combination of symptoms that's important in determining whether a person is having a heart attack and not the severity of chest pain.

", "title": "Symptoms of a heart attack"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#treatments-summary", "description": "A heart attack needs to be treated in hospital as quickly as possible. Medicine or surgery may be needed to restore the supply of blood to your heart.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#treatments-other", "description": "A heart attack needs to be treated in hospital as quickly as possible. Medicine or surgery may be needed to restore the supply of blood to your heart.", "text": "

While waiting for an ambulance, it may help to chew and then swallow a tablet of aspirin (ideally 300mg), as long as the person having a heart attack is not allergic to aspirin.

Aspirin helps to thin the blood and improves blood flow to the heart.

In hospital, treatment for a heart attack depends on how serious it is.

The 2 main treatments are:

  • using medicines to dissolve blood clots
  • surgery to help restore blood to the heart
", "title": "Treating heart attacks"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#causes", "description": "The main cause of a heart attack is the blood vessels leading to the heart becoming blocked.", "text": "

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of heart attacks.

CHD is a condition in which the major blood vessels that supply the heart get clogged with deposits of cholesterol, known as\u00a0plaques.

Before a heart attack, 1 of the plaques bursts (ruptures), causing a\u00a0blood clot to develop at the site of the rupture.

The clot may block the supply of blood to the heart, triggering a heart attack.

", "title": "Causes of a heart attack"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-attack/#prevention", "description": "You can help reduce your risk of having a heart attack by eating a healthy diet, doing regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight.", "text": "

There are 5 main steps you can take to reduce your risk of having a heart attack (or having another heart attack):

  • smokers should quit smoking
  • lose weight if you're overweight or obese
  • do regular exercise \u2013 adults should do at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) of\u00a0moderate-intensity aerobic activity each week, unless advised otherwise by the doctor in charge of your care
  • eat a low-fat, high-fibre diet, including wholegrains and at least 5 portions of fruit and vegetables a day
  • moderate your alcohol consumption

A heart attack (myocardial infarction or MI) is a serious medical emergency in which the supply of blood to the heart is suddenly blocked, usually by a blood clot.

A heart attack is a medical emergency. Call 999 and ask for an ambulance if you\u00a0suspect\u00a0a heart attack.

A lack of blood to the heart\u00a0may seriously damage the heart muscle and can be life threatening.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of a heart attack", "text": "Symptoms of a heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of\u00a0a heart attack\u00a0can include:

  • chest pain\u00a0\u2013\u00a0the chest can feel like it's being pressed or squeezed by a heavy object, and pain can radiate from the chest to the jaw, neck, arms and back
  • shortness of breath
  • feeling weak or lightheaded, or both
  • an overwhelming feeling of anxiety

It's important to know that not everyone experiences severe chest pain. This is particularly the case with many women. The pain can often be mild and mistaken for indigestion.

It's the combination of symptoms that's important in determining whether a person is having a heart attack and not the severity of chest pain.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating heart attacks", "text": "Treating a heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

While waiting for an ambulance, it may help to chew and then swallow a tablet of aspirin (ideally 300mg), as long as the person having a heart attack is not allergic to aspirin.

Aspirin helps to thin the blood and improves blood flow to the heart.

In hospital, treatment for a heart attack depends on how serious it is.

The 2 main treatments are:

  • using medicines to dissolve blood clots
  • surgery to help restore blood to the heart
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of a heart attack", "text": "Causes of a heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is the leading cause of heart attacks.

CHD is a condition in which the major blood vessels that supply the heart get clogged with deposits of cholesterol, known as\u00a0plaques.

Before a heart attack, 1 of the plaques bursts (ruptures), causing a\u00a0blood clot to develop at the site of the rupture.

The clot may block the supply of blood to the heart, triggering a heart attack.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Recovering from a heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from a heart attack

The time it takes to recover from a heart attack will depend on the amount of damage to your heart muscle.

Most people can return to work after having a heart attack. Some people are well enough to return to work after 2 weeks. Other people may take several months to recover. How quickly you can go back to work depends on your health, the state of your heart and the type of work you do.

The recovery process aims to:

  • reduce your risk of another heart attack through a combination of lifestyle changes (such as eating a healthy diet), and medicines (such as\u00a0statins), which help to lower blood cholesterol levels
  • gradually restore your physical fitness so you can resume normal activities (cardiac rehabilitation)

Find out more about recovering from a heart attack

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of a heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of a heart attack

Complications of a heart attack can be serious and possibly life threatening.

These include:

  • arrhythmias \u2013 these are abnormal heartbeats. 1 type is where the heart begins beating faster and faster, then stops beating (cardiac arrest)
  • cardiogenic shock \u2013 where the heart's muscles are severely damaged and can no longer contract properly to supply enough blood to maintain many body functions
  • heart rupture \u2013 where the heart's muscles, walls or valves split apart (rupture)

These complications can happen quickly after a heart attack and are a leading cause of death.

Many people die suddenly from a complication of a heart attack before reaching hospital or within the 1st month after a heart attack.

The outlook often depends on:

  • age \u2013 serious complications are more likely as you get older
  • the severity of the heart attack \u2013 how much of the heart's muscle has been damaged during the attack
  • how long it took before a person received treatment \u2013 treatment for a heart attack should begin as soon as possible

Find out more about complications of a heart attack

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing a\u00a0heart attack", "text": "Preventing a\u00a0heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are 5 main steps you can take to reduce your risk of having a heart attack (or having another heart attack):

  • smokers should quit smoking
  • lose weight if you're overweight or obese
  • do regular exercise \u2013 adults should do at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) of\u00a0moderate-intensity aerobic activity each week, unless advised otherwise by the doctor in charge of your care
  • eat a low-fat, high-fibre diet, including wholegrains and at least 5 portions of fruit and vegetables a day
  • moderate your alcohol consumption
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 9, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Video: Heart attack", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Heart block:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Heart block", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Heart block", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Heart block is a condition where the heart beats more slowly or with an abnormal rhythm. Find out what causes it and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-block/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-08-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-08-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-block/", "name": "Heart block", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-09-08T13:22:00+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-block/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Heart block"}], "keywords": ["Heart and vascular diseases", "Heart", "Heart block"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Heart block is a condition where the heart beats more slowly or with an abnormal rhythm. It's caused by a problem with the electrical pulses that control how your heart beats.

Symptoms depend on which type of heart block you have. The least serious type, 1st-degree heart block, may not cause any symptoms.

2nd-degree heart block sometimes causes troublesome symptoms that need treatment, and 3rd-degree heart block \u2013 the most serious type \u2013 can sometimes be a medical emergency.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of heart block", "text": "Symptoms of heart block", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

1st-degree heart block

1st-degree heart block does not usually cause any symptoms. Most people only find out they have it when they're tested for an unrelated medical condition.

2nd-degree heart block

Most people with the less serious type of 2nd-degree heart block, known as Mobitz type 1, do not have any symptoms. But some people may feel:

  • lightheaded or dizzy
  • faint

People with the more serious type of 2nd-degree heart block, known as Mobitz type 2 heart block, are more likely to have Mobitz type 1 symptoms as well as:

  • chest pain
  • shortness of breath
  • feeling very dizzy suddenly when standing up from a lying or sitting position\u00a0\u2013\u00a0this is caused by having low blood pressure (hypotension)

3rd-degree heart block

Symptoms of 3rd-degree or complete heart block include:

  • feeling faint
  • being short of breath
  • extreme tiredness, sometimes with confusion
  • chest pain

Call 999 if your symptoms are severe or come on very quickly. These symptoms can be life threatening.

All types of heart block can increase your risk of developing other heart rhythm problems, such as atrial fibrillation (an irregular and abnormally fast heart rate).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of heart block", "text": "Causes of heart block", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some people are born with heart block\u00a0\u2013 known as congenital heart block.

But more commonly, heart block develops later in life. This is known as acquired heart block and can be caused by:

  • other heart conditions, such as a heart attack
  • some prescription medicines
  • other conditions, such as Lyme disease
  • having heart surgery

Babies are more likely to have congenital heart block if they're born with a heart defect, or if their mother has an autoimmune condition, such as lupus.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment of heart block", "text": "Treatment of heart block", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Heart block normally only needs to be treated if it's causing symptoms.

Depending on the cause of heart block and your symptoms, you may need to have a small device called a pacemaker fitted in your chest. A pacemaker is a small battery-operated device inserted under the skin of your chest. It sends frequent electrical pulses to keep your heart beating regularly.

Read more about how a pacemaker is fitted

Treatment for heart block usually works well. Most people live a normal active life with a pacemaker.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Diagnosing heart block", "text": "Diagnosing heart block", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Unless you're experiencing symptoms, heart block is often diagnosed during routine tests for other conditions.

An\u00a0electrocardiogram (ECG) is the main test used to diagnose heart block. It measures the electrical activity of your heart.

An ECG can be carried out at rest or while you're exercising. Your doctor may ask you to wear a portable ECG monitor to get a reading over time. It provides a useful overall assessment of how well your heart is working.

The results of an ECG can also sometimes indicate the type of heart block you have.

Heart failure:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Heart failure", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Heart failure", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what heart failure is, including what the symptoms are and how it's treated.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-10-26T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-10-26T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/", "name": "Heart failure", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-01T18:08:38+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/#overview", "description": "Heart failure is where the heart is unable to pump blood around the body properly and needs treatment to help it work.", "text": "

Symptoms of heart disease include shortness of breath, tiredness and swelling in your ankles or legs.

Heart failure is caused by damage to the heart or a problem with the way it works. Common causes include heart disease and high blood pressure.

The main treatments for heart failure are healthy lifestyle changes and medicines. Some people may also need a pacemaker or heart surgery.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of heart disease include shortness of breath, tiredness and swelling in your ankles or legs.", "text": "

The main symptoms of heart failure are:

  • breathlessness\u00a0after activity or at rest
  • feeling tired most of the time and finding exercise exhausting
  • swollen ankles and legs

Some people also experience other symptoms, such as a persistent cough, a fast heart rate and dizziness.

Symptoms can develop quickly (acute heart failure) or gradually over weeks or months\u00a0(chronic heart failure).

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of heart failure"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/#causes", "description": "Heart failure is caused by damage to the heart or a problem with the way it works. Common causes include heart disease and high blood pressure.", "text": "

Heart failure is often the result of a number of\u00a0problems affecting the heart at the same time.

Conditions that can lead to\u00a0heart failure\u00a0include:

  • coronary heart disease \u2013 where the arteries that supply blood to the heart become clogged up\u00a0with fatty substances (atherosclerosis), which may cause angina or a heart attack
  • high blood pressure \u2013 this can put extra strain on the heart, which over time can lead to heart failure
  • cardiomyopathy \u2013 conditions affecting\u00a0the heart muscle
  • heart rhythm problems\u00a0(arrhythmias), such as\u00a0atrial fibrillation
  • damage or other problems with the heart valves
  • congenital heart disease\u00a0\u2013\u00a0birth defects that affect the normal workings of the heart

Sometimes anaemia, drinking too much alcohol, an overactive thyroid or high pressure in the lungs (pulmonary hypertension) can also lead to heart failure.

Some people may also need a pacemaker or heart surgery.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/#treatments-other", "description": "The main treatments for heart failure are healthy lifestyle changes and medicines. Some people may also need a pacemaker or heart surgery.", "text": "

Treatment for heart failure usually aims to control the symptoms for as long as possible and slow down the progression of the condition.

Common treatments include:

  • lifestyle changes\u00a0\u2013 including eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly and stopping smoking
  • medicine\u00a0\u2013 a range of medicines can help; many people need to take 2 or 3 different types
  • devices implanted in your chest\u00a0\u2013 these can help control your heart rhythm
  • surgery\u00a0\u2013 such as a\u00a0bypass operation or a\u00a0heart transplant

Treatment will usually be needed for life.

A cure may be possible when heart failure has a\u00a0treatable cause. For example, if your heart valves are damaged, replacing or repairing\u00a0them may\u00a0cure the condition.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for heart failure"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Heart failure", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-failure/living-with/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Living with"}], "keywords": ["Heart failure"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Heart failure means that the heart is unable to pump blood around the body properly. It usually occurs because the heart has become too weak or stiff.

It's sometimes called congestive heart failure, although this name is not widely used nowadays.

Heart failure does not mean your heart has stopped working. It just needs some support to help it work better.

It can occur at any age, but is most common in older people.

Heart failure is a\u00a0long-term condition that tends to get gradually worse over time.

It cannot usually be cured, but the symptoms can often be controlled for many years.

Get the flu vaccine

Flu can be very serious if you have heart failure. Ask for your free flu jab at:

  • your GP surgery
  • a local pharmacy that has a flu vaccine service

Find out more about the flu vaccine

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and heart failure from the British Heart Foundation

The main symptoms of heart failure are:

  • breathlessness\u00a0after activity or at rest
  • feeling tired most of the time and finding exercise exhausting
  • swollen ankles and legs

Some people also experience other symptoms, such as a persistent cough, a fast heart rate and dizziness.

Symptoms can develop quickly (acute heart failure) or gradually over weeks or months\u00a0(chronic heart failure).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

See a GP if you experience persistent or gradually worsening symptoms of heart failure.

Call 999 for an ambulance or go to\u00a0your nearest A&E department as soon as possible if you have sudden or very severe symptoms.

A number of tests can be used to help check how well your heart is working,\u00a0including blood tests, an\u00a0ECG and an echocardiogram.

Find out more about how heart failure is diagnosed

Heart failure is often the result of a number of\u00a0problems affecting the heart at the same time.

Conditions that can lead to\u00a0heart failure\u00a0include:

  • coronary heart disease \u2013 where the arteries that supply blood to the heart become clogged up\u00a0with fatty substances (atherosclerosis), which may cause angina or a heart attack
  • high blood pressure \u2013 this can put extra strain on the heart, which over time can lead to heart failure
  • cardiomyopathy \u2013 conditions affecting\u00a0the heart muscle
  • heart rhythm problems\u00a0(arrhythmias), such as\u00a0atrial fibrillation
  • damage or other problems with the heart valves
  • congenital heart disease\u00a0\u2013\u00a0birth defects that affect the normal workings of the heart

Sometimes anaemia, drinking too much alcohol, an overactive thyroid or high pressure in the lungs (pulmonary hypertension) can also lead to heart failure.

Treatment for heart failure usually aims to control the symptoms for as long as possible and slow down the progression of the condition.

Common treatments include:

  • lifestyle changes\u00a0\u2013 including eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly and stopping smoking
  • medicine\u00a0\u2013 a range of medicines can help; many people need to take 2 or 3 different types
  • devices implanted in your chest\u00a0\u2013 these can help control your heart rhythm
  • surgery\u00a0\u2013 such as a\u00a0bypass operation or a\u00a0heart transplant

Treatment will usually be needed for life.

A cure may be possible when heart failure has a\u00a0treatable cause. For example, if your heart valves are damaged, replacing or repairing\u00a0them may\u00a0cure the condition.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for heart failure", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook\u00a0for heart failure

Heart failure is a serious long-term condition that'll usually continue to get slowly worse over time.

It can severely limit the activities you're able to do and is often eventually fatal.

But\u00a0it's\u00a0very difficult\u00a0to\u00a0tell how the condition will progress on an individual basis.

It's very unpredictable. Lots of\u00a0people\u00a0remain\u00a0stable for many years, while\u00a0in some cases it\u00a0may get\u00a0worse quickly.

Social care and support guide

If you:

  • need help with day-to-day living because of illness or disability
  • care for someone regularly because they're ill, elderly or disabled (including family members)

Our guide to care and support explains your options and where you can get support.

"https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-transplant/what-happens/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "What happens"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url":
