"https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heart-transplant/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Risks"}], "keywords": ["Coronary heart disease", "Heart and vascular diseases", "Heart transplant", "Heart", "Heart failure", "Transplantation"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A heart transplant is an operation to replace a damaged or failing heart with a healthy heart from a donor who's recently died.

It may be recommended when a person's life is at risk because their heart no longer works effectively.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Why heart transplants are carried out", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why heart transplants are carried out

A heart transplant may be considered if you have severe heart failure and medical treatments are not helping.

Conditions that may eventually require a heart transplant include:

  • coronary heart disease – a build-up of fatty substances in the arteries supplying the heart, which block or interrupt blood flow to the heart
  • cardiomyopathy – where the walls of the heart have become stretched, thickened or stiff
  • congenital heart disease – birth defects that affect the normal workings of the heart

If your doctor thinks you might benefit from a heart transplant, you'll need to have an in-depth assessment to check whether you're healthy enough to have one before being placed on a waiting list.

Read more about who can have a heart transplant and being on the heart transplant waiting list.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "What happens during a heart transplant", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens during a heart transplant

A heart transplant needs to be carried out as soon as possible after a donor heart becomes available.

The procedure is performed under general anaesthetic, where you're asleep.

While it's carried out, a heart-lung bypass machine will be used to keep your blood circulating with oxygen-rich blood.

A cut is made in the middle of the chest. Your own heart is then removed, and the donor heart is connected to the main arteries and veins. The new heart should then begin beating normally.

Find out more about how a heart transplant is performed

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Recovering from a heart transplant", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Recovering from a heart transplant

You'll usually need to stay in hospital for around 2 or 3 weeks after a heart transplant.

Most people are able to start returning to many of their normal activities within a few months.

Your transplant team can give you advice about how long you may need to avoid certain activities during your recovery.

You'll need to have regular check-ups with your transplant team after the transplant.

You'll also need to take medicines called immunosuppressants for the rest of your life. 

Without these medicines, your body may recognise your new heart as foreign and attack it (rejection).

Find out more about recovering from a heart transplant

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Risks of a heart transplant", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Risks of a heart transplant

A heart transplant is a complex and risky procedure.

Possible complications include:

  • the immune system recognising the transplanted heart as foreign and attacking it (rejection)
  • the donated heart failing to work properly (graft failure)
  • narrowing of the arteries supplying the heart (cardiac allograft vasculopathy)
  • side effects from the immunosuppressant medication, such as an increased vulnerability to infections, weight gain and kidney problems

Many of these problems are treatable, although sometimes another heart transplant may need to be carried out if possible.

Find out more about the risks associated with a heart transplant

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Outlook for heart transplants", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook for heart transplants

Most people can eventually return to their normal activities after a heart transplant and experience a significant improvement in their symptoms for many years.

But it's a major operation and some of the complications can be life threatening.

Overall:

  • 80 to 90 in every 100 people will live at least a year
  • 70 to 75 in every 100 people will live at least 5 years
  • 50 in every 100 people will live at least 10 years

Some people have survived for more than 25 years after a heart transplant.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "NHS Organ Donor Register", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

NHS Organ Donor Register

If you're interested in donating your organs after you die, you can join the NHS Organ Donor Register.

Joining the NHS Organ Donor Register is quick and simple, and will only take a few minutes of your time.

You can remove yourself from the register at any time and can specify what you're willing to donate.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Heavy periods:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Heavy periods", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Heavy periods", "alternateName": ["Periods (heavy)"]}, "description": "Read about heavy periods, also known as menorrhagia. Heavy periods are where an excessive amount of blood is lost during several consecutive periods.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-06-07T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-06-07T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/", "name": "Heavy periods", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:30:52+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/#overview", "description": "Heavy periods are when you lose a lot of blood during your period or your periods last a long time.", "text": "

You may have heavy periods if you lose a lot of blood during your periods, pass large blood clots or your periods last more than 7 days.

It's not always clear why some women get heavy periods. Sometimes it's linked to conditions like fibroids or endometriosis.

Common treatments for heavy periods include contraceptives and medicines to help reduce the amount of blood you lose.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/#symptoms", "description": "You may have heavy periods if you lose a lot of blood during your periods, pass large blood clots or your periods last more than 7 days.", "text": "

It's difficult to define exactly what a heavy period is because it varies from woman to woman. Heavy for 1 woman may be normal for another.

Most women will lose less than 16 teaspoons of blood (80ml) during their period, with the average being around 6 to 8 teaspoons.

Heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as losing 80ml or more in each period, having periods that last longer than 7 days, or both.

But it's not usually necessary to measure blood loss. Most women have a good idea of how much bleeding is normal for them during their period and can tell when this changes.

A good indication that your periods are heavy is if you:

  • are having to change your sanitary products every hour or 2
  • are passing blood clots larger than 2.5cm (about the size of a 10p coin)
  • are bleeding through to your clothes or bedding
  • need to use 2 types of sanitary product together (for example, tampons and pads)
", "title": "How much is heavy bleeding?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/#causes", "description": "It's not always clear why some women get heavy periods. Sometimes it's linked to conditions like fibroids or endometriosis.", "text": "

In about half of women with heavy menstrual bleeding, no underlying reason is found.

But there are several conditions and some treatments that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding.

Some conditions of the womb and ovaries can cause heavy bleeding, including:

  • fibroids \u2013 non-cancerous growths that develop in or around the womb and can cause heavy or painful periods
  • endometriosis \u2013 where the tissue that lines the womb (endometrium) is found outside the womb, such as in the ovaries and fallopian tubes (although this is more likely to cause painful periods)
  • adenomyosis \u2013 when tissue from the womb lining becomes embedded in the wall of the womb; this can also cause painful periods
  • pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) \u2013 an infection in the upper genital tract (the womb, fallopian tubes or ovaries) that can cause symptoms like pelvic or abdominal pain, bleeding after sex or between periods, vaginal discharge and a high temperature
  • endometrial polyps \u2013 non-cancerous growths in the lining of the womb or cervix (neck of the womb)
  • cancer of the womb \u2013 the most common symptom is abnormal bleeding, especially after the menopause
  • polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) \u2013 a common condition that affects how the ovaries work; it causes irregular periods, and periods can be heavy when they start again

Other conditions that can cause heavy periods include:

  • blood clotting disorders, such as Von Willebrand disease
  • an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) \u2013 where the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormones, causing tiredness, weight gain and feelings of depression
  • diabetes

Medical treatments that can sometimes cause heavy periods include:

  • an IUD (intrauterine contraceptive device, or \"the coil\") \u2013 this can make your periods heavier for the first 3 to 6 months after insertion
  • anticoagulant medicine \u2013 taken to prevent blood clots
  • some medicines used for chemotherapy
  • some herbal supplements, which can affect your hormones and may affect your periods \u2013 such as ginseng, ginkgo and soya
", "title": "What causes heavy periods?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/#treatments-summary", "description": "Common treatments for heavy periods include contraceptives and medicines to help reduce the amount of blood you lose.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/#treatments-other", "description": "Common treatments for heavy periods include contraceptives and medicines to help reduce the amount of blood you lose.", "text": "

There are various treatment options for heavy periods. These depend on what's causing your heavy periods, your general health and your preferences.

They include:

  • an intrauterine system (IUS) \u2013 a small device that contains the hormone progestogen is inserted in your womb by a medical professional (often the first treatment offered)
  • medicines without hormones \u2013 such as tranexamic acid or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)
  • medicines with hormones \u2013 such as the combined oral contraceptive pill or progestogen tablets
  • endometrial ablation \u2013 a procedure to remove the lining of the womb
  • myomectomy \u2013 surgery to remove fibroids
  • uterine artery embolisation \u2013 a procedure to shrink fibroids
  • hysterectomy \u2013 surgery to remove to the womb
", "title": "Treating heavy periods"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Heavy periods", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/heavy-periods/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Treatment"}], "keywords": ["Blood", "Bleeding", "Painful periods", "Women", "Heavy periods"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Heavy periods are common, but they can have a big effect on a woman's everyday life.

They do not always have an underlying cause, but they can result from problems such as fibroids or endometriosis, so it's important to get your symptoms checked out.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you're worried about your bleeding
  • your periods have got heavier
  • you're also having other symptoms, such as period pain or bleeding between your periods

Various treatments are available for heavy periods, including:

  • some types of contraception, like an intrauterine system (IUS) or the combined pill
  • medicines, like tranexamic acid
  • surgery
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How much is heavy bleeding?", "text": "How much is heavy bleeding?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's difficult to define exactly what a heavy period is because it varies from woman to woman. Heavy for 1 woman may be normal for another.

Most women will lose less than 16 teaspoons of blood (80ml) during their period, with the average being around 6 to 8 teaspoons.

Heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as losing 80ml or more in each period, having periods that last longer than 7 days, or both.

But it's not usually necessary to measure blood loss. Most women have a good idea of how much bleeding is normal for them during their period and can tell when this changes.

A good indication that your periods are heavy is if you:

  • are having to change your sanitary products every hour or 2
  • are passing blood clots larger than 2.5cm (about the size of a 10p coin)
  • are bleeding through to your clothes or bedding
  • need to use 2 types of sanitary product together (for example, tampons and pads)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes heavy periods?", "text": "What causes heavy periods?", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

In about half of women with heavy menstrual bleeding, no underlying reason is found.

But there are several conditions and some treatments that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding.

Some conditions of the womb and ovaries can cause heavy bleeding, including:

  • fibroids \u2013 non-cancerous growths that develop in or around the womb and can cause heavy or painful periods
  • endometriosis \u2013 where the tissue that lines the womb (endometrium) is found outside the womb, such as in the ovaries and fallopian tubes (although this is more likely to cause painful periods)
  • adenomyosis \u2013 when tissue from the womb lining becomes embedded in the wall of the womb; this can also cause painful periods
  • pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) \u2013 an infection in the upper genital tract (the womb, fallopian tubes or ovaries) that can cause symptoms like pelvic or abdominal pain, bleeding after sex or between periods, vaginal discharge and a high temperature
  • endometrial polyps \u2013 non-cancerous growths in the lining of the womb or cervix (neck of the womb)
  • cancer of the womb \u2013 the most common symptom is abnormal bleeding, especially after the menopause
  • polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) \u2013 a common condition that affects how the ovaries work; it causes irregular periods, and periods can be heavy when they start again

Other conditions that can cause heavy periods include:

  • blood clotting disorders, such as Von Willebrand disease
  • an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) \u2013 where the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormones, causing tiredness, weight gain and feelings of depression
  • diabetes

Medical treatments that can sometimes cause heavy periods include:

  • an IUD (intrauterine contraceptive device, or "the coil") \u2013 this can make your periods heavier for the first 3 to 6 months after insertion
  • anticoagulant medicine \u2013 taken to prevent blood clots
  • some medicines used for chemotherapy
  • some herbal supplements, which can affect your hormones and may affect your periods \u2013 such as ginseng, ginkgo and soya
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Seeing a GP and further tests", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Seeing a GP and further tests

A GP will start by asking you about your heavy bleeding, any changes to your periods and any other symptoms you have, like bleeding between your periods or period pain.

All women who have heavy periods should be offered a blood test to check for iron deficiency anaemia.

The GP may also suggest a physical examination or refer you for further tests to try to find out if there's an underlying cause for your heavy periods.

Further tests may include:

  • other blood tests
  • an ultrasound scan
  • a hysteroscopy \u2013 where a narrow telescope with a light and camera at the end is passed into the womb through the vagina to examine the inside of the womb

Find out more about diagnosing heavy periods

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating heavy periods", "text": "Treating heavy periods", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are various treatment options for heavy periods. These depend on what's causing your heavy periods, your general health and your preferences.

They include:

  • an intrauterine system (IUS) \u2013 a small device that contains the hormone progestogen is inserted in your womb by a medical professional (often the first treatment offered)
  • medicines without hormones \u2013 such as tranexamic acid or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)
  • medicines with hormones \u2013 such as the combined oral contraceptive pill or progestogen tablets
  • endometrial ablation \u2013 a procedure to remove the lining of the womb
  • myomectomy \u2013 surgery to remove fibroids
  • uterine artery embolisation \u2013 a procedure to shrink fibroids
  • hysterectomy \u2013 surgery to remove to the womb
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

[{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Hepatitis\u00a0A is a liver\u00a0infection caused by a virus that's spread in the poo of an infected person.

It's uncommon in the UK,\u00a0but certain\u00a0groups are at increased risk. This includes travellers to parts of the world with poor levels of sanitation, men who have sex with men, and people who inject drugs.

Hepatitis A\u00a0can be unpleasant, but it's not\u00a0usually serious and\u00a0most people make a full recovery within a couple of months.

Some people, particularly young children, may not have any symptoms.

But\u00a0hepatitis A\u00a0can occasionally last for many months and, in rare cases, it can\u00a0be life threatening if\u00a0it causes\u00a0the liver to stop working properly (liver failure).

A\u00a0hepatitis A vaccine is available for people at high risk of infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

Get advice about coronavirus and liver disease from the British Liver Trust

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of hepatitis A", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms\u00a0of hepatitis A

The symptoms of hepatitis A develop, on average, around 4 weeks after becoming infected, although not everyone will get them.

Symptoms can include:

  • feeling\u00a0tired\u00a0and generally\u00a0unwell
  • joint and muscle pain
  • a raised temperature
  • loss of appetite
  • feeling or being sick
  • pain in the upper right part of your tummy
  • yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
  • dark pee and pale poo
  • itchy skin

The symptoms will usually pass within a couple of months.

Find out more about the symptoms of hepatitis A

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

See your GP for advice if:

  • you have symptoms of hepatitis A\u00a0\u2013\u00a0a\u00a0blood test\u00a0can usually confirm whether you have the infection
  • you might have been exposed to the hepatitis A virus recently but you do not have any symptoms \u2013 treatment given early on may be able to stop the infection developing
  • you think you\u00a0might need the hepatitis A vaccine \u2013 your GP\u00a0can advise you about whether you should have the vaccine

Although hepatitis A is not usually serious, it's important to see your GP so they can rule out more serious conditions with similar symptoms, such as hepatitis C or scarring of ther liver\u00a0(cirrhosis).

It may also be necessary to test your friends, family and any sexual partners in case you have spread the infection to them.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How\u00a0you can get hepatitis A", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How\u00a0you can get hepatitis A

Hepatitis A is most widespread in parts of the world\u00a0where standards of sanitation and food hygiene are generally poor, such as parts of Africa, the Indian subcontinent,\u00a0the Far East, the Middle East, and Central and South America.

You can get the infection from:

  • eating food\u00a0prepared by someone with the infection who has not washed their hands properly or washed them in water contaminated with sewage
  • drinking contaminated water, including ice cubes
  • eating raw or undercooked shellfish\u00a0from\u00a0contaminated water
  • close contact with someone who has hepatitis A
  • less commonly, having sex with someone with hepatitis A (this is particularly a risk for\u00a0men who have sex with men) or injecting drugs using contaminated equipment

Someone\u00a0with hepatitis A is most infectious from around 2 weeks before symptoms appear until about a week after symptoms first develop.

Find out more about the causes of hepatitis A

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Vaccination\u00a0against\u00a0hepatitis A", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vaccination\u00a0against\u00a0hepatitis A

Vaccination against\u00a0hepatitis A is not routinely offered in the UK because the risk of infection is low for most people.

It's only recommended for people at an increased risk, including:

  • close contacts of someone with hepatitis A
  • people\u00a0planning to travel to or live in parts of the world where hepatitis A is widespread, particularly if sanitation and food hygiene are expected to be poor
  • people with\u00a0any type of long-term\u00a0liver disease
  • men who have sex with other men
  • people who inject illegal drugs
  • people who may be exposed to hepatitis A through their job\u00a0\u2013 this includes\u00a0sewage workers, people who work for organisations where personal hygiene may be poor, such as a homeless shelter, and people working with\u00a0monkeys, apes and gorillas

The hepatitis A\u00a0vaccine is usually available for free on the NHS for anyone who\u00a0needs it.

Find out more about the hepatitis A vaccine

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for hepatitis A", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatments\u00a0for hepatitis A

There's currently no cure for hepatitis A. But it usually gets better on its own within a couple of\u00a0months. You can usually look after yourself at home.

While you're ill, it's a good idea to:

  • get plenty of rest
  • take painkillers, such as\u00a0paracetamol\u00a0or\u00a0ibuprofen,\u00a0for any aches and pains\u00a0\u2013\u00a0ask your GP for advice about this, as you may need to take lower doses than normal or avoid certain medications until you have recovered
  • maintain a cool, well-ventilated environment, wear loose clothing and avoid\u00a0hot baths or showers to reduce any itching
  • eat small, light meals to help reduce nausea and vomiting
  • avoid alcohol\u00a0to reduce the strain on your liver
  • stay off work or school and avoid having sex until at least a week after your\u00a0jaundice or other symptoms started
  • practise good hygiene, such as\u00a0washing your hands with soap and water regularly

Speak to your GP if your symptoms are particularly troublesome or have not started to improve within a couple of months.

They\u00a0can prescribe medications to help with itchiness, nausea or vomiting, if necessary.

Find out more about treating hepatitis A

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for hepatitis A", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook

For\u00a0most people, hepatitis A gets better within 2 months and there are no long-term effects.

Once it passes, you normally develop life-long immunity against the virus.

In around\u00a01 in every\u00a07 people with the infection, the symptoms may come and go for up to\u00a06 months before eventually disappearing.

Life-threatening complications such as liver failure are rare, affecting less than 1 in every 250 people with hepatitis A.

People most at risk include the elderly and those with pre-existing liver\u00a0problems.

If you have hepatitis A and liver failure, you'll usually need a\u00a0liver transplant.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hepatitis B", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hepatitis B", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about hepatitis B, an infection of the liver caused by a virus. Find out about the symptoms, causes, treatments and risks of the condition.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-01-30T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-01-30T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/", "name": "Hepatitis B", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:31:32+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#overview", "description": "Hepatitis B is an infection of the liver caused by a virus.", "text": "

Hepatitis B does not always have symptoms. Possible symptoms of an infection include a high temperature, feeling sick, diarrhoea and tummy pain.

Hepatitis B sometimes gets better without treatment. It if lasts a long time, you may need medicines to keep the virus under control.

Hepatitis B is spread in blood and bodily fluids. Ways it can be spread include having sex without a condom and sharing needles.

There is a vaccine that can help prevent hepatitis B. The vaccine is offered on the NHS to all babies born in the UK and some people at high risk.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#symptoms", "description": "Hepatitis B does not always have symptoms. Possible symptoms of an infection include a high temperature, feeling sick, diarrhoea and tummy pain.", "text": "

Many people with hepatitis B will not experience any symptoms and may fight off the virus without realising they had it.

If symptoms do develop, they tend to happen 2 or 3 months after exposure to the hepatitis B virus.

Symptoms of hepatitis B include:

  • flu-like symptoms, including tiredness, a fever, and general aches and pains
  • loss of appetite
  • feeling and being\u00a0sick
  • diarrhoea
  • tummy pain
  • yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)

These symptoms will usually pass within 1 to 3 months (acute hepatitis B), although\u00a0occasionally the infection can last for 6 months or more (chronic hepatitis B).

", "title": "Symptoms\u00a0of hepatitis B"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#treatments-summary", "description": "Hepatitis B sometimes gets better without treatment. It if lasts a long time, you may need medicines to keep the virus under control.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#treatments-other", "description": "Hepatitis B sometimes gets better without treatment. It if lasts a long time, you may need medicines to keep the virus under control.", "text": "

Treatment for hepatitis B depends on how long you have been infected for.

If you have been exposed to the virus in the past few days, emergency treatment can help stop you becoming infected.

If you have only had the infection for a few weeks or months (acute hepatitis B), you may only need treatment to relieve your symptoms while your body fights off the infection.

If you have had the infection for more than 6 months (chronic hepatitis B), you may be offered treatment with medicines that can keep the virus under control and reduce the risk of liver damage.

Chronic hepatitis B often requires long-term or lifelong treatment and regular monitoring to check for any further liver problems.

", "title": "Treatments\u00a0for hepatitis B"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#causes", "description": "Hepatitis B is spread in blood and bodily fluids. Ways it can be spread include having sex without a condom and sharing needles.", "text": "

The hepatitis B virus is found\u00a0in the\u00a0blood and bodily fluids, such as semen and vaginal fluids, of an infected person.

It can be spread:

  • from\u00a0a mother to her newborn baby, particularly in countries where the infection is common (read more about hepatitis B in pregnancy)
  • within families (child to child) in countries where the infection is common
  • by injecting drugs and sharing needles and other drug equipment, such as spoons and filters
  • by having sex with an infected person without using a\u00a0condom
  • by having a tattoo,\u00a0body piercing, or medical or dental treatment in an unhygienic environment with unsterilised equipment
  • by sharing toothbrushes or razors contaminated with infected blood

Hepatitis B is not spread\u00a0by kissing,\u00a0holding hands, hugging, coughing, sneezing or sharing crockery\u00a0and utensils.

", "title": "How\u00a0hepatitis B is spread"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/#prevention", "description": "There is a vaccine that can help prevent hepatitis B. The vaccine is offered on the NHS to all babies born in the UK and some people at high risk.", "text": "

A vaccine that offers protection against hepatitis B is routinely available for all\u00a0babies born in the UK.

It's also available for\u00a0people at high risk of the infection or complications from it.

This includes:

  • babies born to hepatitis B-infected mothers
  • close family and sexual partners of someone with hepatitis B
  • people\u00a0travelling to a part of the world where hepatitis B is widespread, such as\u00a0sub-Saharan Africa, east and southeast Asia, and the Pacific Islands
  • families adopting or fostering children from high-risk countries
  • people\u00a0who inject drugs or have a sexual partner who injects drugs
  • people\u00a0who change their sexual partner frequently
  • men who have sex with men
  • male and\u00a0female sex workers
  • people who work somewhere that places them at risk of contact with blood or body fluids, such as nurses, prison staff, doctors, dentists and laboratory staff
  • people with chronic liver disease
  • people with chronic kidney disease
  • prisoners
  • people who receive regular blood or blood products, and their carers

The hepatitis B vaccine is given to infants\u00a0as part of the\u00a0routine childhood vaccination schedule\u00a0and those at high risk of developing the infection.

You do not need to pay for the vaccine if your child is eligible to receive it as part of the routine childhood vaccination schedule, or they're born to a mother with hepatitis B.

Others\u00a0may have to pay for it.

", "title": "Preventing\u00a0hepatitis B"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hepatitis B", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-b/complications/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Hepatitis B", "Liver"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Hepatitis B\u00a0is\u00a0an infection of the liver caused by a virus that's spread through blood and body fluids.

It often does not cause any obvious symptoms in adults,\u00a0and typically passes in a few months without treatment.

But in\u00a0children, it\u00a0often persists for years and may eventually cause serious liver damage.

Hepatitis B is less common in the UK than other parts of the world, but certain groups are at an increased risk.

This includes people originally from high-risk countries, people who inject drugs, and people who have unprotected sex with multiple sexual partners.

A\u00a0hepatitis B vaccine is available for people at high risk of the condition.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms\u00a0of hepatitis B", "text": "Symptoms\u00a0of hepatitis B", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Many people with hepatitis B will not experience any symptoms and may fight off the virus without realising they had it.

If symptoms do develop, they tend to happen 2 or 3 months after exposure to the hepatitis B virus.

Symptoms of hepatitis B include:

  • flu-like symptoms, including tiredness, a fever, and general aches and pains
  • loss of appetite
  • feeling and being\u00a0sick
  • diarrhoea
  • tummy pain
  • yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)

These symptoms will usually pass within 1 to 3 months (acute hepatitis B), although\u00a0occasionally the infection can last for 6 months or more (chronic hepatitis B).

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When\u00a0to get medical advice", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When\u00a0to get medical advice

Hepatitis B can be serious, so you should get medical advice if:

  • you think you may have been exposed to the hepatitis B virus\u00a0\u2013 emergency treatment can help prevent infection if given within a\u00a0few days of exposure
  • you have symptoms\u00a0associated with\u00a0hepatitis B
  • you're at a high risk of hepatitis B \u2013\u00a0high-risk groups include people born in a country where the infection is common, babies born to mothers infected with hepatitis B, and people who have ever injected drugs

You can go to\u00a0your local\u00a0GP surgery, drug service, genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinic or sexual health clinic\u00a0for help and advice.

A\u00a0blood test\u00a0can be carried out to check if you have hepatitis B or have had it in the past.\u00a0

The hepatitis B vaccine may also be recommended to reduce your risk of infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatments\u00a0for hepatitis B", "text": "Treatments\u00a0for hepatitis B", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for hepatitis B depends on how long you have been infected for.

If you have been exposed to the virus in the past few days, emergency treatment can help stop you becoming infected.

If you have only had the infection for a few weeks or months (acute hepatitis B), you may only need treatment to relieve your symptoms while your body fights off the infection.

If you have had the infection for more than 6 months (chronic hepatitis B), you may be offered treatment with medicines that can keep the virus under control and reduce the risk of liver damage.

Chronic hepatitis B often requires long-term or lifelong treatment and regular monitoring to check for any further liver problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How\u00a0hepatitis B is spread", "text": "How\u00a0hepatitis B is spread", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The hepatitis B virus is found\u00a0in the\u00a0blood and bodily fluids, such as semen and vaginal fluids, of an infected person.

It can be spread:

  • from\u00a0a mother to her newborn baby, particularly in countries where the infection is common (read more about hepatitis B in pregnancy)
  • within families (child to child) in countries where the infection is common
  • by injecting drugs and sharing needles and other drug equipment, such as spoons and filters
  • by having sex with an infected person without using a\u00a0condom
  • by having a tattoo,\u00a0body piercing, or medical or dental treatment in an unhygienic environment with unsterilised equipment
  • by sharing toothbrushes or razors contaminated with infected blood

Hepatitis B is not spread\u00a0by kissing,\u00a0holding hands, hugging, coughing, sneezing or sharing crockery\u00a0and utensils.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Preventing\u00a0hepatitis B", "text": "Preventing\u00a0hepatitis B", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A vaccine that offers protection against hepatitis B is routinely available for all\u00a0babies born in the UK.

It's also available for\u00a0people at high risk of the infection or complications from it.

This includes:

  • babies born to hepatitis B-infected mothers
  • close family and sexual partners of someone with hepatitis B
  • people\u00a0travelling to a part of the world where hepatitis B is widespread, such as\u00a0sub-Saharan Africa, east and southeast Asia, and the Pacific Islands
  • families adopting or fostering children from high-risk countries
  • people\u00a0who inject drugs or have a sexual partner who injects drugs
  • people\u00a0who change their sexual partner frequently
  • men who have sex with men
  • male and\u00a0female sex workers
  • people who work somewhere that places them at risk of contact with blood or body fluids, such as nurses, prison staff, doctors, dentists and laboratory staff
  • people with chronic liver disease
  • people with chronic kidney disease
  • prisoners
  • people who receive regular blood or blood products, and their carers

The hepatitis B vaccine is given to infants\u00a0as part of the\u00a0routine childhood vaccination schedule\u00a0and those at high risk of developing the infection.

You do not need to pay for the vaccine if your child is eligible to receive it as part of the routine childhood vaccination schedule, or they're born to a mother with hepatitis B.

Others\u00a0may have to pay for it.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Outlook\u00a0for hepatitis B", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Outlook\u00a0for hepatitis B

The vast majority of people infected with hepatitis B in adulthood are able to fight off the virus and fully recover within 1 to 3 months.

Most will then be immune to the infection for life.

Babies and children with hepatitis B are more likely to develop a chronic infection.

Chronic hepatitis B affects around:

  • 90% of babies with hepatitis B
  • 20% of older children with hepatitis B
  • 5% of adults with hepatitis B

Although treatment can help, there's a risk that people with\u00a0chronic hepatitis B could eventually develop life-threatening problems, such as scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) or\u00a0liver cancer.

Find out about the symptoms, causes and treatments for the condition.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-06-21T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-06-21T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/", "name": "Hepatitis C", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:32:58+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#overview", "description": "Hepatitis C is a virus that affects your liver. It can be very serious if it's not treated.", "text": "

There are often no symptoms of hepatitis C at first. Some people get symptoms like muscle aches, a high temperature, tiredness and tummy pain.

You can catch hepatitis C from contact with the blood of an infected person, such as by sharing needles. It's very rare to catch it from having sex.

Hepatitis C can usually be treated with antiviral medicines. These need to be taken for several weeks.

You can reduce your risk of catching hepatitis C by not sharing needles, razors or toothbrushes with other people.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#symptoms", "description": "There are often no symptoms of hepatitis C at first. Some people get symptoms like muscle aches, a high temperature, tiredness and tummy pain.", "text": "

Hepatitis C often does not have any noticeable symptoms until the liver has been significantly damaged.

This means many people have the infection without realising it.

When symptoms do occur, they can be mistaken for another condition.

Symptoms can include:

  • flu-like symptoms, such as\u00a0muscle aches\u00a0and a high temperature (fever)
  • feeling tired all the time
  • loss of appetite
  • tummy (abdominal) pain
  • feeling and being sick

The only way to know for certain if these symptoms are caused by hepatitis C is to get tested.

", "title": "Symptoms of hepatitis C"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#causes", "description": "You can catch hepatitis C from contact with the blood of an infected person, such as by sharing needles. It's very rare to catch it from having sex.", "text": "

The hepatitis C virus is usually\u00a0spread through blood-to-blood contact.

Some ways the infection can be spread include:

  • sharing unsterilised needles\u00a0\u2013 particularly needles used to inject recreational drugs
  • sharing razors or toothbrushes
  • from a pregnant woman to her unborn baby
  • through unprotected sex\u00a0\u2013 although this is very rare

In the UK, most hepatitis C infections happen in people who inject drugs or have injected them in the past.

It's estimated around half of those who inject drugs have the infection.

", "title": "How do you get hepatitis C?"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#treatments-summary", "description": "Hepatitis C can usually be treated with antiviral medicines. These need to be taken for several weeks.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#treatments-other", "description": "Hepatitis C can usually be treated with antiviral medicines. These need to be taken for several weeks.", "text": "

Hepatitis C can be treated with medicines that stop the virus multiplying inside the body. These usually need to be taken for several weeks.

Until recently, most people would have taken 2 main medicines called pegylated interferon (a weekly injection) and ribavirin (a capsule or tablet).

Tablet-only treatments are now available.

These new hepatitis C medicines have been found to make treatment more effective, are easier to tolerate, and have shorter treatment courses.

They include simeprevir, sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Using the latest medications, more than 90% of people with hepatitis C may be cured.

But it's important to be aware that you will not be immune to the infection and should take steps to reduce your risk of becoming infected again.

", "title": "Treatments for\u00a0hepatitis C"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/#prevention", "description": "You can reduce your risk of catching hepatitis C by not sharing needles, razors or toothbrushes with other people.", "text": "

There's no vaccine for hepatitis C, but\u00a0there are ways to reduce your risk of becoming infected.

These include:

  • not sharing\u00a0any drug-injecting equipment with other people\u00a0\u2013 including\u00a0needles and other equipment, such as\u00a0syringes, spoons and filters
  • not sharing razors or\u00a0toothbrushes that might be contaminated with blood

The risk of getting hepatitis C through sex is very low. But it may be higher\u00a0if\u00a0blood is present, such as menstrual blood or from minor bleeding during anal sex.

Condoms are not usually necessary to prevent hepatitis C for long-term heterosexual couples, but it's a good idea to use them when having anal sex or sex with a new partner.

", "title": "Preventing hepatitis C"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hepatitis-c/treatment/#self-care", "description": "Hepatitis C can usually be treated with antiviral medicines. These need to be taken for several weeks.", "text": "

There are some\u00a0things you can do to help limit any damage to your liver and prevent the infection spreading to others.

These can\u00a0include:

  • eating a healthy, balanced\u00a0diet
  • exercising regularly
  • cutting out alcohol or limiting how much you drink
  • stopping smoking
  • keeping personal items, such as toothbrushes or razors, for your own use
  • not sharing\u00a0any\u00a0needles or syringes with others

Hepatitis C is a virus that can infect the liver.\u00a0If left untreated,\u00a0it can sometimes cause serious and potentially life-threatening damage to\u00a0the liver over many years.

But with modern treatments, it's usually possible to cure the infection, and most people with it will have a normal life expectancy.

It's estimated around 215,000 people in\u00a0the UK\u00a0have hepatitis C.

You can become infected with\u00a0it if you come into contact with the blood of an infected person.

Getting tested for hepatitis C

Seek medical advice if you have persistent symptoms of hepatitis C or there's a risk you're infected, even if you do not have any symptoms.

A blood test can be carried out to see if you have the infection.\u00a0

GPs, sexual health clinics,\u00a0genitourinary medicine (GUM) clinics or drug treatment services all offer testing for hepatitis C.

Early diagnosis and treatment can help prevent or limit any damage to your liver,\u00a0as well as help ensure the infection is not passed on to other people.

Find out more about testing for hepatitis C

Hepatitis C can be treated with medicines that stop the virus multiplying inside the body. These usually need to be taken for several weeks.

Until recently, most people would have taken 2 main medicines called pegylated interferon (a weekly injection) and ribavirin (a capsule or tablet).

Tablet-only treatments are now available.

These new hepatitis C medicines have been found to make treatment more effective, are easier to tolerate, and have shorter treatment courses.

They include simeprevir, sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Using the latest medications, more than 90% of people with hepatitis C may be cured.

But it's important to be aware that you will not be immune to the infection and should take steps to reduce your risk of becoming infected again.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of hepatitis C", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of hepatitis C

If the infection is left untreated for many years, some people with hepatitis C will develop scarring of the\u00a0liver (cirrhosis).\u00a0

Over time, this can cause the liver to stop working properly.

In severe cases, life-threatening problems, such as liver failure, where the liver loses most or all of its functions,\u00a0or\u00a0liver cancer, can eventually develop.

Treating hepatitis C as early as possible can help reduce the risk of these problems happening.

Find out more about the complications of hepatitis C

There's no vaccine for hepatitis C, but\u00a0there are ways to reduce your risk of becoming infected.

These include:

  • not sharing\u00a0any drug-injecting equipment with other people\u00a0\u2013 including\u00a0needles and other equipment, such as\u00a0syringes, spoons and filters
  • not sharing razors or\u00a0toothbrushes that might be contaminated with blood

The risk of getting hepatitis C through sex is very low. But it may be higher\u00a0if\u00a0blood is present, such as menstrual blood or from minor bleeding during anal sex.

Condoms are not usually necessary to prevent hepatitis C for long-term heterosexual couples, but it's a good idea to use them when having anal sex or sex with a new partner.

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hiatus hernia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hiatus hernia", "alternateName": ["Hernia (hiatus)"]}, "description": "A hiatus hernia is when part of your stomach moves up into your chest. It’s very common if you’re over 50. It doesn’t normally need treatment if it’s not causing you problems.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-01-16T00:00:00+00:00", "2021-01-16T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/", "name": "Hiatus hernia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-12T07:34:21+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/#overview", "description": "A hiatus hernia is a problem affecting the stomach. It can cause stomach acid to travel up to your throat.", "text": "

Symptoms of hiatus hernia include a burning feeling in your chest (heartburn), burping and feeling sick.

Treatments for a hiatus hernia include taking antacids, eating smaller portions and losing weight. You may need surgery if it does not get better.

It's not clear what causes a hiatus hernia. It's more common if you're over 50, pregnant or overweight.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/#symptoms", "description": "Symptoms of hiatus hernia include a burning feeling in your chest (heartburn), burping and feeling sick.", "text": "

You can have a hiatus hernia without knowing and without it being a problem.

With a hiatus hernia you may:

  • have a painful burning feeling in your chest, often after eating (heartburn)
  • bring up small amounts of food or bitter-tasting fluids (acid reflux)
  • have bad breath
  • burp and feel bloated
  • feel or be sick
  • have difficulty or pain when swallowing

These are the symptoms of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD).

", "title": "Check if you have a hiatus hernia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/#treatments-summary", "description": "Treatments for a hiatus hernia include taking antacids, eating smaller portions and losing weight. You may need surgery if it does not get better.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/#treatments-other", "description": "Treatments for a hiatus hernia include taking antacids, eating smaller portions and losing weight. You may need surgery if it does not get better.", "text": "

Broadly, treatment follows these steps:

  1. Change your eating habits – for example, eat smaller, more frequent meals and do other things to help with the symptoms of GORD.
  2. If you smoke, try to give up – tobacco smoke can irritate your digestive system and make your symptoms worse.
  3. Buy medicines from the pharmacy – ask the pharmacist what you should take to help with the symptoms of GORD.
  4. See a GP – if medicines from the pharmacy and changing your eating habits do not help, a GP can prescribe stronger medicines.
  5. Further tests – if stronger medicines do not work, a GP can send you for further tests to find out if your symptoms are caused by a hiatus hernia. They might also prescribe medicines for long-term GORD.
  6. Surgery – a GP might refer you to a specialist to check if you need surgery. This usually only happens if other treatments have not worked and you keep having very bad symptoms.
", "title": "Treatment for a hiatus hernia"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiatus-hernia/#causes", "description": "It's not clear what causes a hiatus hernia. It's more common if you're over 50, pregnant or overweight.", "text": "

It's not clear what causes a hiatus hernia. Anyone can have one, but it's more common if you're over 50, pregnant or overweight.

"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Urgent", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Get advice from 111 now if you have indigestion or acid reflux and:

  • you have lost weight for no reason
  • swallowing becomes difficult
  • you're being sick (vomiting) frequently
  • there's blood in your sick
  • you have pain in your upper tummy

111 will tell you what to do. They can arrange a phone call from a nurse or doctor if you need it.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

Get an urgent GP appointment

A GP may be able to help you.

Ask your GP practice for an urgent appointment.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for a hiatus hernia", "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Broadly, treatment follows these steps:

  1. Change your eating habits – for example, eat smaller, more frequent meals and do other things to help with the symptoms of GORD.
  2. If you smoke, try to give up – tobacco smoke can irritate your digestive system and make your symptoms worse.
  3. Buy medicines from the pharmacy – ask the pharmacist what you should take to help with the symptoms of GORD.
  4. See a GP – if medicines from the pharmacy and changing your eating habits do not help, a GP can prescribe stronger medicines.
  5. Further tests – if stronger medicines do not work, a GP can send you for further tests to find out if your symptoms are caused by a hiatus hernia. They might also prescribe medicines for long-term GORD.
  6. Surgery – a GP might refer you to a specialist to check if you need surgery. This usually only happens if other treatments have not worked and you keep having very bad symptoms.
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Surgery for a hiatus hernia

Keyhole surgery is usually used for a hiatus hernia. This involves making small cuts in your tummy (abdomen).

It's done under general anaesthetic, so you'll be asleep during the operation.

After surgery, it usually takes:

  • 2 to 3 days to go home
  • 3 to 6 weeks to go back to work
  • 6 weeks before you can eat what you want
  • a few months to recover from side effects like bloating, burping, farting and difficulty swallowing

There's a small risk (about 1 in 100) that your side effects will not go away and you'll need more surgery.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What causes a hiatus hernia", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

It's not clear what causes a hiatus hernia. Anyone can have one, but it's more common if you're over 50, pregnant or overweight.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}]}
Hiccups:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Hiccups", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Hiccups", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about things you can do yourself to stop or prevent hiccups.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiccups/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-13T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-07-13T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiccups/", "name": "Hiccups", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-07-17T14:00:21+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/hiccups/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Hiccups"}], "keywords": ["Hiccups"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most people get hiccups sometimes. They should only last a few minutes. You can usually wait for them to go away or treat them yourself without seeing a GP.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things you can try", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do yourself to stop or prevent hiccups

Although many people find these things helpful, there's no evidence that they work for everyone.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • breathe into a paper bag (do not put it over your head)

  • pull your knees up to your chest and lean forward

  • sip ice-cold water

  • swallow some granulated sugar

  • bite on a lemon or taste vinegar

  • hold your breath for a short time

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not drink alcoholic, fizzy or hot drinks

  • do not chew gum or smoke \u2013 these can cause you to swallow air

  • do not eat spicy food

  • do not eat food very quickly

  • do not eat or drink something very cold immediately after something hot

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Why we get hiccups

There's often no obvious reason why you get hiccups, but some people find certain things trigger their hiccups, such as:

  • stress
  • strong emotions, like excitement
  • eating and drinking

In rare cases, hiccups that last longer than 48 hours can be due to a medical condition or a medicine you're taking.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if your hiccups:

  • last longer than 48 hours
  • come back very often and are affecting your life
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment from a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment from a GP

The GP will want to find out if your hiccups are caused by a health condition or medicine you're taking. Treating the condition or changing your medicine should stop your hiccups.

If there's no obvious cause, they might be able to prescribe a medicine called chlorpromazine to treat your hiccups. This does not work for everyone.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
High blood pressure (hypertension):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "High blood pressure (hypertension)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "High blood pressure (hypertension)", "alternateName": ["Hypertension", "Blood pressure (high)"]}, "description": "Find everything you need to know about high blood pressure, including causes, symptoms, diagnosis and treatment, with links to other useful resources.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-10-23T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-10-23T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/", "name": "High blood pressure (hypertension)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-23T14:57:54+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#overview", "description": "High blood pressure, also called hypertension, is when the pressure in your blood vessels is unusually high. It can be serious if not treated.", "text": "

High blood pressure does not usually have any symptoms. The only way to find out if you have it is to get your blood pressure checked.

Things that increase your chances of high blood pressure include being overweight, having an unhealthy diet, smoking and not exercising enough.

Lifestyle changes like eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly can help lower high blood pressure. Some people also need to take medicines.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#symptoms", "description": "High blood pressure does not usually have any symptoms. The only way to find out if you have it is to get your blood pressure checked.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#causes", "description": "Things that increase your chances of high blood pressure include being overweight, having an unhealthy diet, smoking and not exercising enough.", "text": "

It's not always clear what causes high blood pressure, but there are things that can increase your risk.

You might be more at risk if you:

  • are\u00a0overweight
  • eat too much salt and do not eat\u00a0enough fruit and vegetables
  • do not\u00a0do enough exercise
  • drink\u00a0too much\u00a0alcohol\u00a0or\u00a0coffee (or other caffeine-based drinks)
  • smoke
  • do not get much sleep or have disturbed sleep
  • are over 65
  • have a relative with high blood pressure
  • are of black African or black Caribbean descent
  • live in a deprived area

Making healthy lifestyle changes can sometimes help reduce your chances of getting high blood pressure and help lower your blood pressure\u00a0if it's already high.

", "title": "Things that can increase your risk of getting high blood pressure"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#treatments-summary", "description": "Lifestyle changes like eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly can help lower high blood pressure. Some people also need to take medicines.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#self-care", "description": "Lifestyle changes like eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly can help lower high blood pressure. Some people also need to take medicines.", "text": "

These lifestyle changes can help prevent and\u00a0lower high blood pressure:

  • reduce the amount of salt you eat and have a generally healthy diet
  • cut back on alcohol\u00a0
  • lose weight\u00a0if you're overweight
  • exercise\u00a0regularly
  • cut down on caffeine
  • stop smoking

Some people with high blood pressure may also need to take 1 or more medicines to stop their blood pressure getting too high.

", "title": "Lifestyle changes to reduce blood pressure"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/high-blood-pressure-hypertension/#treatments-other", "description": "Lifestyle changes like eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly can help lower high blood pressure. Some people also need to take medicines.", "text": "

If you're diagnosed with high blood pressure, your doctor may recommend taking 1 or more medicines to keep it under control.

These come as tablets and usually need to be\u00a0taken once a day.

Common blood pressure medicines include:

  • ACE inhibitors \u2013 such as enalapril, lisinopril, perindopril and ramipril
  • angiotensin-2 receptor blockers (ARBs) \u2013 such as candesartan, irbesartan, losartan, valsartan and olmesartan
  • calcium channel blockers \u2013 such as amlodipine, felodipine and nifedipine or diltiazem and verapamil
  • diuretics \u2013 such as indapamide and bendroflumethiazide
  • beta blockers \u2013 such as atenolol and bisoprolol
  • alpha blockers \u2013 such as doxazosin
  • other diuretics \u2013 such as amiloride and spironolactone

The medicine recommended for you will depend on things\u00a0like how high your blood pressure is, your age and your ethnicity.

High blood pressure, or hypertension, rarely has noticeable symptoms. But if untreated, it increases your risk of\u00a0serious problems such as heart attacks and\u00a0strokes.

Around a third of adults in the UK have high blood pressure, although many will not realise it.

The only way to find out if your blood pressure is high is to have your blood pressure checked.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

Coronavirus advice

  • British Heart Foundation: what coronavirus means for you if you have heart or circulatory disease
